Posts.Content: If his PSA is high, over 4.0, and it doubled over the last year and his DRE was marked as 'abnormal' then it's time for a biopsy. There is no other option really....Or you can just ignore the warnings and hope for the best....

Posts.Title: Husband wants second PSA test~

Posts.Content: Eligard and Lupron are the same drug and they induce chemical castration and all the wonderful things that implies...The longer you are on it, the more profound the reaction is....One year is not too bad, most men recover quickly from that. Two years treatment, the recovery is slower and not as certain..After 3 years, there is little chance of the comeback, the effect becomes pretty permanent. Much depends on your age..Younger men recover better than older men..Hot flashes day and night. They slowly taper off..Loss of sexual desire and ability..You become impotent but you don't care..Loss of most of your body hair. Slow breast development. Testicles shrink to half their former size..Slow loss of muscle mass replaced with fat (if you are not very careful). But. controlling the cancer now (it does that very nicely) will give your body a chance to fully heal from the surgery before you begin the Radiation Treatment..The radiation will stop the healing process right where it is... In the past, it was thought that 40 fractions was the correct dose rate for radiation. But with todays expanded knowledge and vastly improved equipment, many RO's are finding that a shorter treatment of around 25 fractions work just as well if not better with no increase in toxicity..A side benefit to this is that it's much cheaper and you are done quicker. I would talk to your RO about it. Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Hormone therapy for prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Whether or not your husbands cancer is curable or not is debatable, but when HT is combined with RT, the chances for a cure increase considerably over what can be expected with RT alone..But as you know, there is a heavy price to pay in the way of side-effects..more and more, chemo is being added to the mix also, increasing the side-effect load even more...G-8, 9 & 10 guys play this game much differently than the G-6 & G-7 guys...Make no mistake about it, you are in a fight for your husbands life. Quality of life and long-term survival are sometimes at odds with each other....Only you and your husband can chart your journey..It might be worth traveling to a major cancer treatment center and get a second opinion on a course of treatment that offers the best possible outcome..You only get one chance at this...Best of luck to you both..

Posts.Title: New Member, Many Questions,Central Pa.

Posts.Content: It does no good to worry about things you can do nothing about.....Bring a pair of loose-fitting sweat pants to come home in. When they are setting you up with the catheter, get all the supplies out of them that you can..Extra straps, a day bag and a night bag, all the little bits and pieces. That stuff can be hard to find once you leave the hospital...If your appetite is zero, some "liquid Diet" stuff like "Ensure" and Canada Dry Ginger Ale will usually go down and stay down until you can eat again...Best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: Brew, how old is Dad? Age can make a big difference when choosing treatment options..If the weight loss is unexplained, looking for a different type of cancer might be in order. It's possible to have more than one type of cancer. PC is pretty easy to spot..Other types can be difficult to diagnose...I know you have had enough bad news for one day but we might as well put all the cards on the table...Both you and Dad should read Dr. Walsh's book "Guide to surviving Prostate Cancer". It will give you the background you need to make intelligent treatment decisions..Best of luck to you both...

Posts.Title: Seed implant question about post PSA results

Posts.Content: "Margins: Involved By Invasive Carcinoma Margin Limitations: Less Than 3MM Rt Posterior Primary Pattern 4-" They almost got it all but not quite..Sometimes these positive margins produce nothing, especially "less than 3mm"...You will have to wait a month or two for your first post-op PSA test which should be undetectable. Until then, concentrate on getting yourself fully recovered from the surgery, walk as much as you can...There is really nothing else you can do at this point so don't waste your time worrying about it...

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: Yeah, that Gleason 8 puts you in the high-risk group and at age 48 surgery MIGHT be your best choice.. Posts.Title: New Member, Many Questions,Central Pa.

Posts.Content: It does no good to worry about things you can do nothing about.....Bring a pair of loose-fitting sweat pants to come home in. When they are setting you up with the catheter, get all the supplies out of them that you can..Extra straps, a day bag and a night bag, all the little bits and pieces. That stuff can be hard to find once you leave the hospital...If your appetite is zero, some "liquid Diet" stuff like "Ensure" and Canada Dry Ginger Ale will usually go down and stay down until you can eat again...Best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: What doctors are best at MD Anderson

Posts.Content: A skilled urologist using a modern ultrasound guided biopsy tool has about a 90% chance of finding any cancer present.. 10% of the time, they don't find it, at least not the first time.. It took them 3 tries to find mine...Your insurance company has some rather strict rules about what they will pay for and what they won't. Your tissue samples will go to a local pathology lab. Unless there is reason to doubt their findings, ordering an expert second opinion could cost you $800 if your insurance company balks....

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: Casodex is an older HT drug and is, today, seldom used by itself. It is usually combined with Lupron and the two drugs work in concert..Surgeons however prefer that heavy HT not be used because it makes the prostate gland "sticky" and difficult to work with...I'm just guessing, but perhaps they put you on Casodex as a holding action to limit your cancer growth while not creating more problems for the surgeon..Read Walsh's book..... I too have underwent all three treatments, surgery, radiation and (currently) HT..and my doctors all agreed (after the surgery alone had failed) that it was NOT a waste of time and by removing all the cancer they could by surgery, the radiation and HT had much less cancer to deal with and my life would be prolonged as a result.. On your next blood draw, you might ask that your testosterone level be checked also..With hormone therapy, you need to keep an eye on both sides of the coin....

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: Donelson, when dealing with prostate cancer, there is no such thing as "normal"....Every case is different. Have you read Dr. Walsh's book? I would be questioning your surgeon about whether surgery is the most appropriate, effective treatment at this point..It may very well be that surgery + radiation + hormone treatment is your best course of treatment, your best shot at a cure, but it also subjects you to the heaviest possible side-effect load....Have you consulted with a Radiation Oncologist and Medical Oncologist and heard their opinions on how you should proceed?

Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: After 18 months on HT and an undetectable PSA, my R.O. relented and allowed me to stop the HT. But 6 months later my PSA was no longer undetectable..I went back on Eligard (same as Lupron) but PSA did not return to zero..Medical Oncologist added Casodex (50mg/day) and in October I'll have another check-up and see where I stand..On my own, I'm also doing pomegranate, IP-6, Turmeric as diet supplements. Also 1000mg/day calcium and Vit-D to combat bone loss that can accompany HT.. Should you also undergo surgery as your primary treatment you should know that radiation treatment will stop the recovery process from the surgery..So you want to be fully continent or as continent as possible before you start the radiation..If you are lucky, your first PSA test at 5 weeks after surgery will be zero and that will give you some breathing room to fully recover from the surgery before they start the radiation..I was lucky in that I was dry from day one, but most guys go through a period of incontinence after surgery..
Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Your lymphatic system is a waste draining system, sort of like a sewer system..If some are surgically removed, the drains are tied off, and they can back up. This is called a Lympocele, you could call it an abscess.. Back to the hospital to have the fluid-filled cavity drained..If it's infected, like with staph, now you have serious problems..So removing lymph nodes involves a certain amount of increased risk...

Posts.Content: Mr. Zaman, what country do you live in? In the States you would be offered surgery (to remove the prostate gland) or maybe radiation to kill the cancer in the gland..Hormone therapy (Zoladex and Casodex) would only be used if the surgery or radiation did not cure it...Hormone therapy is not curative..It will control your cancer for a period of time then the cancer will progress.. Gleason 6 is not aggressive cancer and it seldom if ever metastasizes outside the prostate gland. The trouble is you can never be SURE there is no higher grade cancer lurking that the biopsy missed....The only way to know for sure is to remove the gland and do a complete pathology examination on it....

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: With your G-6 and low PSA, either treatment gives you a 95% chance for a full cure....So it becomes a choice of side-effect risk.... Surgery allows for a detailed pathology report of your cancer, which can differ from the limited biopsy report..And, should it fail, you get a second chance for a cure with salvage radiation...But you face a higher risk of impotence and incontinence.. With radiation, the side-effect risk is lower, but there is no second chance should it fail to cure you..Some radiation oncologists combine both seeds and beam radiation to achieve a better success than even surgery provides while still maintaining lower side-effects... You can take your time with this, do your research, investigate the treatment centers that specialize in performing these treatments and have perfected them..At 53, your insurance company (if you have insurance) will have a say in what treatments they are willing to pay for.. You should ask that the treatment provider get pre-approval to avoid any unpleasant surprises.. Best of luck to you and welcome to The Club......

Posts.Content: With your G-6 and low PSA, either treatment gives you a 95% chance for a full cure....So it becomes a choice of side-effect risk.... Surgery allows for a detailed pathology report of your cancer, which can differ from the limited biopsy report..And, should it fail, you get a second chance for a cure with salvage radiation...But you face a higher risk of impotence and incontinence.. With radiation, the side-effect risk is lower, but there is no second chance should it fail to cure you..Some radiation oncologists combine both seeds and beam radiation to achieve a better success than even surgery provides while still maintaining lower side-effects... You can take your time with this, do your research, investigate the treatment centers that specialize in performing these treatments and have perfected them..At 53, your insurance company (if you have insurance) will have a say in what treatments they are willing to pay for.. You should ask that the treatment provider get pre-approval to avoid any unpleasant surprises.. Best of luck to you and welcome to The Club......

The negative side of HRT seems to far outweigh the positive side.....

Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Casodex is an older HT drug and is, today, seldom used by itself. It is usually combined with Lupron and the two drugs work in concert..Surgeons however prefer that heavy HT not be used because it makes the prostate gland "sticky" and difficult to work with...I'm just guessing, but perhaps they put you on Casodex as a holding action to limit your cancer growth while not creating more problems for the surgeon..Read Walsh's book..... I too have underwent all three treatments, surgery, radiation and (currently) HT..and my doctors all agreed (after the surgery alone had failed) that it was NOT a waste of time and by removing all the cancer they could by surgery, the radiation and HT had much less cancer to deal with and my life would be prolonged as a result.. On your next blood draw, you might ask that your testosterone level be checked also..With hormone therapy, you need to keep an eye on both sides of the coin....

While getting a negative biopsy report is a great relief, you need to stay on top of things for a year or two.. Posts.Title: Biopsy last Thursday (7/26/12) came back negative!

Posts.Content: Casodex side effects: chest pain, cough or trouble breathing; feeling short of breath, even with mild exertion; swelling in your hands or feet; fever, chills, body aches, flu symptoms; pale skin, easy bruising or bleeding; blood in your urine; or nausea, pain in your upper stomach, itching, dark urine, clay-colored stools, jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes). Less serious side effects may include: hot flashes; breast pain or swelling; weakness, dizziness; back pain, pelvic pain, joint or muscle pain; increased nighttime urination; upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation; weight changes; impotence, loss of interest in sex, or trouble having an orgasm; dizziness, headache; or sore throat, runny nose or other cold symptoms. I would certainly give your doctor a call. Some men can't tolerate Casodex. Most men have few problems with it..

Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Based on my own observations, a low "T" level is frequently observed in men who have been diagnosed with PC...To me, that means an abnormally low "T" level is possibly a symptom of PC, not a cause of PC....If you are healthy and feel increasing your "T" level and helping to support a new billion dollar class of drugs will somehow benefit you, go for it...But if you have been diagnosed with PC, or possibly have PC that has not been diagnosed, then by feeding the cancer the hormone it craves and needs goes against all accepted medical practice.. Removing testosterone from PC victims bodies is a proven, effective treatment..For a period of time at least, the cancer can be controlled by using "hormone therapy", adding years to patients lives...To move in the opposite direction, intentionally increasing the "T" level in men diagnosed with PC, that would be classified as malpractice...But in the 85% of men who do not have PC or BPH, then boosting "T" levels is harmless at least from the prostates standpoint... The side-effect list attached to these drugs is enough to give anyone pause before jumping on that bandwagon...

Posts.Content: If you can't get your testosterone level down below 10, I would consider an orchiectomy... It is the most effective form of ADT. Some guys just can't handle the psychological end of it but when you are on ADT for the duration what difference does it make? It's cheap and effective..Ask about clinical trials that might work for you including TRANSFORMER. It's a long shot but in your situation so what? In many cases, even if the testosterone injections don't work, they usually "reset" the Xtandi clock so that drug starts working again..Provenge is another treatment that in many men works quite well....It's not time to throw in the towel yet!

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: Mr. Zaman, what country do you live in? In the States you would be offered surgery (to remove the prostate gland) or maybe radiation to kill the cancer in the gland..Hormone therapy (Zoladex and Casodex) would only be used if the surgery or radiation did not cure it...Hormone therapy is not curative..It will control your cancer for a period of time then the cancer will progress.. Gleason 6 is not aggressive cancer and it seldom if ever metastasizes outside the prostate gland. The trouble is you can never be SURE there is no higher grade cancer lurking that the biopsy missed....The only way to know for sure is to remove the gland and do a complete pathology examination on it....

Posts.Content: I would follow your surgeons instructions carefully...Some very delicate work was done re-connecting your plumbing and it will take 3 or 4 months for things to heal up enough too get back to normal..There are many different incontinence products out there including briefs....Find what works best for you and give it a little time..Regaining urinary control is usually a slow and measured process....

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: Yeah, that Gleason 8 puts you in the high-risk group and at age 48 surgery MIGHT be your best choice.. As far as the BEST surgeon working there, I would ask their Director of Oncology that question...But I would also let them evaluate your case completely and find out what ALL your options are..They are one of the top 5 hospitals in the country so you can't go too far wrong...Best of luck to you... If you have not yet read Dr. Pat Walsh's book, "Surviving Prostate Cancer" now would be a good time to do so...

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: After 18 months on HT and an undetectable PSA, my R.O. relented and allowed me to stop the HT. But 6 months later my PSA was no longer undetectable..I went back on Eligard (same as Lupron) but PSA did not return to zero..Medical Oncologist added Casodex (50mg/day) and in October I'll have another check-up and see where I stand..On my own, I'm also doing pomegranate, IP-6, Turmeric as diet supplements. Also 1000mg/day calcium and Vit-D to combat bone loss that can accompany HT.. Should you also undergo surgery as your primary treatment you should know that radiation treatment will stop the recovery process from the surgery..So you want to be fully continent or as continent as possible before you start the radiation..If you are lucky, your first PSA test at 5 weeks after surgery will be zero and that will give you some breathing room to fully recover from the surgery before they start the radiation..I was lucky in that I was dry from day one, but most guys go through a period of incontinence after surgery..

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: "Margins: Involved By Invasive Carcinoma Margin Limitations: Less Than 3MM Rt Posterior Primary Pattern 4-" They almost got it all but not quite..Sometimes these positive margins produce nothing, especially "less than 3mm"...You will have to wait a month or two for your first post-op PSA test which should be undetectable. Until then, concentrate on getting yourself fully recovered from the surgery, walk as much as you can...There is really nothing else you can do at this point so don't waste your time worrying about it...

Posts.Title: My Pathology Staging Info, Could Use Some Thoughts On This

Posts.Content: Eligard and Lupron are the same drug and they induce chemical castration and all the wonderful things that implies...The longer you are on it, the more profound the reaction is....One year is not too bad, most men recover quickly from that. Two years treatment, the recovery is slower and not as certain..After 3 years, there is little chance of the comeback, the effect becomes pretty permanent. Much depends on your age..Younger men recover better than older men..Hot flashes day and night. They slowly taper off..Loss of sexual desire and ability..You become impotent but you don't care..Loss of most of your body hair. Slow breast development. Testicles shrink to half their former size..Slow loss of muscle mass replaced with fat (if you are not very careful). But. controlling the cancer now (it does that very nicely) will give your body a chance to fully heal from the surgery before you begin the Radiation Treatment..The radiation will stop the healing process right where it is... In the past, it was thought that 40 fractions was the correct dose rate for radiation. But with todays expanded knowledge and vastly improved equipment, many RO's are finding that a shorter treatment of around 25 fractions work just as well if not better with no increase in toxicity..A side benefit to this is that it's much cheaper and you are done quicker. I would talk to your RO about it. Best of luck to you...

Posts.Content: Brew, how old is Dad? Age can make a big difference when choosing treatment options..If the weight loss is unexplained, looking for a different type of cancer might be in order. It's possible to have more than one type of cancer. PC is pretty easy to spot..Other types can be difficult to diagnose...I know you have had enough bad news for one day but we might as well put all the cards on the table...Both you and Dad should read Dr. Walsh's book "Guide to surviving Prostate Cancer". It will give you the background you need to make intelligent treatment decisions..Best of luck to you both...

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: It does no good to worry about things you can do nothing about.....Bring a pair of loose-fitting sweat pants to come home in. When they are setting you up with the catheter, get all the supplies out of them that you can..Extra straps, a day bag and a night bag, all the little bits and pieces. That stuff can be hard to find once you leave the hospital...If your appetite is zero, some "liquid Diet" stuff like "Ensure" and Canada Dry Ginger Ale will usually go down and stay down until you can eat again...Best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: Donelson, when dealing with prostate cancer, there is no such thing as "normal"....Every case is different. Have you read Dr. Walsh's book? I would be questioning your surgeon about whether surgery is the most appropriate, effective treatment at this point..It may very well be that surgery + radiation + hormone treatment is your best course of treatment, your best shot at a cure, but it also subjects you to the heaviest possible side-effect load....Have you consulted with a Radiation Oncologist and Medical Oncologist and heard their opinions on how you should proceed?

Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Casodex is an older HT drug and is, today, seldom used by itself. It is usually combined with Lupron and the two drugs work in concert..Surgeons however prefer that heavy HT not be used because it makes the prostate gland "sticky" and difficult to work with...I'm just guessing, but perhaps they put you on Casodex as a holding action to limit your cancer growth while not creating more problems for the surgeon..Read Walsh's book..... I too have underwent all three treatments, surgery, radiation and (currently) HT..and my doctors all agreed (after the surgery alone had failed) that it was NOT a waste of time and by removing all the cancer they could by surgery, the radiation and HT had much less cancer to deal with and my life would be prolonged as a result.. On your next blood draw, you might ask that your testosterone level be checked also..With hormone therapy, you need to keep an eye on both sides of the coin....

Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: After 18 months on HT and an undetectable PSA, my R.O. relented and allowed me to stop the HT. But 6 months later my PSA was no longer undetectable..I went back on Eligard (same as Lupron) but PSA did not return to zero..Medical Oncologist added Casodex (50mg/day) and in October I'll have another check-up and see where I stand..On my own, I'm also doing pomegranate, IP-6, Turmeric as diet supplements. Also 1000mg/day calcium and Vit-D to combat bone loss that can accompany HT.. Should you also undergo surgery as your primary treatment you should know that radiation treatment will stop the recovery process from the surgery..So you want to be fully continent or as continent as possible before you start the radiation..If you are lucky, your first PSA test at 5 weeks after surgery will be zero and that will give you some breathing room to fully recover from the surgery before they start the radiation..I was lucky in that I was dry from day one, but most guys go through a period of incontinence after surgery..

Posts.Title: Diet

Posts.Content: I would follow your surgeons instructions carefully...Some very delicate work was done re-connecting your plumbing and it will take 3 or 4 months for things to heal up enough too get back to normal..There are many different incontinence products out there including briefs....Find what works best for you and give it a little time..Regaining urinary control is usually a slow and measured process....

Posts.Title: do i have pc?

Posts.Content: Whether or not your husbands cancer is curable or not is debatable, but when HT is combined with RT, the chances for a cure increase considerably over what can be expected with RT alone..But as you know, there is a heavy price to pay in the way of side-effects..more and more, chemo is being added to the mix also, increasing the side-effect load even more...G-8, 9 & 10 guys play this game much differently than the G-6 & G-7 guys...Make no mistake about it, you are in a fight for your husbands life. Quality of life and long-term survival are sometimes at odds with each other....Only you and your husband can chart your journey..It might be worth traveling to a major cancer treatment center and get a second opinion on a course of treatment that offers the best possible outcome..You only get one chance at this...Best of luck to you both..

Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: If you can't get your testosterone level down below 10, I would consider an orchiectomy... It is the most effective form of ADT. Some guys just can't handle the psychological end of it but when you are on ADT for the duration what difference does it make? It's cheap and effective..Ask about clinical trials that might work for you including TRANSFORMER. It's a long shot but in your situation so what? In many cases, even if the testosterone injections don't work, they usually "reset" the Xtandi clock so that drug starts working again..Provenge is another treatment that in many men works quite well....It's not time to throw in the towel yet!

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: A skilled urologist using a modern ultrasound guided biopsy tool has about a 90% chance of finding any cancer present.. 10% of the time, they don't find it, at least not the first time.. It took them 3 tries to find mine...Your insurance company has some rather strict rules about what they will pay for and what they won't. Your tissue samples will go to a local pathology lab. Unless there is reason to doubt their findings, ordering an expert second opinion could cost you $800 if your insurance company balks....

Posts.Title: do i have pc?

Posts.Content: With your G-6 and low PSA, either treatment gives you a 95% chance for a full cure....So it becomes a choice of side-effect risk.... Surgery allows for a detailed pathology report of your cancer, which can differ from the limited biopsy report..And, should it fail, you get a second chance for a cure with salvage radiation...But you face a higher risk of impotence and incontinence.. With radiation, the side-effect risk is lower, but there is no second chance should it fail to cure you..Some radiation oncologists combine both seeds and beam radiation to achieve a better success than even surgery provides while still maintaining lower side-effects... You can take your time with this, do your research, investigate the treatment centers that specialize in performing these treatments and have perfected them..At 53, your insurance company (if you have insurance) will have a say in what treatments they are willing to pay for.. You should ask that the treatment provider get pre-approval to avoid any unpleasant surprises.. Best of luck to you and welcome to The Club......

If it does NOT cut your PSA in half, then it's time for another biopsy....

Posts.Content: Your lymphatic system is a waste draining system, sort of like a sewer system..If some are surgically removed, the drains are tied off, and they can back up. This is called a Lympocele, you could call it an abscess.. Back to the hospital to have the fluid-filled cavity drained..If it's infected, like with staph, now you have serious problems..So removing lymph nodes involves a certain amount of increased risk...

Posts.Title: L nodes ?

Posts.Content: Based on my own observations, a low "T" level is frequently observed in men who have been diagnosed with PC...To me, that means an abnormally low "T" level is possibly a symptom of PC, not a cause of PC....If you are healthy and feel increasing your "T" level and helping to support a new billion dollar class of drugs will somehow benefit you, go for it...But if you have been diagnosed with PC, or possibly have PC that has not been diagnosed, then by feeding the cancer the hormone it craves and needs goes against all accepted medical practice.. Removing testosterone from PC victims bodies is a proven, effective treatment..For a period of time at least, the cancer can be controlled by using "hormone therapy", adding years to patients lives...To move in the opposite direction, intentionally increasing the "T" level in men diagnosed with PC, that would be classified as malpractice...But in the 85% of men who do not have PC or BPH, then boosting "T" levels is harmless at least from the prostates standpoint... The side-effect list attached to these drugs is enough to give anyone pause before jumping on that bandwagon...

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: Casodex side effects: chest pain, cough or trouble breathing; feeling short of breath, even with mild exertion; swelling in your hands or feet; fever, chills, body aches, flu symptoms; pale skin, easy bruising or bleeding; blood in your urine; or nausea, pain in your upper stomach, itching, dark urine, clay-colored stools, jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes). Less serious side effects may include: hot flashes; breast pain or swelling; weakness, dizziness; back pain, pelvic pain, joint or muscle pain; increased nighttime urination; upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation; weight changes; impotence, loss of interest in sex, or trouble having an orgasm; dizziness, headache; or sore throat, runny nose or other cold symptoms. I would certainly give your doctor a call. Some men can't tolerate Casodex. Most men have few problems with it..

Posts.Title: HT while awaiting surgery...flu like side effects?

Posts.Content: You want to be completely recovered from the surgery before you start radiation...Especially incontinence issues...Radiation will stop the recovery process right where it is....E.D. and incontinence are locked in. There will be no further improvement..But yes, when HT is combined with RT, the duration is usually between 1 and 2 years. Sometimes 3 years..There is a lot of debate about how long is necessary to achieve the desired result....

Posts.Title: Hormone therapy..how long?

Posts.Content: Any man can get a PSA test for around $40 without a doctors prescription. You just walk into a medical lab or street clinic and ask for one...Few men are aware of this pathway to a potentially life-saving blood test.... 230,000 men will be diagnosed with PC his year, their cancers detected initially by a PSA test! 34,000 will die from it...It's insane to suppress the use of this life-saving test !! If we don't find it, maybe it will just go away...Good luck with that....

Posts.Content: You are correct Mike...Who you find on these forums are Newbies looking for information and guys who's treatment did not result in a complete cure...Also, some guys who's treatment resulted in a cure but at a price of heavy side-effects like incontinence or ED that does not respond to the solutions offered.....And this poses a problem...The Newbies get a somewhat twisted picture of what lies in store for them because they never meet the 65% of PC victims who are cured, have minimal side-effects, and move on......

Posts.Title: opinion needed

Posts.Content: 5+3=8 is a somewhat unusual Gleason finding...I would have one of the 2 expert labs take a look at your husbands slides to verify those findings. Epstein at Johns-Hopkins or Bostwick Labs..How his treatment will proceed depends a lot on an accurate Gleason score...5+3 is high-risk prostate cancer and it must be treated very aggressively to achieve a cure or long-term survival. Surgery is not the "Gold Standard" it was just a few years ago. Investigate all your other treatment options. If you decide on surgery, choose your surgeon carefully. You want the best one available to you...Best of luck to you....

Posts.Title: Stage 4 Guys, Have You Tried This One ??

Posts.Content: My PSA was 230 before I started dosetaxel chemo treatments. After the second treatment, it had dropped to 143 so I was happy about that, it had been doubling every 28 days..But after the third treatment it had gone back up to 160. We tried a forth infusion but it continued to climb. Hoping that the chemo might have "reset" the cancer so Zytiga would work again, but it was not..So now, waiting for a new set of scans then possibly a biopsy (bone biopsy) to see if I have any useful genetic markers that would make immunotherapy effective..So in the meantime I'm trying Cyclophosphamide just to hold the lid on things for the time being..If I get lucky, maybe it will prove effective..

Posts.Title: Stage 4 Guys, Have You Tried This One ??

Posts.Content: There is the standard test (0.1) and the ultra-sensitive test (0.03)..In the real world, salvage treatment is unlikely to start if the PSA is below 0.3 or 0.2 regardless of the test used....With the ultra-sensitive test, results tend to jump around a bit normally. This can produce a lot of "PSA Anxiety" , needless worry over that, in the end, doesn't make any difference in the overall outcome..The two tests are priced about the same....Worrying about cancer can be just as debilitating as the cancer itself...

Posts.Title: Ultra-sensitive PSA test?

Posts.Content: Sooner or later the ADT (Lupron et-al), the Zytiga, the Xtandi and the Doxetaxel all stop working..Things can start to look pretty bleak..My Onco suggested I try Cyclophosphamide, an older, cheaper, almost forgotten oral chemo (one pill a day along with Prednisone) that has proven very effective in treating advanced prostate cancer..It is well tolerated and carries a low side-effect load. When you are running out of options it's certainly worth a try. You might ask your Onco about it...

Posts.Content: You must yourself heal completely from the surgery before you start radiation..The radiation will stop the healing process right where it is...if you are still a little incontinent you will remain that way....Also, radiation treatments can be VERY expensive..Don't bankrupt yourself, get a solid estimate of your out-of-pocket expenses before you start.. There are people who can help....

Posts.Content: 5+3=8 is a somewhat unusual Gleason finding...I would have one of the 2 expert labs take a look at your husbands slides to verify those findings. Epstein at Johns-Hopkins or Bostwick Labs..How his treatment will proceed depends a lot on an accurate Gleason score...5+3 is high-risk prostate cancer and it must be treated very aggressively to achieve a cure or long-term survival. Surgery is not the "Gold Standard" it was just a few years ago. Investigate all your other treatment options. If you decide on surgery, choose your surgeon carefully. You want the best one available to you...Best of luck to you....

Posts.Title: Husband recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Don't wait 3 months...abstain from sex and bike riding for 72 hours and get another PSA test. If it's over 5, make an appointment to see a URO. Any DRE performed by a "she" internist has little value..If the URO feels a biopsy is called for, DO IT ! If you are scared to death about what a biopsy might find, you will REALLY be scared when your PSA is over 30 and the URO tells you a biopsy is no longer necessary and he refers you to a Medical Oncologist...You can go to any number of walk-in labs and get a PSA test without a prescription. You will have the results in a few hours..

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: The ADT therapy you are on can produce a complete remission, the cancer becoming undetectable to the normally used scans...You can indeed stop the ADT drugs and allow your testosterone to slowly return to normal..At the same time you would be wise to check your PSA level monthly and see if your cancer is also responding to the testosterone..You should be aware that some rare types of aggressive prostate cancer produce no PSA so the PSA test is useless for tracking these cancers...I too am on ADT and would like a "vacation" from it..My Oncologist is very much against it. He says if you let your cancer progress unchecked even for a short period, it can be very difficult to get it under control again..Looks like you have modified your diet and are taking a few supplements..You might check out one called Pomi-T. it can't hurt.. At age 48, I would be looking at the most aggressive treatment available including any clinical trials that offer the latest drugs and treatment techniques...It might be worth traveling to one of the big cancer research and treatment centers where the latest scans and diagnostic tools are available.. Best of luck to you.. The reason surgery or radiation was not offered to you is because the scans showed the cancer has metastasized, spread beyond the primary tumor. But if your scans are now clean, no detectable spread, then IGRT, beam radiation, might be worthwhile and available to you...Talk to a Radiation Oncologist about it..

Posts.Title: New on Forum, my background & question about discontinuing T-suppression meds.

Posts.Content: If a surgeon did 5 RALP's a week, he would perform 250 operations a year..If he got paid $2000 for each operation (out of the $30,000-$40,000 charged) he would make $500,000 a year..It would take him 6 years to reach maximum proficiency if the 1600 figure is correct...In order to perform the 90,000 prostatectomy's done every year, 400 surgeons are needed working at the 5 a week rate.. My surgeon did no more than 3 a week...So maybe in the real world, there are 1000 surgeons doing these operations... So when a surgeon begins his career doing robotic surgeries, some poor bugger has to be #1, # 2 and number 3...and number 100...These poor guys are lucky just to come out of the operating room alive..Expecting to be cured of their cancers, expecting to remain continent and potent, that would be like depending on miracles..I guess we should just be happy we live in a place where articles like this get published and patients can do a little research before they let the smiling anesthesiologist stick that needle in their arm...

AgeInfo.Phrase: In order to perform the 90 000 prostatectomy's done every year

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: Sooner or later the ADT (Lupron et-al), the Zytiga, the Xtandi and the Doxetaxel all stop working..Things can start to look pretty bleak..My Onco suggested I try Cyclophosphamide, an older, cheaper, almost forgotten oral chemo (one pill a day along with Prednisone) that has proven very effective in treating advanced prostate cancer..It is well tolerated and carries a low side-effect load. When you are running out of options it's certainly worth a try. You might ask your Onco about it...

Posts.Title: Stage 4 Guys, Have You Tried This One ??

Posts.Content: There are two types of PSA test, Standard and Ultra-sensitive..You are getting the ultra-sensitive test which can produce a lot of PSA anxiety..You may have other issues going on back-stage (insurance) so that may be playing a part in treatment recommendations. Radiation treatment is very expensive.. So waiting until October to start that is not unreasonable..if your PSA continues to rise, they can clamp it and prepare you for radiation treatment by starting adjunct ADT now..At some point you need to consult with a Radiation Oncologist and get his thoughts....

Posts.Title: Radiation recovery time

Posts.Content: We all go through this...Every case is different...The lymph node positive is, as you know, not good news...But hubby can STILL get lucky and beat this...MAYBE, just maybe, radiation can get it all...It's expensive, the odds are not in your favor and your insurance company might balk..But it might be worth doing if you can make it happen..If your lead doctor is a urologist /surgeon, it's time to consult with a Medical Oncologist, preferably one who specializes in prostate cancer, to develop a treatment plan to extend your husbands life as long as possible..Quality of life plays an important role in these decisions..In many cases, prostate cancer can be controlled for a long period of time without unacceptable quality of life issues...I'm a G9, facing the same situation, but I'm 70 years old so things are a little different..... Best of luck to you both....

Posts.Title: Urgent Advice Needed. Gleason 9

Posts.Content: The only way to measure the EXACT size of a prostate gland is to cut it out and put it on a scale....Low-grade PC (Gleason 6) seldom if ever metastasizes so it all comes out with the package.. Even today's sophisticated scans can not determine where the cancer ends and the healthy tissue begins.. Higher grade PC (G-8, 9, 10) frequently metastasize, cancer cells moving through the bloodstream and lymphatic system and these are virtually impossible to detect or completely eliminate. We try and sometimes succeed..but in many cases, success is not possible..The Grim Reaper can only be held off for so long...

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer size

Posts.Content: Don't wait 3 months...abstain from sex and bike riding for 72 hours and get another PSA test. If it's over 5, make an appointment to see a URO. Any DRE performed by a "she" internist has little value..If the URO feels a biopsy is called for, DO IT ! If you are scared to death about what a biopsy might find, you will REALLY be scared when your PSA is over 30 and the URO tells you a biopsy is no longer necessary and he refers you to a Medical Oncologist...You can go to any number of walk-in labs and get a PSA test without a prescription. You will have the results in a few hours..

Posts.Title: I now have a catheter...

Posts.Content: Lupron is a cash-cow for urologists, who seen to be the ones who get to administer it.. Yes, the effect lasts longer than advertised. For most men, after 2 years on HT, the effect is more or less permanent..The 6 month shot does not cost much more than the 3 month...(about $2000). You can never assume HT will reduce your PSA to undetectable..You list your PSA as 0.1 Or is it <0.1? <0.1 means your PSA IS undetectable using the standard test...Now if your doctor prescribes the ultra-sensitive test, you can take it out to .001, but why? Just more to worry about...

Posts.Title: Frustration

Posts.Content: Welcome to our little club...Yes, read Walsh's book. Then maybe read Dr. Chodaks book, shorter and to the point, it goes over the treatment options with a fine tooth comb. "Winning the battle Against Prostate Cancer" something like that..Also, most Urologists are also surgeons, Dr. Walsh is one of the best, so these specialists naturally favor surgery..It was once the Gold Standard for treating prostate cancer. But that is no longer true, radiation in its many forms has made great advances over the past 10 or 15 years to where now it equals or exceeds surgery in effectiveness..Talk to a Medical Oncologist, they have seen it all and they get to treat those for whom surgery and radiation have failed. They can offer worthwhile insights you won't get from Urologists, surgeons, Radiation Oncologists.. best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: Pls Recommend Urologist - newly diagnosed!!!

Posts.Content: These drugs, by themselves, have very few side effects..The "side effects" you are experiencing are what castration feels like, chemical or otherwise....When your testosterone drops to near zero, you are going to experience some pretty unpleasant hormone withdrawal symptoms..Hot flashes, total loss of sexual ability and desire, weight gain, fatigue, loss of muscle mass...Welcome to the club.. Perhaps you should be seeing a Medical Oncologist as your "team leader" when it comes to developing a treatment plan...Urologists are operating outside their skill-set when it comes to hormone therapy..But they tend to hang on because the money is so good. Lupron, Eligard, Firmagone, these drugs all do the same thing and they compete with each other for a slice of the pie. The doctor who gives you the shot gets a big kick-back from the company who made the drug..All kinds of backstage wheeling and dealing...List price for Lupron or Eligard is about $2900 for the 6 month dose..Firmagon is a little more...Nobody pays list price except uninsured cash customers. Medicare pays about $1000 leaving you with a $200 co-pay.... If your cancer has metastasized and you are on these drugs for life, you might as well do the physical castration a one time $800-$1000 charge. No more shots or possible drug side-effects and it offers the lowest possible testosterone reading...

Posts.Title: New Member/Maiden Voyage

Posts.Content: Three years is a long time for adjunct hormone treatment...You are correct in that you won't know if the SRT worked until you stop taking the hormone drugs..The ultra-sensitive PSA test you are using tends to bounce around so you can view 0.02-0.05 as undetectable. The standard test is close enough at this point and >0.1 is also viewed as undetectable without all the drama..After 18 months on HT and undetectable PSA, I persuaded my R.O. to take me off the shots a little early..I stayed undetectable for 6 months but then a 0.3 PSA....I'm back on HT for the duration....The problem with 3 years on the HT drugs, after that long, the effect of the drugs becomes more or less permanent. Your testicles atrophy and that's that....Also, you only get so much effectiveness out of HT..After a while you become "Hormone Refractory", your cancer progresses.. There is plenty of debate about how long "adjunct HT" needs to be administered to get the added benefit from the RT / HT package...The quality of life problems caused by 3 years of HT may be too high a price to pay for the benefit achieved...Many R.O.'s feel 18 months to 2 years works almost as good as 3 years. Some only use 1 year to limit quality of life problems..

Posts.Title: Suspect Alternative to Biopsy from first time confused poster

Posts.Content: You have two choices, Surgery or Radiation. Both work equally well, so comes down to a choice of side-effect risk..In my opinion, the most effective radiation treatment is Brachy (seeds) plus IGRT used in combination. You can add a year of hormone therapy to that mix, but that increases the side-effects considerably... Regardless of what you do, it's worth the effort to find the best surgeon or radiation oncologist available to you to perform these treatments...But in the end, YOU will have to make the choice of what treatment is best for YOU.

Posts.Title: active watch for 2 years and now gleason 8...what now

Posts.Content: Dr Walsh's book writing is a sideline..He is a pioneer in the treatment of Prostate Cancer. Be sure you were reading the 3rd edition of his book..There is debate as to when to start HT after curative measures have failed..Every case is different..Every case responds differently to treatment. Some men get a nice, long remission on HT while in others the disease progresses rapidly regardless of treatment..Some men can go on prolonged HT "vacations" and their PSA behaves or advances slowly..In others, as soon as testosterone levels begin to climb, the PSA levels increase rapidly and can be very hard to get back under control.... Dr Walsh is a master surgeon and Urologist. He also knows much about Oncology as it relates to prostate cancer..But he is NOT a Medical Oncologist and he seldom treats PC patients once metastasis is detected..The exact methods and timetables used in the palliative treatment of terminal cancer patients is not his area of expertise. But you can be sure whatever appears in his book has the full approval of the Oncology department at Johns-Hopkins..His book is considered "The Bible" for good reason... http://urology.jhu.edu/patrickwalsh/

Posts.Title: Is Dr. Walsh's book current on early vs late hormone therapy?

Posts.Content: Lupron shots can cause a temporary spike in testosterone levels which can cause an increase in PSA and prostate cancer symptoms..Oncologists usually prescribe a 30 day treatment of Casodex to suppress the effects of this testosterone spike..Thirty days after the shot, "T" levels are usually at castrate levels and PSA can be expected to register a sharp drop. Four to six months out, PSA will be as low as it's going to get...A newer "hormone" drug, Firmagon, lowers testosterone without any "bounce" so the Casodex is not needed..
Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before My Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Hormone therapy is used in one of two ways..First as an adjunct to some other form of primary treatment be it surgery or radiation. Studies have shown it can increase the effectiveness of SRT, salvage radiation treatment, and it can also be used to augment any radiation treatment. Radiation Oncologists love it because it makes them look good both in the short term and hopefully in the long term.. In the past, HT was used as a primary treatment for late-stage PC discovered before the age of the PSA test. Physical castration was the method employed. This never CURED anyone of Prostate Cancer, but it gave them several years of survival improvement. Today, it still offers no cure, it's a palliative treatment, and drugs are used instead of castration. Since it's effective and relatively inexpensive, it's still used before the newer, far more expensive therapies that are now available..When the HT stops working and the patients PSA continues to rise, it's referred to as becoming "hormone refractory".. The downside of HT are the side-effects...They begin with hot flashes which can be severe, many men feel fatigued and listless, some suffer emotional upsets, all sex drive and ability quickly evaporates, breast development begins, body hair disappears, ones personality becomes a lot more "mellow"... Not everyone suffers all these things at the same time, but as the duration of treatment grows longer, the side-effects become more prominent..The unspoken truth is that few men have to endure HT for prolonged periods of time....Another unspoken truth, the longer you are on HT, the longer it takes to recover from it and after 3 years or so, the effect of the drugs becomes permanent in most men... Men without health insurance might wish to consider physical castration as the long-term cost of the drugs used can be quite high. Castration is the least expensive form of HT and it's thought to be the most effective as it lowers testosterone levels to almost nothing...

Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before My Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Lupron shots can cause a temporary spike in testosterone levels which can cause an increase in PSA and prostate cancer symptoms..Oncologists usually prescribe a 30 day treatment of Casodex to suppress the effects of this testosterone spike..Thirty days after the shot, "T" levels are usually at castrate levels and PSA can be expected to register a sharp drop. Four to six months out, PSA will be as low as it's going to get...A newer "hormone" drug, Firmagon, lowers testosterone without any "bounce" so the Casodex is not needed..

Four to six months out, PSA will be as low as it's going to get...A newer "hormone" drug, Firmagon, lowers testosterone without any "bounce" so the Casodex is not needed..
Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before My Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Hormone therapy is used in one of two ways..First as an adjunct to some other form of primary treatment be it surgery or radiation. Studies have shown it can increase the effectiveness of SRT, salvage radiation treatment, and it can also be used to augment any radiation treatment. Radiation Oncologists love it because it makes them look good both in the short term and hopefully in the long term.. In the past, HT was used as a primary treatment for late-stage PC discovered before the age of the PSA test. Physical castration was the method employed. This never CURED anyone of Prostate Cancer, but it gave them several years of survival improvement. Today, it still offers no cure, it's a palliative treatment, and drugs are used instead of castration. Since it's effective and relatively inexpensive, it's still used before the newer, far more expensive therapies that are now available..When the HT stops working and the patients PSA continues to rise, it's referred to as becoming "hormone refractory".. The downside of HT are the side-effects...They begin with hot flashes which can be severe, many men feel fatigued and listless, some suffer emotional upsets, all sex drive and ability quickly evaporates, breast development begins, body hair disappears, ones personality becomes a lot more "mellow"... Not everyone suffers all these things at the same time, but as the duration of treatment grows longer, the side-effects become more prominent..The unspoken truth is that few men have to endure HT for prolonged periods of time....Another unspoken truth, the longer you are on HT, the longer it takes to recover from it and after 3 years or so, the effect of the drugs becomes permanent in most men... Men without health insurance might wish to consider physical castration as the long-term cost of the drugs used can be quite high. Castration is the least expensive form of HT and it's thought to be the most effective as it lowers testosterone levels to almost nothing...

Posts.Title: What do you guys make of this?

Posts.Content: You have two choices, Surgery or Radiation. Both work equally well, so comes down to a choice of side-effect risk..In my opinion, the most effective radiation treatment is Brachy (seeds) plus IGRT used in combination. You can add a year of hormone therapy to that mix, but that increases the side-effects considerably... Regardless of what you do, it's worth the effort to find the best surgeon or radiation oncologist available to you to perform these treatments...But in the end, YOU will have to make the choice of what treatment is best for YOU.

Posts.Title: Near total continence 8 days post op--is this possible?

Posts.Content: Welcome to our little club.... You might wish to pick up a copy of Dr. Pat Walsh's book, "Surviving Prostate Cancer" to get a much broader understanding of what is going on. If you choose surgery (you have other choices) know that the skill of the surgeon is all-important..The BEST surgeons get considerably better results than the not so good ones...So do your homework when choosing your surgeon..There are two types of surgery, open or robotic. They both work equally well, again, success depends on the skill of the surgeon...Best of luck to both you and your Dad...

Posts.Content: Chances are, you have a UTI, not PC so get ready for a run of antibiotics before any biopsies.. Your urologist should do a DRE and if that's abnormal, THEN a biopsy for sure..But yeah,PSA 23, that may be more than what an infection could produce....

Posts.Title: Can't sleep in Thailand - high PSA result

Posts.Content: I too was continent from day one...Now, 5 years out and having gone through RT, I'm still continent but I have to be careful about certain activities and when the urge comes, I need to find a place quickly....
Posts.Title: Near total continence 8 days post op--is this possible?

Posts.Content: It's hard to give an answer because every case is different..Some men get a long-term remission out of HT & chemo and some men do not...Generally speaking, the lower that PSA number goes during the first year of treatment, the longer the remission will last..Provenge and Xtandi are two advanced treatments that might benefit your husband..

Posts.Title: ED Meds Cost (Cialis)

Posts.Content: The PSA test has saved countless numbers of mens lives..Prostate cancer was once a death sentence with the DRE being the only diagnostic tool...There are newer non-invasive blood and urine tests just coming to market that are far more accurate in spotting prostate cancer or ruling it out without the need for a biopsy. Patent lawyers and the big testing labs are working it all out backstage..So in the meantime, we still must rely on the PSA test to sound the alarm and give men the chance to be treated early when the disease is still curable..You now have two PSA numbers which will be of great value as time goes on and your risk factor increases..Few young men know what their "normal" PSA number is. But you do. That can be quite an advantage and can save a lot of guesswork in the future...
Posts.Title: PSA Score high and only 36

Posts.Content: If your cancer has been cured by the surgery, you have no reason to feel blue...Incontinence and impotence are two of the things many of us face and we deal with it. Sometimes things get better and sometimes not. But at least you are here able to talk about them.....Count your blessings...
Posts.Title: 16 Month Post Op Blues

Posts.Content: The 90% cure rate ("cure" means you are still alive 10 years out...) only applies to organ confined disease...Every case is different. While these charts and tables can give you an idea of your overall odds, don't bet the farm on them. Use them as a guide only.....At this point, there is a lot of guesswork going on..Should you choose surgery, the entire prostate gland will receive a thorough biopsy and at that point most of the guesswork will be removed and survival chances better understood...

Posts.Title: I'm Confused by Han and Partin Table Stats

Posts.Content: Ask your primary care doctor to refer you to see a urologist..They have the skills and the training to sort this out in short order..If you are going to worry yourself to death, you might as well have a biopsy if you think that will put your mind at ease..But a biopsy is fairly expensive and is not exactly something to look forward to... You have now established a PSA base line, 3.3 The last test was 2.8, going down..Going down is always good..Wait 6 or 8 months and have another one. In the meantime, don't make yourself sick by worrying about it...

Posts.Title: 1 month post op PSA check.

Posts.Content: Are you referring to a PSA test report? Then yes, 164 is a number that must be investigated and explained....Several things can cause abnormally high PSA readings. Your Urologist will (should) investigate all the other possibilities before performing a biopsy to check for cancer..You should know that there are men walking around will no cancer symptoms with PSA levels of 1000 or more..So don't be giving yourself a death sentence just yet !

Posts.Title: 164 ng/ml?

Posts.Content: Get a copy of Dr. Walsh's book and read it. See the sticky thread at the top of this forum..Diagnosing PC is a step by step process and the first step was the PSA test. Next comes the 12 core TRUS guided biopsy. If positive, then will come the MRI and bone scans. Then your Urologist will recommend a treatment plan, offering several choices, taking all the evidence into consideration... A high PSA number does not necessarily mean aggressive cancer...With prostate cancer, some of the more aggressive types produce very little PSA.. Be sure you get pre-approval and find out what the co-pays will be before doing any tests or treatments..

Posts.Content: Medical treatment costs are out of control and 3T MRI scans are very expensive and are likely to stay that way..Should cancer be found, the cost of treating it can sore into the stratosphere..Insurance companies can be expected to resist at every turn... They want to stop giving men PSA tests...You want them, instead, to switch to an annual MRI screening? Not going to happen..Get sick and die. Much cheaper than prolonged treatment that ends at the same place...

Posts.Content: At least 300..Surgery is pretty aggressive treatment for G-6 PC....How many of your cores were positive? What percentage of the positive cores was cancer? If you don't have a copy of the biopsy pathology report, ask for one and study it carefully.. With surgery, the surgeons skill is all important..The best surgeons achieve considerably better results than the mediocre ones...

Posts.Content: Get a copy of Dr. Walsh's book and read it. See the sticky thread at the top of this forum..Diagnosing PC is a step by step process and the first step was the PSA test. Next comes the 12 core TRUS guided biopsy. If positive, then will come the MRI and bone scans. Then your Urologist will recommend a treatment plan, offering several choices, taking all the evidence into consideration... A high PSA number does not necessarily mean aggressive cancer...With prostate cancer, some of the more aggressive types produce very little PSA.. Be sure you get pre-approval and find out what the co-pays will be before doing any tests or treatments..

Posts.Title: My Husband has triple digit PSA

Posts.Content: The problem with biopsies, you can't DEPEND on them to have detected ALL the tumors..You still could be harboring a more aggressive tumor that the biopsy needles missed...Prostate Cancer tends to be multi-focal..When complete organs are biopsied after surgery, the average number of tumors found is 7...If they are all Gleason 6, no problem...But if one turns out to be Gleason 8, then you will be glad you had the surgery..With your family history, your age, surgery may indeed be your best bet. Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Recently, the Social Security Administration has added stage 4 prostate cancer (hormone refractory and or mets) to their "Compassionate Allowance" program which fast-tracts applicants so they can begin receiving benefits in a month or two... As I understand it, SSDI, Social Security Disability Income is for people under 65 and SSI, Supplemental Security Income is for those over 65. Many of us are unaware these programs even exist. You can call 1-800-772-1213 to make an appointment at your local SS office. Be sure to mention the Compassionate Allowance program to greatly speed up the process... While you can own a house and a car, if other assets total over $2000 it would seem you are out of luck for SSI but not SSDI. Make the call and find out.

Posts.Title: SSDI & SSI available for Stage 4 people...

Posts.Content: So I made the phone call and asked the questions..If you are already collecting Social Security Retirement Benefits you are ineligible to collect Disability Benefits...You can't get them both..So if you are over 65 you can forget SSDI. You CAN get SSI, Supplemental Security Income but only if you have very limited assets and your SS retirement check is less than around $800.......

Posts.Content: G-9 is considered "high-risk" and it is NOT unusual for the surgeon to recommend "adjutant" radiation treatment following surgery, especially if the post-surgery pathology report is less than perfect...Recent studies have demonstrated that by adding hormone treatment to the radiation, the radiation becomes 50% more effective than when it is used alone... Debating "salvage" and "adjunct" radiation is just nit-picking, really...It is important that you get yourself as continent as possible before any adjunct radiation treatment as the radiation pretty much stops progress on that front..Going on HT can buy you time in that regard...

Posts.Title: First Post M- CRPC What now?

Posts.Content: The same thing happened to me, quite suddenly I developed a complete blockage. This was after (months later) I had prostate surgery..Uro did a scope job (Cystoscope) and found a small bladder stone obstructing and irritating my urethra..He was able to remove the stone with an attachment on the 'scope and that was that..Catheter was removed the next day and no more problems... I would think a careful Cystoscope examination by an expert urologist would be able to find the source of your Dad's problem.....

Posts.Title: Why can't my dad pee (and will he ever on his own again)?

Posts.Content: In the past, chemo was reserved until other treatments had failed. Recent studies have shown it's more effective if used first instead of last...It has also been discovered that bringing Zytiga (abiraterone) in sooner also works better... Other things to consider, get pre-approval from your insurance company before starting Zytiga, it's very expensive.. At some point Dad should have some scans (MRI, bone scan) to check if the cancer has spread and if so, how badly...His treatment will be based on the results of these scans... How long the Zytiga will be effective varies with every patient..2 to 5 years is a pretty good ball-park estimate.. There is another drug, Xtandi that can be tried if and when the Zytiga fails..

Posts.Title: Advanced Stage (Stage 4) Prostrate Cancer

Posts.Content: First, a little background...In the United States, treating cancer, including Prostate Cancer, is Big Business.. Most aspects of cancer treatment are very profitable for the people delivering the treatment...The drugs used are usually expensive in the extreme....Surgery can easily top $70,000. Radiation treatment, the 40 fraction IMRT / IGRT variety can go $150,000..So it's to be expected that the people (doctors) who provide these treatments all claim that the treatment they are providing is best....The FDA tries to keep a lid on the situation but since all these treatments and drugs have demonstrated that they work and in the case of surgery and radiation they seem to work equally well..So it is left to the patient to separate the wheat from the chaff and choose a treatment protocol that suits their needs best..None of the treatments are without risks, many present major quality of life issues....I have found consulting with my family doctor can be helpful..He has no financial interest in your cancer treatment and he has seen it all when it comes to both positive and negative results of cancer treatment...

Posts.Title: An educated choice for HIFU, Brachy, AS, Divinci, plus many others

Posts.Content: Does your surgeon perform robotic surgery at all or does he limit all his surgeries to the open procedure? This is major abdominal surgery and you are 68 years old.. Also, did the RO you consulted have any working relationship with the Urologist who is treating you? It might be better if they did not know each other.... Even if you must travel, I think I would consult with an expert robotic surgeon who has performed at least 300 prostatectomies using the Da Vinci surgical robot..I must add, the outcomes produced by open or robotic surgery are the same, all things being equal...Robotic surgeries advantage is it's shorter recovery time..

Posts.Title: Just Received My Treatment Options

Posts.Content: Yes, the next step in your treatment is called hormone therapy..Since there are major quality of life issues associated with this treatment, your doctors may wish to wait as long as possible before starting it..They don't inject you with hormones..They inject you with Lupron or a similar drug which stops the production of testosterone in your body. Most forms of PC require testosterone to grow and spread..Unfortunately, this treatment does not work forever..The length of time it's effective is different in every case so it's very hard to predict but for the majority of cases, the time period is 2 to 5 years. When you get your second opinions, one of the specialists you talk to should be a medical oncologist who is up to date on treating prostate patients..This is no longer a Urology issue.....Best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: PSA vs Gleason vs DRE question

Posts.Content: At least 300..Surgery is pretty aggressive treatment for G-6 PC....How many of your cores were positive? What percentage of the positive cores was cancer? If you don't have a copy of the biopsy pathology report, ask for one and study it carefully.. With surgery, the surgeons skill is all important..The best surgeons achieve considerably better results than the mediocre ones...

Posts.Title: VA vs University Medical

Posts.Content: The problem with biopsies, you can't DEPEND on them to have detected ALL the tumors..You still could be harboring a more aggressive tumor that the biopsy needles missed...Prostate Cancer tends to be multi-focal..When complete organs are biopsied after surgery, the average number of tumors found is 7...If they are all Gleason 6, no problem...But if one turns out to be Gleason 8, then you will be glad you had the surgery..With your family history, your age, surgery may indeed be your best bet. To get an unbiased view of ALL your treatment options, pick up a copy of Dr. Gerald Chodaks book "Winning the battle against prostate cancer"...It's up to date and he focuses on treatment and he sticks to the FACTS....

Posts.Content: I would not get too excited about that...An MRI does not define soft tissue abnormalities very well.. 9mm is the size of a large pea..More testing may be needed to confirm the "mass" is cancer..If it is, Cyro (freezing) might be a good option as might HiFu but you will have to travel outside the States for that and pay out of pocket..I would let your medical team hash it over and see what they come up with..

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Summary, Next Steps ?

Posts.Content: I was lucky in that regard..I was "dry" from the moment they took the catheter out...Yes, walk as much as you are comfortable with..The anesthesia left me with zero appetite, I could not eat for 3 or 4 days, so the constipation became a real problem..I talked like Donald Duck for a few days, the breathing tube they inserted irritated my vocal cords..But by 2 weeks out all that was just a fading memory..I developed more serious problems..A hospital acquired staph infection that put me back in the hospital for a week...Rare, but it happens..

Posts.Content: Is Dad being treated in the United States ? At the moment, the HT is being used as an adjunct to the RT. They will take him off it before he becomes resistant to it..Recent studies have shown that Chemo done right after the RT can be very effective. At this point, a CURE is still not out of the question...

Posts.Title: How painful is catheter removal?

Posts.Content: I was lucky in that regard..I was "dry" from the moment they took the catheter out...Yes, walk as much as you are comfortable with..The anesthesia left me with zero appetite, I could not eat for 3 or 4 days, so the constipation became a real problem..I talked like Donald Duck for a few days, the breathing tube they inserted irritated my vocal cords..But by 2 weeks out all that was just a fading memory..I developed more serious problems..A hospital acquired staph infection that put me back in the hospital for a week...Rare, but it happens..

Posts.Title: and its done! I'm post-op

Posts.Content: If the doctor that is treating him is a Urologist, it's time to consult with a Medical Oncologist...Also, there is such a thing as PSA Bounce, a temporary spike in PSA that can occur after radiation treatment. A visit with his Radiation Oncologist might be in order to see if that's a possibility..The "shot" he was given was probably Lupron or a Lupron type drug that amounts to chemical castration. There will be side-effects from that... Mortality prognosis is difficult to predict until metastasis to the bones is confirmed..Then that 5 year average is correct. At tens years, 90% have died..But these figures are before all the new treatments available today..Provenge is just one of them.. How prostate cancer behaves can be very hard to predict..Some men respond well to treatment and live a long time. Others do not respond so well and their prognosis is not as good.....If you and your dad have not yet read Dr. Walsh's book, now would be a good time to do so..It will answer many of your questions...See Dr. Walsh at the top of the forum page... Best of luck to your Dad....

Posts.Title: Any recommendations on prostate surgeons

Posts.Content: RO's get paid for each treatment they perform. As you could expect, they prefer 38 - 40 fractions from a purely reimbursement standpoint..A big reduction in treatments means a big pay-cut for them so you can expect some heavy push-back from that group..Insurance companies of course will be pushing for fewer treatments..

Posts.Title: Hypofractionated Rsdiation for Prostate Cancer Study

Posts.Content: The "standard" biopsy is guided by an ultrasound probe. they take 12 cores and if you have cancer they find it 90% of the time...The MRI guided procedure is usually done in a hospital or large and well-equipped clinic because MRI machines are large and very expensive..Be sure to get pre-approval from your insurance company as they may refuse to pay for it, claiming it's not medically justified..There may be another method where you get a MRI of your prostate, then your Urologist uses this image along with his live ultrasound image to zero in on any suspicious areas the MRI may have revealed..

Posts.Title: Biopsy questions???

Posts.Content: I hope Alex can find his thread in this forum...Welcome to our club Alex..before you make a treatment decision, there are two books on the subject you should read..Dr. Walsh's book mentioned above in a sticky thread, and Dr. Gerald Chodaks "Winning the battle against prostate cancer" which focuses on treatment options in an unbiased way...The doctors you will talk to will all try to promote the treatment they are familiar with or specialize in themselves...YOU will have to sort the wheat from the chaff. The two books I mentioned will help you make your treatment decision..And of course there is a wealth of information stored in this forum, the good, the bad and the ugly, it's all here....You should know your G-7, PSA 4.8 cancer has a very high cure rate no matter what treatment path you choose...It's the skill of your doctors not the treatment method that determines success or failure on this journey....Do your homework, make your decision and don't look back....

Posts.Title: New to this, Recently diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Hey, welcome to the club nobody wants to join..The high PSA number is somewhat troubling and 4+3 equals 7 is not the best either so I would make his treatment as aggressive as possible...Aggressive treatment will lead to some heavy quality of life issues, this will not be a walk in the park...I hope one of the books you are reading is Dr. Walsh's...Learn how to use the Partin Tables to come up with some very accurate prognostications..Yes, you can beat this but there will be a price to pay..

Posts.Title: Did I make the right choice.

Posts.Content: If the doctor that is treating him is a Urologist, it's time to consult with a Medical Oncologist...Also, there is such a thing as PSA Bounce, a temporary spike in PSA that can occur after radiation treatment. A visit with his Radiation Oncologist might be in order to see if that's a possibility..The "shot" he was given was probably Lupron or a Lupron type drug that amounts to chemical castration. There will be side-effects from that... Mortality prognosis is difficult to predict until metastasis to the bones is confirmed..Then that 5 year average is correct. At tens years, 90% have died..But these figures are before all the new treatments available today..Provenge is just one of them.. How prostate cancer behaves can be very hard to predict..Some men respond well to treatment and live a long time. Others do not respond so well and their prognosis is not as good.....If you and your dad have not yet read Dr. Walsh's book, now would be a good time to do so..It will answer many of your questions...See Dr. Walsh at the top of the forum page... Best of luck to your Dad....

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with cancer

Posts.Content: Hello Kay...With any luck, the hormone treatment will put him in complete remission, his PSA dropping to a very low number. A drug called bicalutimide can sometimes help to achieve this..This treatment is usually effective for 3 to 5 years before he becomes hormone refractory, the lack of testosterone stops working, and other drugs can be used to further extend his life..A new study has shown the Docetaxel chemo, started early, can extend patients lives longer than otherwise expected...However, the side-effects from this treatment can degrade quality of life to the point the benefit obtained is not worth the suffering caused by the drug..Some men tolerate it better than others..His Indian Oncologist seems to be offering state of the art treatment, all things considered..

Posts.Title: New Member LOST SCARED

Posts.Content: His PSA doubling time is a good thermometer to predict his mortality...You should keep monitoring his PSA...Rejecting the Xtandi might have been a mistake, it has very low side-effects and can be very effective..If it's ridiculous cost is a factor, there are programs and pathways to eliminate the medical bills..Look into Medicare "Extra Help" which will stop all the medical co-pays. Do you own your home ? Make sure all your property (houses and cars) are held in "joint tenancy" so you don't have to screw around with probate. Make sure his will is in order while he can still do something about it..

Posts.Title: Good News For All You CRPC guys....

Posts.Content: Robotic and open surgery have the same outcomes, the advantage of robotic is the patient has a quicker recovery and seldom needs a transfusion during surgery..The open method is usually performed in about half the time required for the robotic procedure so time under anesthesia is considerably less..What is important is the SKILL and experience of the surgeon, not the method he uses....

Posts.Title: I'm 3+4=7 Gleason score

Posts.Content: I hope Alex can find his thread in this forum...Welcome to our club Alex..before you make a treatment decision, there are two books on the subject you should read..Dr. Walsh's book mentioned above in a sticky thread, and Dr. Gerald Chodaks "Winning the battle against prostate cancer" which focuses on treatment options in an unbiased way...The doctors you will talk to will all try to promote the treatment they are familiar with or specialize in themselves...YOU will have to sort the wheat from the chaff. The two books I mentioned will help you make your treatment decision..And of course there is a wealth of information stored in this forum, the good, the bad and the ugly, it's all here....You should know your G-7, PSA 4.8 cancer has a very high cure rate no matter what treatment path you choose...It's the skill of your doctors not the treatment method that determines success or failure on this journey....Do your homework, make your decision and don't look back....
