Posts.Title: New to this, Recently diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: For me, walking was the best therapy after surgery...Yeah, walking with the catheter and leg bag is a pain but it's worth the effort to do it..The more I walked, the better I felt...The foot pain should subside the more he walks on them...The testicle swelling is normal, they have lost the reservoir for the fluid (sperm) they produce. Same thing happens with a Vasectomy.. Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Post radical laparoscopic prostatectomy concerns

Posts.Content: Your radiation treatment will cover a fairly wide area..IMRT administered by a modern LINAC like a Rapid-Arc is better at this than is proton which works better when the target is smaller. Spreading out the proton beam to cover a wider area is tricky business and in the past has resulted in serious problems with unwanted neutron production..

Posts.Title: Adjuvant therapy prostatectomy  proton beam vs IMRT?

Posts.Content: Dr Walsh's book, mentioned in the sticky threads, covers advanced disease in the last few chapters..It's comprehensive and worth reading..Usually, the hormone treatment or ADT will control the cancer for two or three years, giving you time to investigate the new drugs and treatments just coming into use, some of which are very effective..Clinical trials give you a shot at the very latest treatments..You may have to travel to one of the big cancer research centers to take advantage of these...If your husband is still being treated by a urologist, it's time to consult with a Medical Oncologist, preferably one who specializes in prostate cancer..Have his testosterone level checked also when they do the next PSA test. Sometimes the drugs don't work as advertized. It's important the "T" level is reduced to castrate level..You might ask about the "triple blockade", a combination of 3 hormonal drugs, which deprive the cancer of what it needs from three different directions.. Best of luck to both you and your husband..

Posts.Title: Anyone on Firmagon?

Posts.Content: Hello... Sorry you are here...When your Dad was diagnosed, did they do a biopsy of his prostate gland ? If so, there would be a Gleason score which can be important in selecting treatment and predicting the future..At 65, he should be on Medicare and it sounds like he can get the "Extra Help" option which eliminates most if not all the co-pays....So the financial side should not be that big a problem... As for treatment, most men get a big response to ADT (Lupron) and that scary PSA number will hopefully collapse to almost nothing..The ADT by itself usually produces a 2 -3 year remission. Yes, the ADT has some unpleasant side-effects but not as bad as the alternative. Starting chemo sooner rather than later has also proved to be effective.. If your dad is still being treated by a Urologist, it's time to visit with a Medical Oncologist. Their training and knowledge is focused on treating cancer which is what you need right now... With PC, every case is different, every case responds differently to treatment so making predictions about mortality is impossible..But rest assured, most of us, even the stage 4, Gleason 9 guys can and do survive for many years. Everyday, new, advanced drugs and treatments are coming online. Many of us live to die from something other than Prostate Cancer..

Posts.Title: recently diagnosed, stage 4 spread to bones and lymphs, psa of 1053.6...

Posts.Content: With those biopsy results, my personal opinion is that a second opinion on the slides is a waste of time and money..Gleason 8 is Gleason 8 and if your local lab can't read THAT correctly they should be shut down....The second opinion becomes more important when all they find is a small sample of Gleason 6 in one or two samples.. Then, there might be a question and it's important to get it right..Getting an opinion from MD Anderson is smart. Do it. If they agree surgery is the best choice, you will have the option of robotic surgery performed by one of the best robotic surgeons in the world...Not that there is anything wrong with open surgery, some claim it delivers a better cure rate, (not proven) it certainly requires a longer recovery. You husband has aggressive, high-risk cancer. So aggressive treatment is called for. The most aggressive treatment. It may very well be that the surgery will be followed by radiation treatment combined with hormone treatment..So be it. You do what you must do to beat this thing and YES, you CAN beat it ! Best of luck to you both and read Dr. Walsh's book....

Posts.Title: Good News For All You CRPC guys....

Posts.Content: For me, walking was the best therapy after surgery...Yeah, walking with the catheter and leg bag is a pain but it's worth the effort to do it..The more I walked, the better I felt...The foot pain should subside the more he walks on them...The testicle swelling is normal, they have lost the reservoir for the fluid (sperm) they produce. Same thing happens with a Vasectomy.. Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Viagra insurance issues?

Posts.Content: In many countries, orchiectomy (surgical castration) is still practiced as a low cost and effective form of hormone therapy..It usually is effective for at least 2 years..The next line of defense would be Chemotherapy if that is available to you. Much depends on your Dad's age and overall condition.. WebMD is pretty close with it's mortality estimate. But every case is different so it's hard to predict..You can chart his PSA doubling time and get a pretty good idea of how quickly the cancer is spreading....

Posts.Title: Increasing PSA after surgery and hormone theraphy

Posts.Content: Surgery, once called the "Gold Standard" has not changed much in 10 or 15 years..Radiation treatment on the other hand has been making great strides in how it is performed, the equipment that is used and the techniques involved..It's ability to produce a cure is much improved over what it was just a few years ago... As for your second opinion, I would consult a Medical Oncologist referred by your primary care doctor, not your Urologist. Then have that MO recommend an radiation oncologist to consult with. Most of the books dealing with prostate cancer, including Dr. Walsh's have become obsolete over the past few years, that's how fast things are changing..Much of the information you will find that's written about PC is aimed at the 65% who are diagnosed as being Gleason 6. But you are a Gleason 8 which puts you in a completely different category. The treatment recommended for you will be much more aggressive than those with G-6 and G-7 prostate cancer...The latest thinking seems to be that radiation, especially the combination of Brachytherapy and beam radiation is more effective at curing high-risk prostate cancer than surgery is...So do your homework and don't be rushed into making a treatment decision..

Posts.Title: The results are in

Posts.Content: After castration, there would be no need for Casodex or any other HT drug.. That's one of it's benefits..Casodex is low cost but it is not the most effective form of hormone treatment. If the pain is being caused by bone mets (metastasis to the bones, common with PC) this can sometimes be treated effectively with spot radiation treatment..If that is not an option, then opiate pain killers can at least control the pain so he is comfortable.. How old is Dad? There are two food supplements that have been shown to slow down progression of prostate cancer. Pomegranate juice or extract and something called IP-6..These don't offer dramatic improvements but it's better than nothing... Best of luck to you and your Dad, we are all here to help you....
Posts.Title: Increasing PSA after surgery and hormone theraphy

Posts.Content: Dr Walsh's book, mentioned in the sticky threads, covers advanced disease in the last few chapters..It's comprehensive and worth reading..Usually, the hormone treatment or ADT will control the cancer for two or three years, giving you time to investigate the new drugs and treatments just coming into use, some of which are very effective..Clinical trials give you a shot at the very latest treatments..You may have to travel to one of the big cancer research centers to take advantage of these...If your husband is still being treated by a urologist, it's time to consult with a Medical Oncologist, preferably one who specializes in prostate cancer..Have his testosterone level checked also when they do the next PSA test. Sometimes the drugs don't work as advertized. It's important the "T" level is reduced to castrate level..You might ask about the "triple blockade", a combination of 3 hormonal drugs, which deprive the cancer of what it needs from three different directions.. Best of luck to both you and your husband..

Posts.Title: The Use of Biomarkers in Prostate Cancer Screening and Treatment

Posts.Content: To answer your question, yes...These tests and procedures are expensive (your insurance may balk) but since a biopsy does not sample the entire gland, you can't be sure there is no higher grade cancer lurking...These tests are a useful tool in spotting more aggressive cancer missed by the biopsy...Also, get a second opinion on the biopsy slides. There are two expert labs that specialize in analyzing prostate biopsy slides. Sometimes they find things journeymen pathologists miss...

Posts.Title: Color-Doppler Ultrasound and/or Advanced Prostate 3 Tesla MRI

Posts.Content: There are several choices of drugs that achieve the same end..You should find out if the side-effects are from the drug itself or are they the normal result of reducing your testosterone to castrate levels? Chemical castration produces all kinds of side-effects. Hot flashes, fatigue, mood swings, body hair loss, impotence and not caring about it, loss of bone and muscle mass, breast development... Three years?? Many radiation oncologists have backed off to 16 months-2 years without backsliding on the cure rate improvement. After 3 years on HT, the effects tend to become permanent..

Posts.Title: New member looking for help in analysing my PSA results

Posts.Content: You might wish to read "Guide To Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Patrick Walsh. it will answer all your questions. You have Gleason 7 which is moderately aggressive and it looks like you have caught it very early which gives you an excellent chance of being cured..You don't have to rush into anything, you have plenty of time to study all your options and choose a treatment plan that is right for you...They all have their advantages and disadvantages and the doctors will promote whatever treatment they specialize in..

Posts.Title: biopsy result yesterday ... I have prostate cancer at 40 years old. Need advices

Posts.Content: Surgery, once called the "Gold Standard" has not changed much in 10 or 15 years..Radiation treatment on the other hand has been making great strides in how it is performed, the equipment that is used and the techniques involved..It's ability to produce a cure is much improved over what it was just a few years ago... As for your second opinion, I would consult a Medical Oncologist referred by your primary care doctor, not your Urologist. Then have that MO recommend an radiation oncologist to consult with. Most of the books dealing with prostate cancer, including Dr. Walsh's have become obsolete over the past few years, that's how fast things are changing..Much of the information you will find that's written about PC is aimed at the 65% who are diagnosed as being Gleason 6. But you are a Gleason 8 which puts you in a completely different category. The treatment recommended for you will be much more aggressive than those with G-6 and G-7 prostate cancer...The latest thinking seems to be that radiation, especially the combination of Brachytherapy and beam radiation is more effective at curing high-risk prostate cancer than surgery is...So do your homework and don't be rushed into making a treatment decision..

Posts.Title: Questions about Traveling for Treatment and Getting Local Care

Posts.Content: " Our uro here does have about 400 deVinci's, but most all when he was in training." You go to a big teaching hospital like J-H or MDA or Mayo and you don't REALLY know WHO is going to perform you surgery. The big name doctor you talked to might be in the room with his student closely watching and directing him but the guy actually operating the robot might be a complete newbee....Everybody tells you be sure your surgeon has at least 300 procedures..Some say 400..One guy here says 1000 is needed..But how do these surgeons build up their numbers count ?? Many, many men get successfully operated on by surgeons with far fewer than 300 robotic surgeries under their belt..So be sure to verify exactly WHO will be in the daVinci robot's drivers seat....The Master or his Student..

Posts.Title: Pet ct type for mets Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Have you had one of the newer bone scans (think F-1 to check and see if there are any bone mets? If they are doing radiation, I suspect you have had such a scan and it was clear....As the other guys have said, it IS possible to cure G-9 & G-10 prostate cancer but the odds are not as good as the G-6 and G-7 guys.....We can make more accurate comments if you posted your complete biopsy report and PSA at diagnosis...Even if the radiation fails to deliver a cure, there are treatments today for advanced PC that can keep you going for many years...Best of luck to you....

Posts.Title: Gleason 10

Posts.Content: How old are you Jack...? Yes indeed, that's a nasty report....Your 3 month PSA test will be important in planning future treatment.. Nothing to do now but wait, get healed up, and study up on all your options. The Urologists job is pretty much done. It's time to visit with a Medical Oncologist and get his viewpoints on how to proceed...have your PCP refer you to one, not your urologist. Try to find an MO who specializes in PC or at least find one who treats a lot of PC patients..Next step may be a couple of scans to see if your cancer has spread anywhere else..Todays scanning technology has made huge advances, makes deciding on a treatment path much easier and more productive... Best of luck to you....

Posts.Title: The Use of Biomarkers in Prostate Cancer Screening and Treatment

Posts.Content: The BAT study going on at Johns-Hopkins is a possible breakthrough in advanced prostate treatment...It only works in men that have become hormone refractory, their advanced disease no longer responding to ADT or hormone therapy..But it needs to go through a Stage 3 clinical trial before the FDA will approve it..These trials are very expensive to conduct..Testosterone, a common, off-patent drug available from several generic drug makers at low prices (compared to most patented cancer drugs) offers little profit motive to the drug companies to fund a trial so getting the treatment approved for use will be difficult. Oncologists are very shy about prescribing an "experimental" treatment as it would leave them open to serious legal problems should the results not meet the patients expectations..One would have to travel outside the United States to have this treatment performed...

Posts.Title: How does % of the nerve bundle spared effect the ED outcome?

Posts.Content: Prostate tumors don't grow in "planes"...The higher the percentage in the core, the larger the tumor is likely to be...If the tumor is found to be 100% of the core, then it's likely it has moved outside the prostate envelope...Prostate cancer is multi-focal. The average prostate gland when removed by surgery and its pathology is worked up, contains seven separate and distinct tumors..

Posts.Title: Mismatch Repair Deficiency (dMMR) and Keytruda for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: In many countries, orchiectomy (surgical castration) is still practiced as a low cost and effective form of hormone therapy..It usually is effective for at least 2 years..The next line of defense would be Chemotherapy if that is available to you. Much depends on your Dad's age and overall condition.. WebMD is pretty close with it's mortality estimate. But every case is different so it's hard to predict..You can chart his PSA doubling time and get a pretty good idea of how quickly the cancer is spreading....

Posts.Title: Increasing PSA after surgery and hormone theraphy

Posts.Content: After castration, there would be no need for Casodex or any other HT drug.. That's one of it's benefits..Casodex is low cost but it is not the most effective form of hormone treatment. If the pain is being caused by bone mets (metastasis to the bones, common with PC) this can sometimes be treated effectively with spot radiation treatment..If that is not an option, then opiate pain killers can at least control the pain so he is comfortable.. How old is Dad? There are two food supplements that have been shown to slow down progression of prostate cancer. Pomegranate juice or extract and something called IP-6..These don't offer dramatic improvements but it's better than nothing... Best of luck to you and your Dad, we are all here to help you....

Posts.Title: New member looking for help in analysing my PSA results

Posts.Content: Okay, you have had the scans and your cancer seems confined..That's good news....Chances are, radiation treatment is almost a certainty. Talk with a RO now..They may put you on HT fairly soon to block any spread while you are recovering from the surgery..If radiation is called for, you want to be completely recovered from the surgery before they begin the radiation. Also, the HT will make the RT more effective if RT is called for. But nothing is going to happen until that first PSA test at 3 months comes in....Nothing you can do about it so don't worry about it. Put you mind someplace else and look forward to enjoying the Holiday season....

Posts.Title: Bad news pathology report

Posts.Content: At the 3 year post surgery mark, 50% of patients have some degree of ED...Percent of nerves damaged or removed is an objective figure made up by surgeons trying to reassure patients..Much depends on your potency before the surgery....If you needed a little help from the blue pill before your surgery you are likely to need a LOT of help now......

Posts.Title: New member looking for help in analysing my PSA results

Posts.Content: " Our uro here does have about 400 deVinci's, but most all when he was in training." You go to a big teaching hospital like J-H or MDA or Mayo and you don't REALLY know WHO is going to perform you surgery. The big name doctor you talked to might be in the room with his student closely watching and directing him but the guy actually operating the robot might be a complete newbee....Everybody tells you be sure your surgeon has at least 300 procedures..Some say 400..One guy here says 1000 is needed..But how do these surgeons build up their numbers count ?? Many, many men get successfully operated on by surgeons with far fewer than 300 robotic surgeries under their belt..So be sure to verify exactly WHO will be in the daVinci robot's drivers seat....The Master or his Student..

Posts.Title: Questions about Traveling for Treatment and Getting Local Care

Posts.Content: Radiation will stop the healing process associated with your surgery right where it is..So if you have any urinary or ED issues those problems will be frozen in place by the radiation...I can understand why you wish to proceed with the radiation ASAP but don't overlook the quality of life issues you may be signing up for by undergoing radiation so soon after surgery...

Posts.Title: Throwing the "Kitchen Sink" at Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: You said his PSA has risen....What's the number? At this point, it's time to consider passing on his care to a Medical Oncologist. The Urologist can do little more for him. Perhaps a full body scan using one of the newer scan techniques (F-18 Choline comes to mind) that can spot the location of any metastasis at an early stage and make treatment more focused..But yes, ADT will indeed be the next treatment approach and it can be very effective. Unfortunately, the side-effects can be difficult to manage for some men..The man-boob thing is the least of it..That's two or three years down the road, he can wait on that for awhile..

Posts.Title: 2.5 yrs later - psa rises.

Posts.Content: In the States, depending on circumstances, primary treatment is either surgery, radiation or, in advanced cases, hormone treatment..Then, if surgery or radiation fail, hormone treatment is used to suppress PSA as much as possible. Hormone treatment can take the form of injections, pills or surgical castration.. When HT quits working, either chemo or Provenge are the next things that are tried. Then Xtandi maybe..Zytiga is another drug that sometimes delivers good results..But NONE of these drugs or treatments offer a cure...They just slow down the progression of the cancer for a while..Even in the States, you must have good insurance or be wealthy to afford these advanced drugs.... Many of us being treated for PC take a supplement or two, Pomegranate being the most popular.. By the way, how old are you?

Posts.Title: About xtandi

Posts.Content: Lumps and bumps are not good...In the States, there are a few Urologists that use a more advanced ultrasound probe to examine the prostate and guide biopsy needles..It's called a Color Doppler Ultrasound...In expert hands, it can help the Urologist determine whether a "nodule" is dangerous or not and whether a biopsy is warranted..An even more advanced test called "CTC" stands for circulating tumor cells can find cancer cells, any cancer cells, circulating freely in your blood. Unfortunately, this test is very expensive and has not been approved as a part of routine PC screening....So Urologists still rely on the PSA & DRE to guide them when making biopsy recommendations..Best of luck to you..

Posts.Title: Nodule with Low PSA

Posts.Content: I'm 73 and on ADT..Are you seeing a Medical Oncologist? He should be directing the hormone treatment, not your urologist..The surgical procedure is probably the best if you can deal with it..It's the cheapest and most effective.. Yes, ADT increases heart attack risk but so what? The increased risk is manageable..You must be careful to avoid weight gain.. It's hard to predict how effective ADT will be for you. Everyone responds a little differently. Many men get a nice long remission, 5 years or more..Some men do not..... Now or later, good question...You could wait a few months and get a better idea of your PSA doubling time. This is a gauge of how fast your cancer is growing..If the doubling time is short, then starting treatment is more urgent..A drug called Casodex might be useful to you. G-9 prostate cancer (me too) is a whole different ball game..There are other, newer drugs and treatments for advanced prostate cancer. Provenge, Zytiga, Xtandi are effective but not curative..Insurance generally will not pay for them (they are VERY expensive) until the ADT stops working.. They are hoping you will die before they have to pay for those drugs...One thing that has proven effective, doing Docetaxel (Chemo) now instead of later. Your overall condition may or may not allow doing chemo...the side effects can be rough...Best of luck to you...!

Posts.Title: Nodule with Low PSA

Posts.Content: Prostate cancer can indeed be a "Terminal Illness"....That's just the way it is....25,000 men die from it every year....Nobody can make those numbers go away...How the patient responds to treatment over the next 2 years will in all likelihood determine how his battle will end and to a certain extent, when it will end..Once bone mets are discovered, the AVERAGE life expectancy is 5 years.. That means half the men die sooner and half die later. Except for the rare few, we are pretty much all gone by year 10... I'm sorry I could not be more optimistic, but that's just the way it is......

Posts.Title: New member looking for help in analysing my PSA results

Posts.Content: I would wait until your Radiation Oncologist requests an empty bowel before you start worrying about that...I would also insist that any external beam radiation be administered by a modern LINAC, like a Varian Rapid-Arc or better..The new equipment can direct the beam MUCH more accurately than the older units and a skilled RO can avoid most damage to healthy tissue by making slight adjustments in the beam path..(actually the machine will do this automatically)... But if an empty bowel is prescribed, then you will become adept at giving yourself an enema before every treatment session..This would be unusual...

Posts.Title: Xtandi and Zytiga

Posts.Content: The amount of cancer found might eliminate active surveillance as a treatment option..At 47, surgery, performed by an expert is probably his best option..Diet and supplements never cured anyone of cancer. Those who claim it has never had cancer to begin with...Most prostatectomies today are performed roboticly , (the daVinci surgical robot) and the skill of the surgeon is very important..You have plenty of time to find the best one available in your area.. Radiation treatments including "seeds" work well too but your husband is young and radiations worst side effects tend to happen many years after the treatment has been performed, when your husband can be expected to still be alive..So don't be rushed into anything, investigate all your options, make your decision and don't look back... The author of "Invasion Of The Prostate Snatchers" also wrote "The Book Of Runes"

Posts.Title: New member looking for help in analysing my PSA results

Posts.Content: Looks like your husband has had prostate cancer for a long time but his "doubling time", the time it takes his PSA value to double is very long...While his PSA is high, aggressive treatment is seldom undertaken at his age. They may recommend HT, hormone treatment, which will control the cancer as long as it needs to be controlled. Then again, they just as likely will just let it ride and not subject him to the HT side effects...There are a couple of drugs that may be useful, Avodart and Proscar which carry a minimal side effect load... Best of luck to you both!

Posts.Title: My husband was just diagnosed

Posts.Content: In my OPINION, expert surgeons can be found almost everywhere and I'm sure several can be found in the Chicago area..Your primary care doctor may be able to help (if you have one)...The University Of Chicago Medical Center should be able to take care of you..Traveling can complicate things and in the end the benefit can be hard to determine..Yes, some surgeons are better than others but even the best have bad days...It's up to YOU to do your homework and choose one you trust and can connect with...But traveling all over the country, I'm not sure that's the answer.... Today, robotic surgery is used 90% of the time for radical prostatectomies. But some of the older surgeons still prefer open surgery. The results are the same.... Robotic usually delivers a quicker recovery, but the old pros present a good argument for the open procedure...Again, YOU must make that choice....Nobody guarantees anything.... At some point, your insurance company will have a voice in all this and unless that's not an issue you need to be aware of that...Nobody here is a doctor but we have all been through the mill and our collective knowledge is available to you. Feel free to tap into it and use it...Best of luck to you....

Posts.Title: Radical Questions

Posts.Content: Lumps and bumps are not good...In the States, there are a few Urologists that use a more advanced ultrasound probe to examine the prostate and guide biopsy needles..It's called a Color Doppler Ultrasound...In expert hands, it can help the Urologist determine whether a "nodule" is dangerous or not and whether a biopsy is warranted..An even more advanced test called "CTC" stands for circulating tumor cells can find cancer cells, any cancer cells, circulating freely in your blood. Unfortunately, this test is very expensive and has not been approved as a part of routine PC screening....So Urologists still rely on the PSA & DRE to guide them when making biopsy recommendations..Best of luck to you..

Posts.Title: Nodule with Low PSA

Posts.Content: All you can do is wait and see....It's the HT that is suppressing your PSA now..As long as your PSA stays under 0.2 you can skip any further treatment but 6 months or a year from now, that's when you will get a better picture......Studies have shown that a 2 year treatment of HT significantly improves outcomes but it is true the side-effect load can be severe....You get to make the choice..

Posts.Title: Xtandi and Zytiga

Posts.Content: CIPRO is a broad spectrum antibiotic that can have some severe and nasty side-effects..Most doctors are getting shy about prescribing it, especially for six weeks....Stop trying to second guess your doctors or telling them what to do...
Posts.Title: PSA MRI and Pain

Posts.Content: Your chances of being diagnosed with prostate cancer are maybe 50-50, perhaps less than that..And if you DO have PC, there's a 55% chance it will be graded Gleason 6, which seldom kills anyone especially if it's treated at some point..But until you have that biopsy, it's all guesswork..... The biopsy itself is nothing to fear, takes about 15 minutes, uncomfortable but painless if properly done. Some blood in the urine and semen for a few days afterwards..But now, you know where you stand, there is no guesswork...But from now on, biopsy or no, you need to have your PSA checked every 6 months. Establishing your PSA velocity is an important tool in predicting whether you have PC or not...

Posts.Title: Immunotherapy grabs a BBC headline

Posts.Content: Looks like your husband has had prostate cancer for a long time but his "doubling time", the time it takes his PSA value to double is very long...While his PSA is high, aggressive treatment is seldom undertaken at his age. They may recommend HT, hormone treatment, which will control the cancer as long as it needs to be controlled. Then again, they just as likely will just let it ride and not subject him to the HT side effects...There are a couple of drugs that may be useful, Avodart and Proscar which carry a minimal side effect load... Best of luck to you both!

Posts.Title: PSA of 80

Posts.Content: You said his PSA has risen....What's the number? At this point, it's time to consider passing on his care to a Medical Oncologist. The Urologist can do little more for him. Perhaps a full body scan using one of the newer scan techniques (F-18 Choline comes to mind) that can spot the location of any metastasis at an early stage and make treatment more focused..But yes, ADT will indeed be the next treatment approach and it can be very effective. Unfortunately, the side-effects can be difficult to manage for some men..The man-boob thing is the least of it..That's two or three years down the road, he can wait on that for awhile..

Posts.Title: Well... I suppose I need your advice.

Posts.Content: Looks like your husband has had prostate cancer for a long time but his "doubling time", the time it takes his PSA value to double is very long...While his PSA is high, aggressive treatment is seldom undertaken at his age. They may recommend HT, hormone treatment, which will control the cancer as long as it needs to be controlled. Then again, they just as likely will just let it ride and not subject him to the HT side effects...There are a couple of drugs that may be useful, Avodart and Proscar which carry a minimal side effect load... Best of luck to you both!

Posts.Title: ED drugs

Posts.Content: Your chances of being diagnosed with prostate cancer are maybe 50-50, perhaps less than that..And if you DO have PC, there's a 55% chance it will be graded Gleason 6, which seldom kills anyone especially if it's treated at some point..But until you have that biopsy, it's all guesswork..... The biopsy itself is nothing to fear, takes about 15 minutes, uncomfortable but painless if properly done. Some blood in the urine and semen for a few days afterwards..But now, you know where you stand, there is no guesswork...But from now on, biopsy or no, you need to have your PSA checked every 6 months. Establishing your PSA velocity is an important tool in predicting whether you have PC or not...

Posts.Title: Well... I suppose I need your advice.

Posts.Content: Do one year of Lupron and start the radiation as soon as possible...Then monitor your PSA closely for a few years. High-tech scans take a lot of time and money but they don't do anything to treat your cancer. From your numbers, it's safe to assume there are still a few cancer cells in your body. They are all probably in your pelvic region. Get after them. Just my humble opinion...

Posts.Title: When to go to Sand lake?

Posts.Content: As Highlander said, the 12 core trus biopsy often misses cancer that is present. There are parts of the prostate that can not be reached with the TRUS method. Having the high-grade PIN is often a sign of developing prostate cancer..A second biopsy is called for. You might ask about a saturation biopsy, performed differently in a hospital setting that will detect PC with 99% certainty if it exists.....

Posts.Title: Disappointing 2nd opinion

Posts.Content: After the Orchidectomy, there is probably no need for the Casodex (bicalutimide) There is no longer any testosterone to block and Casodex has a long side-effect list....And yes, the latest trials have shown that doing Docetaxel early (as long as Dad can tolerate it) seems to work better than using it later on....Within a month he should see a dramatic drop in his PSA and his cancer-caused symptoms..

Posts.Title: Disappointing 2nd opinion

Posts.Content: Pick up a copy of Dr Pat Walsh's book "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" Your library will have a copy so will amazon or ebay.. The "hormone treatment" is actually chemical castration and will reduce his testosterone to near zero. This, hopefully, will starve the cancer of what it needs to grow...(testosterone) For a period of time it is usually very effective...There are other secondary drugs and treatments that can extend his survival considerably, depending on just how hard he wants to fight...

Posts.Title: Death rate while undergoing the robatic assisted prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Australia's medical service industry works a little differently than in the States..Hormone Therapy can deliver a remission lasting several years..The identified bone mets can be treated with radiation to eliminate the pain...Once the cancer is under control, there are several advanced treatments and drugs that can extend survival out 10 years or more...You will have to do your research to see what is available to patients in Australia... None of these treatments and drugs are without side-effects..The Hormone therapy will come with some major ones..It all comes down to just how hard your Dad wants to fight....

Posts.Title: My dad has stage 4 prostate cancer :(

Posts.Content: While you are waiting for your next appointment, pick up a copy of Dr. Pat Walsh's book "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" and read it...At least learn what you might be dealing with...About 60% of the prostate cancer diagnosed is the low-grade Gleason 6 variety which seldom if ever proves to be fatal even if left untreated...That leaves 40% that tends to be aggressive and life-threatening if left untreated. If you are terrified by the thought of having a biopsy, see if you can arrange having a T-3 MRI scan of your prostate. This scan will reveal far more than the DRE and can be used to guide any future biopsy to sample suspicious areas...If you wait until your PSA breaks out above 10, your treatment options become far fewer and the outcomes of any treatment become less certain...

Posts.Title: New Memeber - First Post What to do, what to do????

Posts.Content: Good morning John...In your case, it might be worth traveling to consult with one of the hundred and fifty Medical Oncologists that SPECIALIZE in treating Prostate Cancer..Perhaps getting the COMBINED treatment of Xtandi & Provenge which has produced dramatic, long-lasting results..."Invasion of the prostate snatchers" a somewhat worthless book (for us) by Ralph Blum contains an appendix that lists those 150 prostate cancer specialists by name and phone number.. At this point, we are free to try anything so don't be afraid to think outside the box...There are guys who have kept this monster in check for ten years or more...Best of luck to you....

They may recommend HT, hormone treatment, which will control the cancer as long as it needs to be controlled. Then again, they just as likely will just let it ride and not subject him to the HT side effects...There are a couple of drugs that may be useful, Avodart and Proscar which carry a minimal side effect load... Best of luck to you both!

Posts.Title: PSA of 80

Posts.Content: MRI's are not 100% useful in detecting prostate cancer...30% of the time they miss it....The "saturation biopsy", done differently (you will be sedated), seldom misses any cancer tumors in your prostate..It's probably 98-99% effective in detecting PC...

Posts.Title: Death rate while undergoing the robatic assisted prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: A good book to read to get a PC overview is "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" by Pat Walsh... But to answer your question, there a few strains (variants) of PC that produce very little PSA...Usually, these are aggressive cancers..Since yours came back Gleason 6, a non-aggressive stage, I would get several opinions about what is going on..Leave no stone unturned.. How old are you? Age plays an important part in making treatment decisions...Your cancer may have been detected at the very beginning, before it is large enough to produce much PSA.. Many men with low-grade PC require no treatment at all, the cancer never progresses to a life-threatening stage..Again, age plays an important role...Take your time in researching this...

Posts.Title: Low psa but yes, I have prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Have your testosterone level checked..Not all men get the desired response from the Lupron..Your "T" level should be less than 20 and ideally less than 10..If it's not, perhaps going back on the Casodex would be of benefit.. Your primary care doctor can perform these tests for you..Surgery is not usually recommended in advanced cases, it can't cure you if the horse has left the barn..But it CAN remove 98% or more of the cancer and that leaves just 2% (or whatever) to deal with and not 100%..Radiation might be a better choice as they can focus the beam on a wider area..Lots of things happen back stage, between the doctors and the insurance companies..(radiation costs about 4 times as much as surgery) In this business, nothing happens until it's decided who is going to pay for it..

Posts.Content: Surgery changes the whole male plumbing system..Ejaculating urine is common...When contemplating sex most guys empty their bladder FIRST which greatly reduces the amount of urine involved..

Posts.Title: Friend could use some advice.

Posts.Content: While you are waiting for your next appointment, pick up a copy of Dr. Pat Walsh's book "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" and read it...At least learn what you might be dealing with...About 60% of the prostate cancer diagnosed is the low-grade Gleason 6 variety which seldom if ever proves to be fatal even if left untreated...That leaves 40% that tends to be aggressive and life-threatening if left untreated. If you are terrified by the thought of having a biopsy, see if you can arrange having a T-3 MRI scan of your prostate. This scan will reveal far more than the DRE and can be used to guide any future biopsy to sample suspicious areas...If you wait until your PSA breaks out above 10, your treatment options become far fewer and the outcomes of any treatment become less certain...

Posts.Title: New Memeber - First Post What to do, what to do????

Posts.Content: Since HT comes with a huge side-effect load and it's expensive, there is every reason to minimize it's use. So the only argument is is it effective when used as an adjunct to SRT? Just exactly how much benefit does the patient receive? Seems like you can find studies to support either side of the argument....It's safe to say the jury is still out....

Posts.Title: PSA of 80

Posts.Content: PC still needs to verified..There ARE cases (not many but they exist) where men have had PSA readings in the hundreds or even thousands but they do not have PC! If he does have PC, the results of the biopsy can be used to plan his most effective course of treatment...With today's medicine, even advanced cases can expect long survival times.....

Posts.Title: Only just found out suspected prostate cancer. Very high PSA. How bad is it??

Posts.Content: Thanks guys...The hardest thing about this, I have no symptoms caused by my cancer...I mean life is good, I have managed to deal with the side-effects associated with hormone treatment but other than that, I feel great..But I can now hear the clock ticking, that PSA number being the timekeeper..When you are in the zero club, a status I enjoyed for 2 years, it's easy to think you are going to live forever like we all do..But now that clock is ticking again and I'm going to need a new sword to fight this dragon..I'm aware that the armory is well-stocked with new weapons and the blacksmiths are forging new ones every day..This is a game we play one hand at a time and I still have a few trump cards left....I have a young, smart, aggressive oncologist and we are going to give that dragon a run for his money..

Posts.Title: Xtandi, Zytiga, Radium-223, Provenge Success Stories?

Posts.Content: Sailor, here is a line from a Jimmy Buffet tune..."I'd rather die while I'm living than live when I'm dead".. I'm going to stay in the game and play a few more hands and see how it goes...When you run out of trump cards you can head for the exit....There are guys who have kept this monster in check for 10 years or more, others are not so lucky...But you will never find out unless you try.... Newport, that was very interesting about the Xtandi + Provenge combination treatment resulting in complete remission. We should be doing a lot more of this...
Posts.Title: Xtandi, Zytiga, Radium-223, Provenge Success Stories?

Posts.Content: Hello everyone.. As my cancer enters a new and unwelcome phase, I was wondering if others have had any noteworthy success (as in a prolonged remission) when being treated with any of the new drugs and treatments..Seems to me, the cost and side-effects suffered seldom justified the marginal improvements realized..I'm just trying find out if anyone has enjoyed a worthwhile improvement after being treated with these new drugs..

Posts.Title: Xtandi, Zytiga, Radium-223, Provenge Success Stories?

Posts.Content: Before anyone here can help you very much, we need more information...What was his PSA when he was diagnosed? After his biopsy, he was given a Gleason score. What was that? Is the hormone treatment (Firmagon) going to be his primary treatment or will he have radiation treatment also. What country do you live in? Hormone treatment has some pretty serious side-effects (it's chemical castration after all) and they will develop slowly usually starting with hot-flashes, weight gain, loss of most body hair, loss of muscle mass, loss of libido, impotence...

Posts.Content: "My husband is dealing with this by literally saying 'I don't want to know'! " When it comes to treating PC, ignorance is NOT bliss...Be aware the treating of cancer, any cancer, is BIG business. The treatment providers will compete for your business..The "I don't want to know" attitude will turn your husband into an ATM machine for these treatment providers..At least insist he reads Dr. Walsh's book...

Posts.Title: New Memeber - First Post What to do, what to do????

Posts.Content: Have your testosterone level checked..Not all men get the desired response from the Lupron..Your "T" level should be less than 20 and ideally less than 10..If it's not, perhaps going back on the Casodex would be of benefit.. Your primary care doctor can perform these tests for you..Surgery is not usually recommended in advanced cases, it can't cure you if the horse has left the barn..But it CAN remove 98% or more of the cancer and that leaves just 2% (or whatever) to deal with and not 100%..Radiation might be a better choice as they can focus the beam on a wider area..Lots of things happen back stage, between the doctors and the insurance companies..(radiation costs about 4 times as much as surgery) In this business, nothing happens until it's decided who is going to pay for it..

Posts.Title: Decimal point in PSA level

Posts.Content: For an informed answer, we need more information...His age, PSA before surgery, the results of the post surgery pathology report, (Gleason score, positive margins?) These are the things that will determine the need for salvage or adjunct radiation.. But generally, you want his recovery from the surgery to be complete before radiation is begun. You want to see his PSA at 8-12 weeks post surgery..Any ED or incontinence problems will be locked into place by the radiation, no more improvement after that... Also, it is becoming standard to include HT, hormone therapy for at least a year, more often 2 years, before, during and after radiation as it has been shown to make the radiation more effective..He can start that anytime, the sooner the better. of course, that will lock in the ED for as long as he is on it... The doctors can recommend and offer treatments but YOU decide which ones you wish to pursue..Always get a second opinion before you commit to treatments that come with serious side-effects. One of the doctors you talk to should be a Medical Oncologist, not a Urologist or Radiation Oncologist..These people all have different viewpoints and sometimes they conflict. Only YOU can decide what's best for YOU....Best of luck on this sometimes rough journey... Okay, I checked back and see he is 51 and a G-7..That being the case, if it were me, I would wait until the next PSA test at 8-12 weeks. If it's UNDETECTABLE, that's the goal of surgery, then there is no rush to begin the radiation...Unless of course the post-op pathology report was really ugly..

Posts.Content: Thanks guys...The hardest thing about this, I have no symptoms caused by my cancer...I mean life is good, I have managed to deal with the side-effects associated with hormone treatment but other than that, I feel great..But I can now hear the clock ticking, that PSA number being the timekeeper..When you are in the zero club, a status I enjoyed for 2 years, it's easy to think you are going to live forever like we all do..But now that clock is ticking again and I'm going to need a new sword to fight this dragon..I'm aware that the armory is well-stocked with new weapons and the blacksmiths are forging new ones every day..This is a game we play one hand at a time and I still have a few trump cards left....I have a young, smart, aggressive oncologist and we are going to give that dragon a run for his money..

Posts.Title: Xtandi, Zytiga, Radium-223, Provenge Success Stories?

Posts.Content: Any lifting or exercises that mimic lifting will be banned for at least 4 months..After that, the amount of lifting you are allowed will be slowly increased. At the one year point, normal physical activity is usually permitted..Be SURE to ask your surgeon about ANY exercise plans you may have and get his okay. While the daVinci surgery leaves little external evidence, there is some major internal slicing and dicing involved and it's possible to pull a hernia with little effort..Walking is fine, but check with your doc about the upper-body stuff....

Posts.Content: Perhaps the R.O. can offer an equal chance at controlling the cancer while minimizing the side effects...It sounds like the surgical solution will not guarantee a cure but will produce onerous side-effects, an external 'bladder" strapped to your husbands leg...Has anyone mentioned starting HT (hormone treatment) NOW to control and possibly shrink the cancer? But you are correct, few people are familiar with this rare form of prostate cancer...It might be worth seeking out one of the few specialists who ARE familiar with it.. I would contact one of the big cancer research centers (John Hopkins, MDA) to find the expertise you need...

Posts.Title: Ductal prostate cancer

Posts.Content: It is almost CERTAIN he will need both radiation and HT after the surgery. Gleason 9, 5+4 and a PSA of 80 virtually guarantees it..The surgery MAY improve his odds by removing most of the cancer, reducing the work the radiation and HT will have to do, but the side-effects of the surgery are probably not worth any gain it will provide...He should read Dr. Walsh's book, there's a sticky thread at the top of this forum, to get some insights of exactly what he is dealing with..And since he will be needing the services of a radiation oncologist at some point, he might as well talk to one now..These two specialists, surgeons and radiation oncologists seldom see eye to eye and they are in fact competitors for your business.. Age 57..There may be insurance issues..Be sure the service providers get pre-approval BEFORE any procedures are performed to avoid any nasty surprises.. My signature is written in shorthand, they limit the space you have, but you can see I'm a G-9, had surgery, it failed, then radiation combined with hormone therapy. The side-effects were/are significant, but manageable. I'm doing okay at the 2 year mark but like many of us, there are storm clouds on the horizon...

Posts.Title: I got a secong opnion and still confused

Posts.Content: While Urologists play an important role in detecting and treating the early stages of prostate cancer, there are two other specialists you should consult with before you make any treatment decisions..A Radiation Oncologist and a Medical Oncologist both have the specialized training in cancer treatment that urologists lack.. If "ductal prostate cancer" means PC that has spread to the lymph nodes/ducts, that is not unusual and can be treated..While Gleason 8 is considered aggressive, high-risk cancer, a PSA of 8 usually points to a cancer that has not yet metastasized and therefore is treatable..70 is usually considered the cut-off point for surgery so again, talk with a RO who may offer effective treatment without surgery... I found this link, which pretty well sums things up.. http://www.cblpath.com/uploads/Ducta...ate_Cancer.pdf

AgeInfo.Phrase: metastasized and therefore is treatable  70 is usually considered the cut

If "ductal prostate cancer" means PC that has spread to the lymph nodes/ducts, that is not unusual and can be treated..While Gleason 8 is considered aggressive, high-risk cancer, a PSA of 8 usually points to a cancer that has not yet metastasized and therefore is treatable..70 is usually considered the cut-off point for surgery so again, talk with a RO who may offer effective treatment without surgery... I found this link, which pretty well sums things up.. http://www.cblpath.com/uploads/Ducta...ate_Cancer.pdf

AgeInfo.Phrase: metastasized and therefore is treatable  70 is usually considered the cut

Posts.Title: Ductal prostate cancer

Posts.Content: DogDollar is 100% correct....You hit it as hard as you can with everything that's available..See if the Radiation Oncologist can do anything about that one positive node....With PC, individual outcomes are almost impossible to predict...Best of luck to you both....

Posts.Title: Update. Lymph node positive

Posts.Content: A good book to read to get a PC overview is "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" by Pat Walsh... But to answer your question, there a few strains (variants) of PC that produce very little PSA...Usually, these are aggressive cancers..Since yours came back Gleason 6, a non-aggressive stage, I would get several opinions about what is going on..Leave no stone unturned.. How old are you? Age plays an important part in making treatment decisions...Your cancer may have been detected at the very beginning, before it is large enough to produce much PSA.. Many men with low-grade PC require no treatment at all, the cancer never progresses to a life-threatening stage..Again, age plays an important role...Take your time in researching this...

Posts.Title: Low psa but yes, I have prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Like John T mentioned, that "abnormal" hard spot needs to be explained..An imaging technique called "Color Doppler Ultrasound" in the hands of an expert can reveal much needed information.. Also, some doctors are much better at performing DRE's than others..At some point you can expect your insurance company to get involved with this...They will start imposing limits.. If, in the end, there is still a lot of confusion, you can ask for a "saturation biopsy" which takes 40 samples and gives a much more detailed picture of what is going on..This is done under general anesthesia...

Posts.Title: Low psa but yes, I have prostate cancer

Posts.Content: You should both read Dr. Pat Walsh's book, "Guide to surviving Prostate cancer, third edition" The chances of the 3+4=7 and 4+3=7 Gleason scores being inaccurate are pretty slim..Any competent Pathologist can spot and identify grade 4 prostate cancer..And it's the grade 4 component that you need to worry about... The success of the surgery depends largely on the skill of the surgeon, it's as simple as that. Your surgeon should have done AT LEAST 300 robotic prostate removals to be considered an expert....Side-effect results can vary widely..Incontinence occurs about 20% of time..And some degree of impotence occurs 50% of the time, nerve-sparing procedure or not....Again, the skill of the surgeon is all-important...Usually, both the incontinence and the impotence can be treated successfully. Radiation treatment (there are several forms) offers good results and fewer immediate side-effects..But in a 39 year old man who can be expected to live another 40 years or more, the long-term side-effects of heavy-dose radiation treatment can weigh heavy on your treatment decision... Don't rush into ANY treatment until you understand all the options and are comfortable with your choice...You only get one shot at this....

Posts.Title: Surgery scheduled Scared to death - help

Posts.Content: Several things can cause an abnormally high PSA test. You seem to have 2 of those conditions, an infection and an enlarged prostate..Once the infection has been successfully dealt with, an accurate PSA test can be performed..For a man your age, "normal" would be anything below 2.0 2.1 to 4.0 are in the twilight zone..Over 4.0, further investigation is warranted to find out the cause..Anything over 10.0 is cause for immediate concern..

Posts.Title: Need Help With Your Drug Co-pays ??

Posts.Content: One thing to keep in mind. Prostate cancer tends to be multi-focal. You can not depend on the 12 shot needle biopsy to have found every tumor. There is still a possibility that a more aggressive tumor escaped detection by the biopsy procedure. The chance of this occurring is in the 20-30% range...Where does that number come from? When men choose surgery and the entire gland is removed and biopsied, about 30 percent of the time the original Gleason score is updated to a higher number than the needle biopsy revealed..So if you choose AS as your treatment choice, you need to do everything possible to rule out the possibility that a more aggressive form of cancer might be undiscovered....Your G-6 diagnosis is a great place to start and gives you plenty of time to consider all your treatment options...Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Post radical prostatectomy possibilities for children

Posts.Content: MRI's can only predict prostate cancer with 60-70% accuracy. That's why we still do biopsies... Radiation has just as good a record of delivering a CURE as surgery does... A 'scope job before surgery is somewhat unusual unless there is something specific he wants to check... Dr. Walsh's book is worth reading... Diet never cured anyone of cancer..

Posts.Title: Prostate surgery??

Posts.Content: You say they have very good equipment..Many smaller facilities are using out-dated equipment..I would insist on a Varian RapidArc LINAC or newer..The newer equipment simply outperforms the old stuff by a wide margin, especially in avoiding damage to healthy tissue.. A long-term cure? Yours is a low-risk case, so the chances are high a cure can be achieved. But nothing in this business is 100% guaranteed... Incontinence is rare with radiation, not really an issue if performed by experts...ED? That's a little different..At the 3 year post treatment mark, 50% of those treated have some degree of ED. The little blue pills usually take care of it...

Posts.Title: Feeling Terrible

Posts.Content: Your life is on the line here..You would be AMAZED how fast you can lose weight if you REALLY put your mind to it...Drop your calorie intake to maybe 600 a day and you can lose 1.5 to 2.0 pounds a day, more if you exercise. It's not easy, but all things considered, you can do it. Maybe have a nutritionist help you set it up and monitor your progress...Do you drink ? (alcohol) ..If so, that's the first thing to eliminate..You CAN do it..

Posts.Title: Taking care of yourself while on ADT

Posts.Content: It is almost CERTAIN he will need both radiation and HT after the surgery. Gleason 9, 5+4 and a PSA of 80 virtually guarantees it..The surgery MAY improve his odds by removing most of the cancer, reducing the work the radiation and HT will have to do, but the side-effects of the surgery are probably not worth any gain it will provide...He should read Dr. Walsh's book, there's a sticky thread at the top of this forum, to get some insights of exactly what he is dealing with..And since he will be needing the services of a radiation oncologist at some point, he might as well talk to one now..These two specialists, surgeons and radiation oncologists seldom see eye to eye and they are in fact competitors for your business.. Age 57..There may be insurance issues..Be sure the service providers get pre-approval BEFORE any procedures are performed to avoid any nasty surprises.. My signature is written in shorthand, they limit the space you have, but you can see I'm a G-9, had surgery, it failed, then radiation combined with hormone therapy. The side-effects were/are significant, but manageable. I'm doing okay at the 2 year mark but like many of us, there are storm clouds on the horizon...

Posts.Content: It's the Eligard that's producing the ).01 PSA test result..That's to be expected and hoped for..When they take you off the ADT, 6 months that, just when things are getting back to normal, THAT's the test that counts, that's the big one..But that .01 is indeed good news, it shows you are on the right path, heading in the right direction! So enjoy being in the Zero Club and try to stop worrying, as difficult as that may be....

Posts.Title: Saw palmetto

Posts.Content: Gold Markers = Older LINAC.. If not Dattoli, at least find an RO who has access to a Varian RapidArc machine (LINAC) that is capable of making real-time corrections during the treatment process and greatly limits the exposure of healthy tissue during the process..Learn all you can about Radiation Treatment before you climb on the table...

Posts.Title: Taking care of yourself while on ADT

Posts.Content: We have a single payer system, a big one, here in the United states. It's called the VA Medical System. All the doctors, nurses, technicians, everybody are government employees. The generic drugs they dispense are purchased in bulk quantities at deep discounts. The VA system serves about 9 million patients a year at little or no cost to the veterans.... Mexico has a somewhat unique system where doctors and nurses are trained at government expense, they graduate from med school debt-free...They then must work in the government healthcare system (free to all Mexican citizens) for 10 years. They are paid a decent middle-class salary while working in the government system. At the 10 year mark, they can work in private practice, open clinics of their own, in the parallel private health care system which exists alongside the government system. Or they can stay in the government system, become specialists and are paid more money. or they can do both..Work for the government part time and also maintain a private practice... Canada also uses a system much like our VA system except all Canadian citizens can use it...The vast majority of Canadians are very satisfied with the care they receive.

Posts.Title: Surgery on Wednesday

Posts.Content: Several things can cause an abnormally high PSA test. You seem to have 2 of those conditions, an infection and an enlarged prostate..Once the infection has been successfully dealt with, an accurate PSA test can be performed..For a man your age, "normal" would be anything below 2.0 2.1 to 4.0 are in the twilight zone..Over 4.0, further investigation is warranted to find out the cause..Anything over 10.0 is cause for immediate concern..

Posts.Title: worried, please help

Posts.Content: Have you tried Xtandi? Like Zytiga (Abiraterone Acetate) it's very expensive too but it's an approved treatment with an excellent success record. Push for it..Yes, the VA will push back, it's a never-ending battle.. It's another issue, but we need to change the way "Cancer Drugs" are developed and marketed.. Otherwise, pretty soon, only millionaires will be able to afford cancer treatment... I take a supplement called "Pomi-T" You can find it online, ebay even.. I don't know if it does anything but it's cheap and it can't hurt....My PSA is behaving nicely.. Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Preserving Both Sphincter Muscles in Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Hello Joe...How old are you? Pick up a copy of Dr. Pat Walsh's book, "Surviving Prostate Cancer'" and read it..Before they begin radiation treatments, they should do a couple of scans, a PET-CT and Bone Scan to see if the cancer has spread outside the pelvic area..Maybe they have already done this..Radiation will not be effective if the horse has left the barn..It looks like what you are doing now has been VERY effective and it's a good sign. Stick with it...We are all here to help..If you have any questions or problems post them here and help is on the way...

Posts.Title: Totally Shocked, and not in a good way

Posts.Content: The newer machines need no markers...They do a quick CAT scan just before the radiation beam is turned on..Any movement of the target area or change in its shape is compensated for or the machine is stopped..In the older machines, the gantry stops at intervals, shoots, then moves on to the next position and shots again, usually 7 "firing points" or pathways into the target. This means healthy tissue gets 1/7th the dose of the target..With the RapidArc, the gantry is moving in a programmed arc, making several passes, so healthy tissue receives much less radiation overall....The new machines are more powerful so the dose can be delivered quicker and you spend less time on the table..You get a few tiny tattoos on your belly to line YOU up with the machine when you are on the table..A laser system in the treatment room aids in the positioning..

Posts.Title: Prostate size way off, DART versus gold Markers

Posts.Content: I would ask the doctor politely for your own written report of the post-surgery pathology..You should have your own copy of that and it is your right to have a copy. By revised Gleason score, fortyone means was there any change in the Gleason score from the original needle biopsy. Also, was there any cancer detected in the seminal vesicles..This is a pathway through which PC can escape the prostate capsule...

Posts.Title: Questions for the Doctor

Posts.Content: We are both in the same boat, along with many others..At this point, as Newporter suggested, it's time to find a Medical Oncologist who tends to specialize in prostate cancer..Urologists don't have the specialized cancer training that oncologists do..Hormone therapy is definitely the next step..It comes with a big side-effect load but it's very effective for most men and it can hold the cancer in check for many years. The AVERAGE effective period is about 3 years before the cancer becomes refractory, which means the cancer has developed the ability to grow without any testosterone support..Today, drugs are used (Lupron) to stop testosterone production. In the past it was castration, which is still the most effective form of ADT..Pomegranate juice or extract has been proven to slow PSA doubling time. So has aspirin, but aspirin can cause nasty stomach and intestinal problems so don't take it without a doctors advise.. When to start hormone therapy...There are two schools of thought..One is to wait until your PSA reaches some predetermined level, anywhere from 10 to 50 or higher before starting HT. This gives you some time without suffering the HT side-effects but it allows the cancer to progress unchecked, perhaps to the point where bone metastases are detected which is not a good thing. Then the HT is begun with the hope that it will completely suppress and control the cancer.. The other school of thought is to start the ADT right away so it can suppress the cancer while it's still very small and prevent mets to the bones for as long as possible. Studies have shown that there is little if any difference in survival time between the two methods..Some doctors use intermittent HT, giving their patients a break from the drugs until the PSA begins to rise again..This method offers no survival advantage. Fortunately, there are several new drugs and treatments coming online or already approved that have shown great promise in trials.. While none of them offer a cure, they all offer a considerable increase in survival times... While nobody can accurately predict prostate cancer survival time, and new cancer treatment discoveries are coming quickly now, you and I should be good for another 6 to 10 years if you stay on top of it and use all the tools available..

Posts.Title: Scared after prostate surgery and radiation failure, please adivise

Posts.Content: Jerry, don't believe everything you find and read on the internet..Radiation Treatment has came a LONG ways over the last 5 or 10 years..The equipment used today (LINACS) are far more advanced and accurate delivering the radiation without damaging surrounding healthy tissue, it's a whole new ballgame..The horror stories you can find on the internet about radiation side-effects in the past have largely been eliminated...As long as you have confidence that your RO is up to date on his training and that he is using a modern LINAC to treat you you should be fine..Ask the make and model of the LINAC. It should be a Varian TrueBeam or Rapid Arc, something like that.. The trend that is developing is a reduction in the 40 fraction treatment down to 25 fractions or so, which greatly reduces the cost and time involved..But not everyone can do the shorter treatment..Since your treatment has already started, you are pretty much committed the treatment plan you are on...Best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: EBRT Concerns

Posts.Content: Gleason 6 can almost always be cured with minimal treatment. I would lean towards the Brachy as long as the procedure will be performed by someone who is an expert at it....If that's the case, the brachy should produce a cure with few if any long-term side-effects..JMHO....BUT, if you have an EXPERT surgeon perform a prostatectomy, at your age, the results should be the same and no worries about future problems caused by the radiation.."Radiation, the gift that keeps on giving.."

Posts.Title: Torn between Brachy or Surgery: Input Requested

Posts.Content: When considering robo-surgery, you want a surgeon who has done 300 or more, is comfortable doing them, and can show you a long list of successful outcomes. In the big treatment centers, Robo has all but replaced open surgery because, overall, it works better.. If you don't get the answers you want, you can still find surgeons, usually the older guys, who will be happy to do open surgery...
Posts.Title: Serious Side Effects of Davinci Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: The BEST surgeons can achieve a high cure rate and minimize the chances of serious side-effects, which are different than "complications" but again, the good doctors don't have too many complications either..With the impotence thing, much depends on how potent you are now...If you need "a little help" now, then you will probably need a lot of help after the surgery and radiation offers no free lunch in that regard..It just takes longer to manifest itself.. I chose surgery because if it fails, you get a second chance at a cure with radiation..If you choose radiation as your primary treatment and it fails, you get no second shot at a cure...In my case, G-9, both the surgery and radiation failed and I'm completely impotent.. "with a pathology report saying the gleason was 6- Is that possible with 2 of them 6 and 2 of them 7?. Psa had climbed to 5.9, still under 6." No, not possible..If just one sample had any Grade 4 cancer in it, you are Gleason 7 and that's that. It's the highest grade found that counts, not the lowest.. You should be aware that biopsies are often upgraded to a higher score after surgery when the entire prostate gland can be examined..Needle Biopsies only sample a tiny percentage of the total tissue volume..

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed prostaste cancer -T1c tumor

Posts.Content: How the claim was submitted is important..If you walked into the local Lab Corp and they submitted the claim directly, that could be the problem. You would be better off having your local PCP draw the blood and submit it for testing and do the Medicare billing..You can't fight the system....
Posts.Title: Medicare Refused to Pay for PSA Test

Posts.Content: Another problem, just because a 12 shot biopsy found only a small amount of G-6 cancer, that does not guarantee that's all there is....P.C. tends to be multi-focal, separate tumors can and frequently do develop in the prostate that are a higher grade than what the biopsy discovered. With AS, you are betting your life that your cancer is indolent and no major treatment is necessary..But you can never be sure.....A.S. is a reasonable bet when you have a good M.O. who monitors you closely and uses all the tools available to ferret out any change in the risk you are taking.....

Posts.Title: Questioning next steps after Dad's negative biopsy

Posts.Content: Lots has changed over the last 14 years...Maybe one of the new high-tech scans to actually spot the exact location of the cancer..it might not be in your pelvic area! if you have not consulted with a Medical Oncologist yet, now would be a good time to do so.. Radiation has come a long way...The latest generation of LINACS (the machines that deliver the radiation) are light-years ahead of the older equipment in their ability to deliver the radiation where it's needed and to avoid damaging nearby healthy tissue. If you go with SRT, ask for a Varian RapidArc or better. It costs no more...Near-term, side-effects are minimal..A little fatigue and a feeling of urinary urgency near the end of the treatment cycle..Long term maybe a secondary cancer caused by the radiation but you will be in your 80's....

Posts.Title: Medicare Refused to Pay for PSA Test

Posts.Content: Logic, you have aggressive, life-threatening cancer. To give yourself the best shot, in my opinion, you hit it as hard as you can with everything you can as soon as you can...The best outcomes <SEEM> to be achieved when all 3 treatments are used. Surgery to remove most of the cancer and if you get lucky, all of it. Radiation combined with a year or two of hormone therapy to clean up anything that's left. That was the plan I followed and so far it has worked for me. Yes, this will also subject you to the full range of side-effects associated with these treatments. Every case is different and we all make our own treatment choices based on many different things..Most men with PC have Gleason 6 cancer, 45-50% can get by with much less aggressive treatment. Much of what you will read online is aimed at those men..But men in the Gleason 9 situation, we need to follow a different path if we expect to die from something other than prostate cancer...I hope my views do not offend you or anyone else who may read this..You should read Dr. Walsh's book and consult with several doctors who are PC experts before you make your treatment decision... Best of luck to you....

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnossed - questions about choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: I wonder how much a surgeon gets paid, on average, to do an RP in the U.S.? Somehow, I get the feeling cancer is a MAJOR industry and spoils get divvied up according to carefully developed protocols.. If cancer were cured tomorrow, it would create a depression in the medical community...Oncology is where the big money is...
Posts.Title: Serious Side Effects of Davinci Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: Your low PSA and Gleason made you a perfect candidate for radiation / implants..Buy using the Partin & Han tables, you can pretty much figure out what type of treatment is appropriate for you.. Everyone who is diagnosed should talk to a surgeon who SPECIALIZES in RP, especially if it will be done roboticly. But either way, open or robotic, it's the experience and track record of the surgeon that counts.. After you chat with the surgeon, talk to an experienced Radiation Oncologist who has access to the latest equipment. He is now ALMOST on equal footing with the surgeon when it comes to long-term outcomes..In many cases, radiation is the better choice.. If the outcomes appear to be the same, then you can base your choice on probable side-effects and recovery time. Many men will be diagnosed without having health insurance...Now there is a THIRD factor to be considered. Cost. And a form of treatment not approved in the U.S. but used widely elsewhere called HiFu..Backstage, there is a raging argument going on..
Posts.Title: Serious Side Effects of Davinci Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: Today, 80% of the RP operations performed in the United States are being performed roboticly..

Posts.Title: Torn between Brachy or Surgery: Input Requested

Posts.Content: PC is multi-focal, there tends to be more than one tumor. 7 distinct tumors is the average when they biopsy the entire gland.. I am not a medical professional, nobody here is, but I think surgery is a poor choice when all 12 biopsy cores are positive..You COULD insist that a second, expert reading of your biopsy slides be done by a lab that specializes in PC just to be sure your lab got it right..The recommended hormone, radiation and seeds combination probably has the best overall cure rate in cases like yours which must be called high risk with the 12 cores positive....Like anything else, you want the best people involved in your treatment..You want a Radiation Onco0logist who really knows his stuff and has the latest equipment at his disposal..Try to limit the hormone part of the treatment to no more than 24 months..Best of luck to you...Have you read Dr. Pat Walsh's book? If not, do so..

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: You could have a UTI. This is usually treated with a 2-week run of antibiotics..Sometimes UTI's don't show up in the urine..Some UTI's are difficult to cure and require multiple antibiotics to finally knock them down..If your GP seems perplexed by your condition, ask for a referral to see a Urologist..
Posts.Title: Hey. Need advice.

Posts.Content: There is always a reason for a rapid rise in PSA levels...A good Urologist will find that reason....Should another biopsy be needed, lobby for having a "saturation biopsy", which is performed in a hospital under general anesthetic..A different technique is used that samples more tissue and if there is cancer present it will find it...

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Individual surgeons seldom make enough information about themselves available so potential customers can make an informed decision.. Many don't even keep records detailing the outcomes of their surgeries..The ones that do keep records, those records are always "confidential" or have been carefully filtered to present the surgeon in as good a light as possible..The same thing with "happy customer" testimonials..The surgeon is not going to provide the names of unhappy customers and few will provide any names at all...The ones who have done many procedures (over 400) usually are pretty good at it..That and what kind of gut feeling you have about them after talking with them for a while..

Posts.Title: Torn between Brachy or Surgery: Input Requested

Posts.Content: I was in pretty good shape physically, surgeons seldom turn down $10K for 4 hours work.....But mine stepped back if patients were over 70....Seeds were ruled out because of prostate size, and in Denver few R.O.'s perform Brachy...My surgeon told me right up front that I would probably need radiation regardless..It was a 50-50 deal but a 50% chance for a cure was worth it to me... G-9 is a different ball game..You hit it as hard as you can with everything you have...I'm back on HT/ADT now, PSA under 1.0 But that won't last forever...The goal now is to stop the onset of bone metastasis for as long as possible..There is stuff in the pipeline that is very promising and a couple of the new approved drugs are having great success in slowing the monster down and extending survival times more than was thought possible just a few years ago..You can't let this thing take over your life with doctor appointments every 2 weeks..You can become a cow in a milking parlor with endless scans and tests and office visits...If you have not read Walsh's book, you should...Keeping in mind that he is a surgeon, one of the best..If you decide on beam radiation, look into how old the LINAC they will treat you with is..The new machines (Varian RapidArc) are able to do a MUCH better job, worth seeking one out..Hang in there Brother....Best of luck to you...

AgeInfo.Phrase: radiation regardless  It was a 50 50 deal but a 50%
regardless  It was a 50 50 deal but a 50% chance
