Posts.Title: Sloan Kettering nomogram question

Posts.Content: How the claim was submitted is important..If you walked into the local Lab Corp and they submitted the claim directly, that could be the problem. You would be better off having your local PCP draw the blood and submit it for testing and do the Medicare billing..You can't fight the system....
Posts.Title: Medicare Refused to Pay for PSA Test

Posts.Content: While my PSA at diagnosis was similar to yours, I had less overall cancer in the cores, only one core with G-9..My surgeon told me surgery had a 50-50 chance of delivering a complete cure, but that with G-9, I should expect to do follow-up radiation regardless..My radiation oncologist said forget the surgery, you will need radiation anyway, so lets just do radiation and HT..I then talked with a Medical Oncologist. Explained my quandary..He gave it some thought and then told me "I would try the surgery first, and move on to radiation if that fails"....I took his advise..The surgery DID fail, my PSA hung at 0.9..Not only that, I developed a hospital acquired staff infection that put me back in the hospital for a week and I.V. antibiotics for a month..My only lingering side-effect is 100% impotence..The hot flashes have stopped now that I'm off the HT but I've lost some muscle mass. That's my journey in a nut-shell.. This is not a little bump in the road...This is a BIG bump in the road...You might investigate if Brachytherapy combined with IMRT would work for you..If I had to do it again, I would try a little harder to obtain that treatment even if it means traveling to get it..Also, the newest LINACS, radiation machines, are a better bet than the older equipment. Drop the name "Varian RapidArc" on your R.O. and get his reaction/take on it...I chose an RO who had access to one. It costs no more...
Posts.Title: It Seems Aggressive...

Posts.Content: Another problem, just because a 12 shot biopsy found only a small amount of G-6 cancer, that does not guarantee that's all there is....P.C. tends to be multi-focal, separate tumors can and frequently do develop in the prostate that are a higher grade than what the biopsy discovered. With AS, you are betting your life that your cancer is indolent and no major treatment is necessary..But you can never be sure.....A.S. is a reasonable bet when you have a good M.O. who monitors you closely and uses all the tools available to ferret out any change in the risk you are taking.....

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnossed - questions about choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Of all the new treatments, when Provenge is combined with Xtandi, some spectacular results have been obtained..But since this is not a standard, approved, treatment, getting insurance companies to pay for it is very difficult..Also, some of the old, forgotten, cheap treatments like low-dose Estrogen have produced dramatic and unexpected benefits...Were you so certain you were cured that you neglected having regular (semi-annual) PSA tests? Many of us are in the same boat as you are, we are just at a slightly different spot in our journey. For many of us, these voyages all end at the same place..I try to squeeze the most I can out of every day left to me...The doctors will take over your life if you let them. That's no good either...Best of Luck to You...

Posts.Title: prostate cancer w/mets to bones

Posts.Content: I wonder how much a surgeon gets paid, on average, to do an RP in the U.S.? Somehow, I get the feeling cancer is a MAJOR industry and spoils get divvied up according to carefully developed protocols.. If cancer were cured tomorrow, it would create a depression in the medical community...Oncology is where the big money is...
Posts.Title: Serious Side Effects of Davinci Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: It takes radiation a year or two to work, it's not an instant cure....If your PSA continues a steady rise, then it didn't work..But they have a cornucopia full of treatments and new drugs to work with so a 10 year horizon, regardless, is very realistic....Don't become a PSA slave or get into a PSA anxiety thing.Just play the hand you have been dealt and get on with your life...

Posts.Title: Interpreation of my Gleason

Posts.Content: What, exactly, puts you in the "high risk" category? The reason many RO's recommend 24 months is because that's the time period the clinical trial used that discovered that ADT could boost the effectiveness of radiation by 50%..Recently, there has been a tendency to use shorter time periods because it has been found that 1 year works ALMOST as good as 2 years...But with high risk guys, 2 years is pretty much standard...Oh, don't ask a urologist about radiation doses or hormone therapy. That's above their pay grade...You want a second opinion, chat with a Medical Oncologist..

Posts.Title: How long should I be on ADT (hormone therapy)?

Posts.Content: Sounds good to me..I agree with everything you are doing..just getting the weight off, that is no easy accomplishment, good for you! Yes indeed, it will make everything that follows much quicker and easier.. So you KNOW you have PC and at some point you will have to deal with it..But very few men ever die from G-6 prostate cancer..So take your time and weigh all your options carefully..For you, surgery IS probably the best choice, but find the best surgeon you can. Unless they have been sued for malpractice, they ALL claim to be experts with above average success rates and below average side-effect occurrence..Achieving a cure while avoiding incontinence and impotence is difficult and only the best can do it...Radiation treatment has made great strides in recent years with much improved equipment and techniques..Be sure to consult with a Radiation Oncologist before you make your final treatment decision and see what he has to offer. The combination of seeds and EBRT equals or exceeds the performance of surgery with more manageable side-effects.. Always remember, not only are these people Urologists, Surgeons, Oncologists, they are also salesmen, each with a favorite product to try and sell you...Best of luck to you!

Posts.Title: Wish I knew then..

Posts.Content: ADT or Hormone Therapy (HT) usually has a profound effect at controlling PC But every man is different as to how profound the the remission is..For some men it's 2 years and for others it's 10 years or more..Today, there are new drugs and treatments to try after HT stops working...The key indicator is the PSA reading and its doubling time...

Posts.Title: Radiation Opinions Sought and Be Your Own Advocate

Posts.Content: Hopefully, his PSA will be undetectable and stay undetectable...But if radiation becomes necessary, you should know that it will stop further progress with the incontinence situation..So it's important to get that under control...Two OTC supplements that might be worthwhile, Pomi-T and low-dose aspirin...Check them out...IP-6 is a third compound that some feel has benefit..Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Radiation Opinions Sought and Be Your Own Advocate

Posts.Content: Wait a minute!! A high PSA reading does NOT guarantee prostate cancer!! ONLY a biopsy can do that!! ONLY a biopsy can determine the GRADE of the cancer if indeed he has cancer...I would not begin treatment for prostate cancer until it has been verified that hubby actually HAS prostate cancer.... There are men who have very high PSA readings who have had multiple biopsies but no cancer is found! I would hold off on the Lupron shot until you consult with the experts at MD Anderson and a more complete picture of your husbands condition emerges..

Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: Anschutz Cancer Research center in Denver has published some interesting work they have done with IP6. They have found it worthwhile as have other researchers. I've been taking it for 2 years..I also take Pomi-T a Pomegranate, cumin, broccoli, green tea extract that is dispensed to PC patients in Great Britain with considerable success. Check Amazon, eBay... http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3662486/ The drug companies are not interested in anything they can not patent and make a $Billion$ dollars a year on...

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer and IP6?

Posts.Content: I posted a link to a National Institute of Health published article submitted by researchers at a recognized Cancer Research Center in Denver..Anshutz ....If you take the time to read the link, you will see they achieved some worthwhile results with IP-6..And it doesn't cost $15,000 a month.....Like Pomi-T and Pomegranate, IP-6 has a place in controlling prostate cancer..The whole idea is to slow down that PSA doubling time...

Posts.Title: It's been a few months since surgery

Posts.Content: What, exactly, puts you in the "high risk" category? The reason many RO's recommend 24 months is because that's the time period the clinical trial used that discovered that ADT could boost the effectiveness of radiation by 50%..Recently, there has been a tendency to use shorter time periods because it has been found that 1 year works ALMOST as good as 2 years...But with high risk guys, 2 years is pretty much standard...Oh, don't ask a urologist about radiation doses or hormone therapy. That's above their pay grade...You want a second opinion, chat with a Medical Oncologist..

Posts.Content: They may want to do a cystoscope exam of his urinary track. I think you might insist on it... I went into urinary retention and the 'scope spotted a small bladder stone which was causing the problem..Using the same instrument, they were able to remove the stone on the spot and no more problems...I too was instructed how to self-catheterize and given a supply of catheters to avoid any more Friday night ER visits. I have not had to use any since the stone was removed...

Posts.Title: Cyber Knife Surgery

Posts.Content: PSA VELOCITY is just as important as the actual number..How fast the PSA is going up, it's doubling time... I think you could go another 2 or 3 months, have another PSA test and make your biopsy decision at that point...If the upward trend continues, it's time for a biopsy....Much of your increased PSA is most likely due to the enlarged prostate..You might ask your Uro about going on Avodart for a couple of months and see how your PSA responds to that...In most healthy men, it will cut your PSA in half. If PC is present, the drop in PSA will not be so dramatic..

Posts.Title: Advice needed on getting or not getting a Biopsy on prostate

Posts.Content: I don't think you need to worry about "safety" of drugs imported from Canada..And taking 1/2 a pill a day for a year is ridiculous. 60 days will do all it's going to do...The compound that is Viagra, Sudenafil Citrate is a simple one to make and it is sold all over the world for .50- $1 a pill..Any number of off-shore pharmacy's will be happy to fill your order at a reasonable price..I have used ADC, all day chemists with no problems..Just be careful and do your homework...

Posts.Title: Viagra

Posts.Content: I had the robotic procedure..Sounds like your urologist is more comfortable doing open surgery and there is nothing wrong with that..The recovery is a little longer, that's all..What counts is his success rate, not the technique he uses. For the daVinci machine, you want an expert who is comfortable doing it that way and has done at least 300 of them.. I had lymph nodes removed during my surgery (robotic). About 10 days later I developed an infected lymphocele, a fluid-filled pocket in my abdomen that put me back in the hospital for a week and on IV antibiotics for another month...Any time lymph nodes are removed, lymphoceles can develop because the lymph can't drain properly..My infection was determined to be hospital acquired staff, another issue entirely..

Posts.Title: Lymph node removal with robotic surgery?

Posts.Content: Xtandi, Zytiga, enzalatamide....These drugs have delivered spectacular results in some stage 4 patients..Do they offer a cure? Sorry, but no....When you use the term successful in the context of cancer drugs it usually means the drug produces over one Billion in sales to the patent holder...They consider that a tremendous success...I'm a G-9, still good on ADT, but knowing it's just a matter of time....Hang in there Brother and good luck.... I read that blog...The writer should have read Dr. Walsh's book a long time ago..Urologists and surgeons don't have the training to treat cancer..Once the primary treatment fails, it's time to let a Medical Oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer direct any further treatment...Maybe they can extend your life until you die from something else and maybe they can't..Some forms of Prostate Cancer can't be cured no matter how early they are found...They metastasize before they are detected..The Gleason grade is a fairly good predictor of this... Only the patient can decide whether the cost and side-effects of the treatment is worth any possible benefit that might be obtained...Some of the old, forgotten, off patent treatments like estrogen patches or pills work just as good as the new $10,000 a month therapies..The Hemlock Society offers another path but I'll probably get my wrist slapped just for mentioning those two words...

Posts.Title: Recieved Path Report in the mail

Posts.Content: Wait a minute!! A high PSA reading does NOT guarantee prostate cancer!! ONLY a biopsy can do that!! ONLY a biopsy can determine the GRADE of the cancer if indeed he has cancer...I would not begin treatment for prostate cancer until it has been verified that hubby actually HAS prostate cancer.... There are men who have very high PSA readings who have had multiple biopsies but no cancer is found! I would hold off on the Lupron shot until you consult with the experts at MD Anderson and a more complete picture of your husbands condition emerges..

Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: Things to be aware of..How quickly his PSA drops and how low it gets is important and a good indicator. The lower the better...He should have his PSA checked every 3 months. At some point, it will start to rise. Then the rate of rise becomes important, called PSA doubling time..Slower is better. In the U.S. there are several drugs and treatments that can be given and these can extend patients lives considerably. They are expensive. Things like Xtandi and Provenge.. There are a few food supplements that have been shown to slow down the progression of PC. Pomegranate, IP-6, Turmeric, Broccoli have all been used with success.. But, on average, once prostate cancer has metastasized to the bones, AVERAGE lifespan is a little over 4 years.. 10% die in one year..At 5 years, 60% have died. 10% live beyond 10 years with bone mets....

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer and IP6?

Posts.Content: A second opinion on the biopsy pathology is important when the results show a low volume of Gleason 6 cancer..This can be tricky to read and your treatment choices may depend on an accurate reading..But once you move into Gleason 7 territory, any competent Pathologist can provide an accurate report..There may be slight differences in a local report and an "expert" report, but usually not enough to change your treatment recommendations...Just my opinion.... Also, just because the samples provided to the pathologist return a low volume Gleason 6 report, you can't be SURE there is not some more aggressive cancer lurking undiscovered..The ONLY way to determine that is to remove the entire gland and examine it..In about 30% of PC cases, when surgery is chosen and the gland removed, the final pathology report reveals more aggressive cancer undiscovered by the original biopsy....

Posts.Title: Leg pain

Posts.Content: The only SURE way to diagnose PC is with a biopsy. IF you have prostate cancer, a 12 core needle biopsy will find it 90% of the time..Your PSA velocity will or will not trigger a second and possibly a third biopsy should the first one return negative.. As my PSA continued its upward march, it took three biopsies to finally confirm my cancer. That's just the breaks of the game...You can spend some bucks on a Doppler Color Ultrasound Guided exam and biopsy or a saturation biopsy if the thought of having multiple biopsies does not appeal to you..You may have to travel to find someone to perform the Color Doppler procedure...

Posts.Title: Alternatives to Biopsy for Determining PC ?

Posts.Content: You are confusing the Gleason numbers with the PSA number......Two different things...The PSA is determined by a simple blood test. The Gleason is determined by a biopsy of the prostate tissue..Gleason scores range from 6 to 10, 6 being the least aggressive and 10 being the most aggressive..

Posts.Title: Vacation question

Posts.Content: Wait a minute!! A high PSA reading does NOT guarantee prostate cancer!! ONLY a biopsy can do that!! ONLY a biopsy can determine the GRADE of the cancer if indeed he has cancer...I would not begin treatment for prostate cancer until it has been verified that hubby actually HAS prostate cancer.... There are men who have very high PSA readings who have had multiple biopsies but no cancer is found! I would hold off on the Lupron shot until you consult with the experts at MD Anderson and a more complete picture of your husbands condition emerges..

Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: Third hand information can be very inaccurate and twisted..How old is Dad? If the prostate cancer has metastasized, it's still prostate cancer, not "bone cancer"..When the ADT (hormone therapy, Lupron & Casodex) fail to control the cancer, it's called "Hormone Refractory" and that makes him eligible for several newer treatments including Xtandi & Zitiga. You might want to read Dr Pat Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer" and accompanying your Dad on his next Doctor's visit.. That doctor should be a medical oncologist..Best of luck to you and your Dad....

Posts.Title: Dad's prostate cancer

Posts.Content: The high grade PIN frequently leads to a PC diagnosis on your next biopsy...As for getting old, that just happens whether you have PC or not..I'm still very active and going strong at 71 and I have endured all the PC treatments..The key is staying active, eat healthy, exercise and watch your weight..But that clock keeps ticking and at some point our physical and mental abilities just slip away... Being treated for PC is just a bump in the road....

Posts.Title: Age 65 with Gleason 9 Treatment Options

Posts.Content: PSA VELOCITY is just as important as the actual number..How fast the PSA is going up, it's doubling time... I think you could go another 2 or 3 months, have another PSA test and make your biopsy decision at that point...If the upward trend continues, it's time for a biopsy....Much of your increased PSA is most likely due to the enlarged prostate..You might ask your Uro about going on Avodart for a couple of months and see how your PSA responds to that...In most healthy men, it will cut your PSA in half. If PC is present, the drop in PSA will not be so dramatic..

Posts.Title: Advice needed on getting or not getting a Biopsy on prostate

Posts.Content: PSA 10.2, it's time for a biopsy. If your URO has no one filling in for him, and any possible appointment for a biopsy will be in August sometime, well, you can wait or you can seek out another urologist who perhaps can see you sooner...PC is usually not very aggressive and waiting until August is not an unreasonable decision but that's up to you.....

Posts.Content: I had robotic surgery and needed very little post op pain medication..They gave me some pain pills to take home (the next day) Perkies maybe, but I don't recall needing them..There was some stiffness and discomfort but no real pain..I have never heard of a prostate surgery where they used a "spinal" for post-op pain control....What helped me recover the most was walking...Half a block at first, then after a few days, around the block. Then after a week, I could walk a mile and felt MUCH better for doing it...Talk to your surgeon about it...

Posts.Title: High PSA and enlarged Prostate!!

Posts.Content: Be sure to consult with a Radiation Oncologist..In your case, because of your age, long term side-effects become more important than they would be with and older patient. Over the past 10 years, great advances have been made in radiation treatment. For the most part, the old horror stories no longer apply while effectiveness and side-effect reduction are much improved... As for doing prostatectomies, 90% are done using the daVinci robot today, and not much has changed with surgery over the past 10 years..

Posts.Title: PSA Variations, Prostate Cancer ?

Posts.Content: The only SURE way to diagnose PC is with a biopsy. IF you have prostate cancer, a 12 core needle biopsy will find it 90% of the time..Your PSA velocity will or will not trigger a second and possibly a third biopsy should the first one return negative.. As my PSA continued its upward march, it took three biopsies to finally confirm my cancer. That's just the breaks of the game...You can spend some bucks on a Doppler Color Ultrasound Guided exam and biopsy or a saturation biopsy if the thought of having multiple biopsies does not appeal to you..You may have to travel to find someone to perform the Color Doppler procedure...

Posts.Title: Alternatives to Biopsy for Determining PC ?

Posts.Content: Third hand information can be very inaccurate and twisted..How old is Dad? If the prostate cancer has metastasized, it's still prostate cancer, not "bone cancer"..When the ADT (hormone therapy, Lupron & Casodex) fail to control the cancer, it's called "Hormone Refractory" and that makes him eligible for several newer treatments including Xtandi & Zitiga. You might want to read Dr Pat Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer" and accompanying your Dad on his next Doctor's visit.. That doctor should be a medical oncologist..Best of luck to you and your Dad....

Posts.Title: blood after biopsy

Posts.Content: The only way you will know FOR SURE it's G-6 is to remove the entire prostate gland and examine it..Many Gleason scores are upgraded to a higher number after surgery and a complete biopsy...The needle biopsy can only see a tiny percentage of the gland. Prostate cancer is multi-focal..The average cancerous gland contains 7 separate and distinct tumors..Yes, the cost and side-effects of prostate surgery are considerable..But at age 46, cancer is cancer and it's not going to get better with age.....

Posts.Title: Surgery Scheduled-

Posts.Content: The high grade PIN frequently leads to a PC diagnosis on your next biopsy...As for getting old, that just happens whether you have PC or not..I'm still very active and going strong at 71 and I have endured all the PC treatments..The key is staying active, eat healthy, exercise and watch your weight..But that clock keeps ticking and at some point our physical and mental abilities just slip away... Being treated for PC is just a bump in the road....

Posts.Title: High PSA and enlarged Prostate!!

Posts.Content: Your husband is fighting for his life..But it's not hopeless...Doing the surgery probably will not cure him but it will remove 95% or more of the cancer. This means the radiation will have a MUCH easier time dealing with what gets left behind...You hit this as hard as you can with every tool at your disposal..Yes, there will be unpleasant side-effects but not as unpleasant as the alternative...And DO get second opinions. There are no doctors here..Find a good Medical Oncologist and sit down and have a long talk with him. See what he thinks about doing both surgery and radiation..Ask HIM to recommend a Radiation Oncologist and talk with him too...Pick up a copy of Dr Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer" and read it carefully. THEN decide on a course of treatment and don't look back....Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Young with High PSA and Very Scared

Posts.Content: Most patients tolerate both Xtandi and Zytiga with few (if any) side-effects..That has been my own experience..But at age 85, all bets are off..The older we get the less we are able to tolerate the powerful drugs used to treat cancer..What is his recent PSA history? The Xtandi / Zytiga work pretty quickly if they are going to work at all...You need to be prepared for the day when the side effects caused by the treatment are worse than the condition itself...You might ask the oncologist about reducing the dose to lessen the side effects..Not only is he fighting cancer but also the natural decline associated with advancing age..

Posts.Title: Young with High PSA and Very Scared

Posts.Content: First, you want to be completely continent (if possible) before you start any radiation treatment. Radiation will freeze your recovery from the surgery right where it is..At this point in your treatment, the HT is used to increase the effectiveness of the radiation..Recent studies have shown radiation is twice as effective when HT is in place during and after the radiation treatment. While HT by itself might have some post-surgical benefit, that has not been demonstrated.. With the positive node and Gleason 9, doing adjunct radiation and hormone treatment is pretty much the standard treatment. I too am a G-9 and have undergone all three treatments..My post surgery PSA never dropped below 0.9 but it has been undetectable since the end of my RT...My radiation oncologist at first wanted me on HT for 2 years but relented and stopped the Eligard (Lupron clone) after 14 months on the strength of my undetectable PSA and my complaints about the side-effects..The latest studies show that 12 months of HT is almost as effective as 24 or 36 when used as a adjunct to radiation..Many doctors will still press for 24 or even 36 months which can bring on some pretty heavy side-effects and make recovery from HT slow and difficult, if you recover at all.. Before you jump on the treatment table under a LINAC, try and find the most up to date machine you can..Many treatment centers are still using 10 and 15 year old equipment which is at a disadvantage when compared to the newest machines which can be aimed more accurately and deliver a higher dose while doing less damage to surrounding healthy tissue...Ask your R.O. this question: "Do you have access to a Varian RapidArc ?" and see what he has to say....Like surgeons, all R.O.'s are not the same..Find the best one you can, one that has treated hundreds of prostate patients..They will write the computer program that controls the LINAC during your treatment... I had 40 "fractions" 72 Gray, full pelvic, and like you, the last 7 were called "Boost" and tightly aimed at the prostate bed. Best of luck to you....

Posts.Title: Going on vacation

Posts.Content: Here are the more serious side-effects associated with Casodex.. chest pain, cough or trouble breathing; feeling short of breath, even with mild exertion; swelling in your hands or feet; fever, chills, body aches, flu symptoms; pale skin, easy bruising or bleeding; blood in your urine; or nausea, pain in your upper stomach, itching, dark urine, clay-colored stools, jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes). Some men simply can not tolerate this drug so Lupron or castration becomes their only choice..A new drug, Xtandi, works in a similar manner but in many men is MUCH more effective at suppressing cancer progression..The down-side is its cost, making it difficult to get insurance approval ..

Posts.Title: Bicalutamide monotherapy for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: We Boomers have a tough time facing our mortality....Nobody gets out alive, that's all there is to it...Yes, I know it's a big shock when the Reaper suddenly moves into sharper focus but your Dad still has quite a few years of "Quality Time" left to be with you and the rest of his family..Enjoy every minute of it...As time goes by, the ADT will deliver it's load of depressing side-effects but they are all manageable and a lot better than the alternative...As MM-16 pointed out, there are many advanced treatments available and more on the way. Not that long ago, they reserved chemo until the last resort but they have found that by starting it sooner it seems to work much better ..The chemo drugs they use against PC are not as nasty as those used against other types of cancers..Most men get through it okay...Another thing.. With PC, it's almost impossible to give an accurate prognosis...Every man, every case, responds differently. In some men, the ADT will provide a solid 5 year remission with Dad leading a pretty normal life..In others, the ADT will stop working in a year or less and nobody knows exactly why...You just have to play the cards you are dealt, be your own advocate, learn everything you can and never look back. Encourage Dad to exercise as much as he can. He will feel better and live longer for it. YES the ADT does cause fatigue and a lack of enthusiasm for things he once enjoyed..Don't let him slip into the recliner and just drift away...Get him to agree to an exercise plan and help him to stick to it. It will make a big difference..So who is this guy Fairwind giving all this advise? I'm someone just like your Dad, 75 years old, terminal prostate cancer, been through the meat grinder, but I try to enjoy every day that's given to me and I still have some good time left. When I was a teenager, I never thought I'd make it this far so no regrets, it's all bonus time now.....enjoy every minute of it. Best of luck to you and your Dad.....

Posts.Title: Proton Therapy Advice?

Posts.Content: Most Radiation Oncologists are VERY leery or using it for prostate cancer because they feel the side effect risk is much greater..It works fine for very small cancers in locations not surrounded by critical tissue structures like your bladder and rectum...The risk of damaging these critical organs is just too great with only 5 fractions..Since SBRT has only been used to treat prostate cancer for a short time, there is not enough data available to make any predictions on how effective it might be and how severe any side-effects will be, especially those that develop over time.

Posts.Title: Does anyone know how this new Treatment in NJ replaces 42 Radiations with 5 ?

Posts.Content: I slept in a bed with the night-bag hanging on the frame rail..The nice part, you don't have to get up to pee..How did they "plant" the catheter on your leg just after it exits your penis? A Velcro strap or an adhesive pad with a tube holder built in? It's important that there is the right amount of slack between the two so your penis won't get irritated from the tube pulling on it..Baggy sweat-pants work great for daytime wear..With a little experimenting, you CAN adjust the straps on the leg-bag so it stays in place. How is your appetite? It took me a while before I could eat much..Walking will speed your recovery and make you feel better..Welcome to the other side..

Posts.Title: Alternatives to Lupron

Posts.Content: Before the drugs like Lupron were discovered, orchiectomy, surgical castration, was the standard treatment..For men likely to need hormone treatment for the duration, it's still a viable option. It lowers testosterone to the lowest level possible and it works very quickly. Typical cost is less than half of one Lupron shot so for men without medical insurance, it offers effective, low cost treatment...There are other drugs more expensive than Lupron that claim to work better but insurance companies will seldom approve them... If drugs like Lupron are to be used, the "T" level needs to be monitored closely to make sure the drug is working well enough to be effective. Some oncologists will prescribe 3 different drugs, "The Triple Blockade", to get the maximum cancer fighting effect.

Posts.Title: Firstpost

Posts.Content: Men have 2 sphincters. You lost one of them with your prostate gland..The second one is at the base of your bladder where your urethra was reattached..Depending on how aggressive the surgeon was when he removed your prostate, it can take several months to regain your continence..
Posts.Title: 3 weeks after DaVinci... So many questions

Posts.Content: When prostate cancer is diagnosed, in about 65% of the cases, the Gleason grade is Gleason 6. Now the standard 12 core needle biopsy sometimes misses higher grade cancer that is only found if and when the prostate is surgically removed and the entire gland biopsied..But that leaves the MAJORITY of PC cases in the G-6 catagory which it is believed virtually never metastasizes of spreads beyond the prostate gland. This makes 'Doing Nothing" a good plan for the majority of PC patients..But what about the 40-45% who's Gleason score is something other than Gleason 6? For them "Doing Nothing" can be a death sentence. Lets not forget that 35,000 men will DIE from prostate cancer this year.. So when you see these studies that claim treating prostate cancer is a waste of time because treatment apparently has no effect on the mortality rate, I must take these studies with a grain of salt....Today's mortality rate from prostate cancer is much, much lower than it was 30 years ago, before the PSA test and effective treatments.....The G-6 guys never knew they had cancer and the G-8, 9 and 10 guys were dead in two or three years....

Posts.Title: 10-Year Outcomes after Monitoring, Surgery, or Radiotherapy for Localized PCa

Posts.Content: We Boomers have a tough time facing our mortality....Nobody gets out alive, that's all there is to it...Yes, I know it's a big shock when the Reaper suddenly moves into sharper focus but your Dad still has quite a few years of "Quality Time" left to be with you and the rest of his family..Enjoy every minute of it...As time goes by, the ADT will deliver it's load of depressing side-effects but they are all manageable and a lot better than the alternative...As MM-16 pointed out, there are many advanced treatments available and more on the way. Not that long ago, they reserved chemo until the last resort but they have found that by starting it sooner it seems to work much better ..The chemo drugs they use against PC are not as nasty as those used against other types of cancers..Most men get through it okay...Another thing.. With PC, it's almost impossible to give an accurate prognosis...Every man, every case, responds differently. In some men, the ADT will provide a solid 5 year remission with Dad leading a pretty normal life..In others, the ADT will stop working in a year or less and nobody knows exactly why...You just have to play the cards you are dealt, be your own advocate, learn everything you can and never look back. Encourage Dad to exercise as much as he can. He will feel better and live longer for it. YES the ADT does cause fatigue and a lack of enthusiasm for things he once enjoyed..Don't let him slip into the recliner and just drift away...Get him to agree to an exercise plan and help him to stick to it. It will make a big difference..So who is this guy Fairwind giving all this advise? I'm someone just like your Dad, 75 years old, terminal prostate cancer, been through the meat grinder, but I try to enjoy every day that's given to me and I still have some good time left. When I was a teenager, I never thought I'd make it this far so no regrets, it's all bonus time now.....enjoy every minute of it. Best of luck to you and your Dad.....

Posts.Title: Father with metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: From a biopsy, the "T" staging system is mostly guess-work since even at 100 cores, only a small fraction of the prostate has been sampled..What method was used to perform your biopsies? The only way to do an accurate staging is to remove the prostate gland and examine the entire lump of tissue..In about 30% of the cases, the Gleason score is upgraded to a higher number when the entire organ is biopsied...Another member here, John T, had a diagnosis very similar to yours, you may gain a lot of useful information by searching his threads..

Posts.Content: Depending on your PSA number, finding anything on an initial bone scan is pretty rare. But it's Standard Procedure if for no other reason than it provides a baseline reading that any future scans can be judged against...In cases where the bone scan turns up metastasis, it rules out forms of treatment that would be ineffective..

Posts.Title: My Survival Rate? (New to forums) (PSA + Gleason Score attached)

Posts.Content: Intraductal carcinoma, Gleason 8 is not your garden variety Gleason 6 diagnosis...This is serious business..I have a feeling you will be doing radiation and ADT regardless so why take on the risks and side-effects associated with surgery? The combination of brachy and beam radiation using the techniques available today gives you an excellent chance for a cure.. Posts.Title: Heading back home

Posts.Content: The slides are maintained by the pathology lab that performed the pathology on your biopsy slides..You paid for them, they are your property. Ask your doctor for the name of the lab that did the pathology on your biopsy slides. Call that lab and ask them to send the slides to the lab requesting them. Get that address from your new doctor. Sometimes, your old doctor will do this for you if you are still on good terms with him..If you have a copy of the original pathology report, all the needed information will be on it....

Posts.Content: It's hard to imagine an internal infection like that staying dormant for 3 years...I too suffered a Lymphocele infected with hospital acquired staph..It manifested itself 2 weeks after my surgery...I had to self-administer IV antibiotics for a month after hospital discharge..I was lucky in that my infection responded to treatment..There are hospital acquired infections now that can not be controlled with ANY antibiotics and are usually fatal. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/01/op...akes.html?_r=0 http://blogs.wsj.com/health/2010/02/...hospital-care/

Posts.Title: Lympocele

Posts.Content: Several studies have shown that when HT is combined with RT, the CURE RATE achieved by the RT, be it primary or salvage, is significantly improved..Some R.O's still dispute this and feel that the side-effects brought on by the HT have such a negative impact on quality of life that the benefit provided by the HT is simply not worth the negative impact....In high risk patients, Gleason 8, 9, 10 with positive margins, the benefit offered by the HT seems to outweigh the side-effect burden and R.O.'s become more insistent about using the combined treatment...

Posts.Title: Firstpost

Posts.Content: Intraductal carcinoma, Gleason 8 is not your garden variety Gleason 6 diagnosis...This is serious business..I have a feeling you will be doing radiation and ADT regardless so why take on the risks and side-effects associated with surgery? The combination of brachy and beam radiation using the techniques available today gives you an excellent chance for a cure.. I know it's a tough choice..You might consult with a Medical Oncologist and get his viewpoints on this matter. They have seen it all and may have some insights you have overlooked....

Posts.Title: ADT-and-radiation-for-first-line-treatment-of-node-positive-n1-prostate-cancer

Posts.Content: When you get a chance, you might benefit from reading Dr. Pat Walsh's book, surviving prostate cancer..Learn what you are dealing with...What was your Gleason score, found on your biopsy report. You are entitled to a copy of that... 10 radiation treatments, that's an unusual number..Most of us get 38-40, one a day, weekends off..Your meds sound like hormone treatment, big side-effect hit coming, but it's effective as your PSA response reflects...Eligard (shot) and Casodex, a little white pill....I suspect you have had some scans aimed at spotting any metastasis and determining how extensive that metastasis is.. The results of these tests will determine what form your treatment will take...If they can get you into a good remission, you have many years left to enjoy...

Posts.Title: Radiation vs Surgery

Posts.Content: When you get a chance, you might benefit from reading Dr. Pat Walsh's book, surviving prostate cancer..Learn what you are dealing with...What was your Gleason score, found on your biopsy report. You are entitled to a copy of that... 10 radiation treatments, that's an unusual number..Most of us get 38-40, one a day, weekends off..Your meds sound like hormone treatment, big side-effect hit coming, but it's effective as your PSA response reflects...Eligard (shot) and Casodex, a little white pill....I suspect you have had some scans aimed at spotting any metastasis and determining how extensive that metastasis is.. The results of these tests will determine what form your treatment will take...If they can get you into a good remission, you have many years left to enjoy...

Posts.Title: Hello

Posts.Content: What was his PSA when they discovered it? Has he had any other treatment other than the ADT (hormone)? Surgery, radiation? Everyone responds differently to treatment so it's difficult to make predictions about the future...There are several new drugs available that work quite well and they won't make his teeth fall out...His current PSA of 0.6 is still very low and if and when it metastasizes to the bones the PSA is usually in the hundreds..His age will play a major role as to what treatments are available to him..What was his Gleason score when he was diagnosed? This number has a lot to do with how quickly the disease will progress...

Posts.Title: Possible progression of prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Julie and her Dad live in the UK where things are a little different..Even in the States, most surgeons daVinci or open, get shy about operating on anyone over 70....The risk of complications and poor outcomes becomes too great..In the UK there are simply not enough LINACS (Linear Accelerators) to provide everyone who might benefit from radiation treatment..

Posts.Title: Possible progression of prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: It depends on how long you were on HT......If the HT treatment is limited to less than 2 years, body hair will slowly return. But at age 70, the process can take longer, if ever.....Much will depend on how long it takes your Testosterone level to climb above 200....

Posts.Title: Does body hair come back after HT ?

Posts.Content: As long as the PSA remains undetectable, Urologists tend to control things..Who gives your Dad the Lupron shots? RO's do their thing and usually step back. They seldom direct or control treatments other than radiation..We pray not, but should your Dad's PSA start to rise in the future, A Medical Oncologist should be the one directing his treatment...Urologists and Oncologists sometimes squabble over this...

Posts.Content: If you want to learn more about prostate cancer, there are several good books available..Dr Patrick Walsh's book, see the sticky at the top of the forum page, will educate you as to how prostate cancer is treated.. We can't offer much help without knowing more details about his case. His age, his PSA and Gleason numbers, things like that..Radiation is seldom used to treat advanced PC but it is sometimes used to treat bone lesions and control bone pain..The usual treatment for PC that has metastasized is Hormone Therapy..

Posts.Content: The RapidArc LINAC will do the job at considerably less cost.. Much depends on your dad's insurance coverage and co-pays..EBRT has a proven track record over many decades..The other two forms of radiation have not yet demonstrated any remarkable advantages and they have not been used long enough to have established a track record in treating prostate cancer..There is a lot of showmanship and salesmanship involved with both...The latest EBRT / IGRT machines like the Varian RapidArc provide greatly improved performance and safety over LINAC's used just a few years ago....

Posts.Title: my husband diagnosed-even with thorough checking

Posts.Content: I suspect there might be some insurance issues going on backstage as Radiation Treatment is VERY expensive..So waiting until October to begin treatment would be understandable...Putting you on HT now will make the radiation more effective, 50% more effective than it otherwise would be..Three years was the old "standard" for adjunct hormone treatment but it has been found that two years and even one year delivers almost the same benefit..Your Radiation Oncologist will discuss this with you..It's a quality of life thing..Three years on HT can be rough and recovering from it at that point is very difficult if not impossible. The changes and damage become permanent...It takes a year before the full effects of the ADT are felt..Start taking your calcium pills to protect your bones and adjust your diet to control the weight gain..Don't let that get away from you...The hot flashes peak at about 6 months then slowly subside....The ED becomes profound but the good news is you will no longer care about it..You sex partner may have a slightly different viewpoint...So when you meet your Radiation Oncologist, you will want to discuss in detail the treatment benefit as opposed to the quality of life impact that Hormone Treatment involves..

Posts.Title: New guy - 46 yo, diagnosed on 8/27

Posts.Content: Proton treatment does have a place treating very small cancers in places that photon radiation has trouble with. When used for treating prostate cancer, no advantage has been demonstrated either in the success rate or the side-effect risk. One thing for certain, it costs MUCH more than traditional photon (X-ray) treatment which is expensive enough already. Most insurance companies will deny proton treatment for prostate cancer because equally effective but much cheaper photon treatment is available... One thing to investigate, it has been demonstrated that the usual 40 fraction treatments can safely be reduced to 25 or so greatly reducing the cost and the stress endured by the patient..If you do your homework you can find the studies and clinical trials that support having fewer treatments...As you might expect, many Radiation Oncologists will resist this change...

Posts.Content: Sounds good! Now, take a couple of weeks off from "cancer" and do something enjoyable..Don't focus on your upcoming surgery and become obsessed by it, just put it behind you and go do something else..On November 2, come on back and we'll tell you what to bring to the hospital and fill you in with all the fun you are going to have with "The Catheter"..But for now, take a break..
Posts.Title: I'm scheduled for open surgery

Posts.Content: It took them three tries to find mine....The trans-rectal biopsy technique can not access the entire prostate gland..The upper back corners are simply out of reach..But SOMETHING is making your PSA rise...There is another biopsy technique called a "saturation biopsy" 40 samples, done in the hospital under general anesthesia..It has access to the entire gland..Also, a few expert Urologists use a different machine, "Color Doppler Ultrasound" to guide the procedure more accurately.. PSA is NOT a marker for cancer, BUT, it does not move from 5.5 to 9.0 for no reason...Urologists get paid a lot of money to discover accurately what that reason is....

Posts.Title: Biopsy clear despite high PSA?

Posts.Content: First, send your biopsy slides out for a second, expert opinion. Dr. Epstein at Johns-Hopkins is the place...Estimated Gleason ? You need to know the ACTUAL Gleason numbers. This is important..If you are indeed a Gleason 7, 3+4, then you have two choices Surgery or radiation. Surgery has not changed much over the past 10 or 12 years but radiation as made big advancements..Better cure rates, fewer side-effects. Look into SBRT also called 'Cyberknife" . Also the combination of beam radiation (IMRT) and brachytherapy (seeds) which delivers a very high cure rate....

Posts.Title: New guy - 46 yo, diagnosed on 8/27

Posts.Content: 7.5% of the men in the United States who are diagnosed with prostate cancer will die from it..That means 92.5% who have been diagnosed with PC will die from something else....You can take the rest of the tables and prediction charts with a grain of salt..65% will be found to have Gleason 6 cancer so they can leave the room right now..Most of the mortality will occur in the 35% still seated, the G7, G8, G9 guys, there are 80,500 of us every year. Our chances of surviving are only 70% not 92%. It is in this group that the 27,000 deaths will come from....So, if you are a G9 you are in a fight for your life and do everything possible to keep that monster under control...With early detection and modern treatments, more men are surviving every year..

AgeInfo.Phrase: G8  G9 guys  there are 80 500 of us every year

Posts.Title: Accuracy of Parton Tables and the like

Posts.Content: The person you want to discuss this with is a RO, radiation oncologist. Not your GP, not your Uro, not a medical oncologist. You might have your GP refer you to a RO however.... Salvage Radiation, done in a timely fashion, can still cure your cancer..Today's LINACS (the machine that delivers the radiation dose) are FAR improved over what they were 10 years or even 5 years ago. The ugly side-effects once common with radiation treatment are virtually a thing of the past.. At 62, your insurance coverage might play a role in your decision making. Radiation treatment can be very expensive so be sure you know where you stand with your insurance before you approve treatment....

Posts.Title: Got the news yesterday, what now?

Posts.Content: If you are a veteran, served in the military, they will, in all likelihood take care of you..Failing that, get in touch with your states Medicaid office. Also, The Affordable Healthcare Act is still in force. You CAN buy health insurance with no preexisting condition restrictions. If you are of limited means, the cost should be reasonable..You must be getting pretty close to 65 years when Medicare will kick in. You need a to find a way to bridge that gap..Casodex has a generic counterpart, Bicalutamide, which is not very expensive. This Foundation will provide FREE Lupron if you meet certain terms..Usually these terms are quite liberal. There are more organizations out there that can and will help.. https://www.pparx.org/prescription_a..._lupaneta_pack Typically, they will see how Lupron alone works..Most men get a good response..When it starts to fail they will add the bicalutamide and the combined drugs usually result in another remission..Hopefully, you will now be covered under Medicare when you become "hormone refractory" (the drugs stop working) and you can move on to Zytiga or Xtandi which can produce a dramatic responce and another prolonged remission... So make a few phone calls and you will get what you need....

Posts.Title: Tough statement from my Doctor, Realistic?

Posts.Content: Recovery from surgery is usually a piece of cake..Dealing with the catheter for a week or 10 days is a pain, but you get to sleep all night! Get all the catheter supplies from the hospital that you can..Big bag, leg bag, extra straps...Bring a loose-fitting pair of sweat pants to come home in...Then, walk as much as your surgeon will allow, which is usually unlimited..Walking helps get everything working again..Most guys have little pain or discomfort after the first day or two..Maybe some left-over nausea from the anesthesia..Ginger ale (Canada Dry) and some liquid diet stuff can be handy if he has little appetite..

Posts.Title: New to PC club

Posts.Content: At this point, your Urologist is still your lead doctor..You do not need the services of a Medical Oncologist at this time...A consultation will not hurt, but it should be centered on when to start radiation treatment (salvage radiation) should your PSA start to climb. The person you might want to talk to would be a Radiation Oncologist...Sometimes, depending on all the numbers, Gleason 9 patients get a round of adjunct radiation treatment just as insurance against a relapse..

Posts.Title: A little confused about nerve sparing. What is the criteria?

Posts.Content: It took them three tries to find mine....The trans-rectal biopsy technique can not access the entire prostate gland..The upper back corners are simply out of reach..But SOMETHING is making your PSA rise...There is another biopsy technique called a "saturation biopsy" 40 samples, done in the hospital under general anesthesia..It has access to the entire gland..Also, a few expert Urologists use a different machine, "Color Doppler Ultrasound" to guide the procedure more accurately.. PSA is NOT a marker for cancer, BUT, it does not move from 5.5 to 9.0 for no reason...Urologists get paid a lot of money to discover accurately what that reason is....

Posts.Title: New to site and PC

Posts.Content: You might be jumping the gun on the Zytiga..There are rules that must be followed before your insurance will pay for it..Generally speaking, the Lupron and Casodex combination must stop working before your doctor can prescribe it..Your PSA is virtually undetectable, I would wait for a couple of increases before I started salvage radiation...But the Lupron will mask that, your PSA will probably drop to zero (undetectable) so the need for radiation will be impossible to determine.. It is impossible to predict your mortality..It will be at least 2 years before it can be determined if you are cured or not..With prostate cancer, every case is different. Every case responds differently to treatment. New drugs, treatments and techniques are coming online rapidly making the future impossible to predict.

Posts.Title: New to forum

Posts.Content: There are dozens of products like TBL-12 (sea cucumber extract) that claim to cure cancer...Save your money and stick with treatments that been proven to work... Two books for you to read. Surviving prostate cancer by Dr. Pat Walsh and Winning the battle against prostate cancer by Dr. Gerald Chodak. This will give you the background information you need to make an intelligent treatment choice..

Posts.Title: Preemptive Prostate Removal?

Posts.Content: When to start Rt/HT after surgery is a real balancing act...The radiation will stop the recovery from surgery right where it is..So if your continence is improving, they like to wait until you are dry. No sense inflicting you with a lifetime of incontinence if it can be avoided..Will this slight delay have an impact on your survival chances? Hard to say.... As in your case, HT usually has a dramatic impact in prostate cancer, dropping the PSA to undetectable in many cases..Unfortunately, its effect does not last forever, but it can last for a good many years, especially when combined with other treatments...

Posts.Title: Delaying RT after surgery may of worse outcomes then doing it ASAP

Posts.Content: The person you want to discuss this with is a RO, radiation oncologist. Not your GP, not your Uro, not a medical oncologist. You might have your GP refer you to a RO however.... Salvage Radiation, done in a timely fashion, can still cure your cancer..Today's LINACS (the machine that delivers the radiation dose) are FAR improved over what they were 10 years or even 5 years ago. The ugly side-effects once common with radiation treatment are virtually a thing of the past.. At 62, your insurance coverage might play a role in your decision making. Radiation treatment can be very expensive so be sure you know where you stand with your insurance before you approve treatment....

Posts.Title: 76 wth ED and PSA of 65

Posts.Content: " how important is the tumor volume as reported in the biopsy? " Not that important as needle biopsies are somewhat notorious for missing the overall picture. The only way to know that FOR SURE is to remove the prostate gland and biopsy the whole thing... But your low PSA and small amount of cancer found points to successful treatment no matter which path you follow...

Posts.Title: Tumor volume and treatment

Posts.Content: What is strange is to have a PSA of 1.0 but still have extensive G-9 cancer....That happens sometimes, some variants of PC produce very little PSA....You may have caught it early enough so a cure is still possible...Along with the Uro, talk with a Medical Oncologist and a Radiation Oncologist and get their viewpoints....Your life is on the line here so do your homework carefully...

Posts.Title: Lupron & Casodex Discontinuance?

Posts.Content: You need to treat this...At your age, I would think RT, radiation, would be your best option if your bone scan is still clean...Also, you RO (radiation oncologist) will probably want to include a period of Hormone Therapy, (ADT) which makes the radiation more effective..You could start that NOW to stop the cancer from spreading and prepare yourself for the RT... Radiation treatment, using modern equipment and the latest treatment techniques has come a long ways from where it was just 10 years ago..More effective, fewer side-effects.

Posts.Title: New to PC club

Posts.Content: Calm down, you are going to be fine ! With a PSA of 5, your scans will probably be clean..That means your treatment team can go for a CURE..That's right, CURE..At 71, surgery is pretty risky so that leaves some form of radiation treatment, which is just as effective but with fewer potential side-effects..The Gleason 9 puts you the high-risk group so you can expect aggressive treatment to be recommended..Is the Grim Reaper just a step behind you ?? NO !! With today's treatments and drugs with more coming soon, they can CURE you or worst case, keep you going for another 8 or 10 years...So enjoy the weekend and stop worrying about things you can't do anything about.. At some point you will want to have a discussion with a Radiation Oncologist. Your Uro should refer you to one but if not, find one on your own...Best Of Luck To You ..

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed with stage III T3C

Posts.Content: A second opinion becomes critical if the biopsy report finds Gleason 6 in a very small percentage of the sampled tissue..This can be tricky and there is no margin for error...However, if Gleason grades 4 or 5 are found as a substantial percentage, virtually any pathology lab should have the skills to deliver a correct report. Minor differences between labs will not alter your treatment one way or the other..Same goes for a negative finding..If your report comes back clean, the chances of an expert lab contradicting that are very small...Best of luck on your upcoming report!

Posts.Title: UWM @ Madison, Wi

Posts.Content: Calm down, you are going to be fine ! With a PSA of 5, your scans will probably be clean..That means your treatment team can go for a CURE..That's right, CURE..At 71, surgery is pretty risky so that leaves some form of radiation treatment, which is just as effective but with fewer potential side-effects..The Gleason 9 puts you the high-risk group so you can expect aggressive treatment to be recommended..Is the Grim Reaper just a step behind you ?? NO !! With today's treatments and drugs with more coming soon, they can CURE you or worst case, keep you going for another 8 or 10 years...So enjoy the weekend and stop worrying about things you can't do anything about.. At some point you will want to have a discussion with a Radiation Oncologist. Your Uro should refer you to one but if not, find one on your own...Best Of Luck To You ..

Posts.Content: Calm Down!!! His post op PSA is undetectable, he has no metastasized cancer spreading anywhere! You need to see three consecutive increases in PSA before you even think about secondary treatment..It can take 6 months to regain continence after surgery..Radiation stops the healing process right where it is, so you want to wait as long as possible before you start it..I'm surprised they put him on hormones with a PSA of 0.01.......A positive margin does NOT necessarily mean the cancer has spread...These "he said, she said" posts are usually full of inaccurate information..How old is your dad?

Posts.Title: Getting Biopsy in Two Weeks

Posts.Content: All kinds of things go on backstage in cases like this....But first and foremost, this question must be answered: Will performing a radical prostatectomy on your father extend his survival AT ALL?? Unfortunately, the answer to this is probably not. Once PC has metastasized to the bones, going back and removing the primary tumor has not proven to be effective treatment..Another factor, because this would be considered high-risk surgery (because of his age and the extent of his cancer) few surgeons would be willing participants as the risks involved outweigh any possible benefits delivered....You can also expect your insurance company to balk (yes, even Medicare) because they would judge it to be inappropriate treatment.... You might have a better chance of getting radiation treatment (consult with a Radiation Oncologist) approved because it's less risky and it MIGHT provide a worthwhile extension of his survival, especially if you could convince the providers and the insurance company that you wanted to work outside the box and try a combination of the newer treatments available. Treating the bone mets with Xofigo might be worth a try... Xtandi is another new drug that in some men has had spectacular results...Don't overlook clinical trials as a way to receive advanced treatment at no cost....It all depends on how hard you and Dad want to fight this thing...But Stage 4 terminal cancer is what it is....At some point you must face this and deal with it.. Best of luck to you both.....

Posts.Title: Why not remove the prostate in the case of Stage 4 PCA

Posts.Content: A PSA of 17 can not be explained by BPH unless the gland is truly huge..But there ARE cases of elevated PSA, elevated into the hundreds, where multiple biopsies, saturation biopsies, can not find any cancer...NotPretty, your case is troubling because of the rapid rise over a short period of time..That's called PSA velocity. Your visit with a Urologist will almost certainly lead to a biopsy...

Posts.Title: cancer vs inflamed/infected prostate

Posts.Content: Casodex and Lupron do pretty much the same thing..Chemical castration..When used together, the effect is sometimes enhanced. They should be monitoring his "T" or testosterone level. It should be below 20 and below 10 is even better for maximum effectiveness in suppressing his prostate cancer. Do you remember his Gleason score when he was diagnosed? It is normal for HT to stop working after a period of time..Traditional Chemo has not proven to be very effective against PC, especially when you consider it's side-effects. At age 79, side-effects can be just as fatal as the cancer. There are some new drugs that have just been approved and are fairly effective. Pomegranate juice or extract pills and even low-dose aspirin seen to slow down the progression too...If the bone mets can be located, they can be treated with spot radiation..

Posts.Content: The biopsy itself is no big deal, it's over in 15 minutes. The aftermath can be a little disconcerting, blood in the urine and more so in the semen..It's a good idea to purge your semen yourself before you have sex with a partner..Your back end will be tender for a few days, maybe some blood there too. Get off any blood thinners like aspirin or fish oil. Your Uro should have given you a list of things to avoid. That's very important.. Best of luck to you!

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Pratoman is correct....Survival with prostate cancer is very unpredictable..The term "Average survival time" simply means half the studied group of men died sooner and half died later...With todays new treatments, many men are moving into the "later" category as overall survival rates slowly improve. Your Dad's treatment is very up to date..Starting the docetaxel early, along with the ADT, right at the beginning, has been found to deliver a much better response than delivered by either treatment alone..This is a brand new technique.
Posts.Title: Why not remove the prostate in the case of Stage 4 PCA

Posts.Content: Step one would be a biopsy if not already done..How old is Dad? In any case "Hormone Treatment" will be prescribed which will control the cancer while they evaluate his overall condition and develop a treatment plan..

Posts.Title: Psa 300+

Posts.Content: Once you have been diagnosed with PC, the roll of the PSA test changes. It is used to judge how effective the treatment is and how fast the cancer is progressing. You should know that some forms of PC, especially the most aggressive forms, do not make much PSA and therefore PSA is not as useful in determining cancer progression....A yardstick to watch, what is his PSA now and what it is 3 months after the start of HT.......

Posts.Content: Read Dr. Walsh's book, (see the sticky at the top of the forum) to get a complete understanding of what's going on..The surgery itself is the easiest part of the whole thing because you will have no memory of it..You go to sleep, you wake up, it's over...next day, you go home..Bring a pair of baggy sweat pants to go home in. Posts.Title: Why not remove the prostate in the case of Stage 4 PCA

Posts.Content: A PSA of 17 can not be explained by BPH unless the gland is truly huge..But there ARE cases of elevated PSA, elevated into the hundreds, where multiple biopsies, saturation biopsies, can not find any cancer...NotPretty, your case is troubling because of the rapid rise over a short period of time..That's called PSA velocity. Your visit with a Urologist will almost certainly lead to a biopsy...

Posts.Title: cancer vs inflamed/infected prostate

Posts.Content: There are several new treatments and drugs available that were not available 7 years ago...Provenge might give better results than chemo..As to survival, that's a difficult question...One yardstick that has been used in the past, once PC is detected in the bones, the AVERAGE survival is about 3 years..At the 10 year mark, 90% will have passed...But in your husbands case, no bone mets have been detected yet, correct? If so, then that yardstick may not apply to him... As far as how PC gets treated, much depends on his age, overall health, cost issues, tolerance to side-effects, PSA level and velocity..You will know a lot more after your visit with an oncologist....

Posts.Title: What to Do about Conflicting Advice

Posts.Content: Exactly how doctors are paid is not discussed very much...Some are simply employees of a hospital or a medical services company.. Others are private contractors, granted permission to provide services in hospitals but billing separately.. As for referrals, I've never been sure if there is a "finders fee" passed back to the referring physician.. But a 40 treatment run on an IMRT LINAC, what a bonanza that is..They are going to milk that cow as hard as they can..In Denver, everyone tried to get on the gravy-train all at the same time, resulting in a big surplus of LINAC equipment looking for patients to treat..

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Zytiga or Xtandi will probably be next. They can be very effective...They are very expensive but there are "foundations" that will step in and cover the part that's not covered by insurance if need be....
Posts.Title: First Injection with Xofigo

Posts.Content: Have your testosterone level checked to be sure the Trelstar is working as advertised. It should (must) be below 20 and hopefully below 10. If that checks out, Consult with a Medical Oncologist about moving from Casodex to Zytiga or Xtandi (Your Uro's job is done) as these newer drugs are more effective.. At some point, chemo will come into the picture. It has been found the sooner you start this, the better it works...

Posts.Title: BCR after a year on ADT

Posts.Content: Of all the men diagnosed with Prostate Cancer, only 7% of them die from it. The other 93% die from something other than prostate cancer..There is almost NO mortality in the Gleason 6 group which makes up 60-65 percent of all cases diagnosed..Most of the prostate cancer deaths occur in the Gleason 8, 9 and 10 high risk group...So...You have plenty of time to make a treatment decision and as has been mentioned, all the available treatments are equally effective at delivering a cure...

Posts.Content: The Third Edition of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book "Guide To Surviving Prostate Cancer", is now available. The second edition published in 2007 , was in need of being updated and the newest edition brings the book up to date.. When it comes to the diagnosis and treatment of Prostate Cancer, this book is considered "The Bible" by many.. While the Second Edition contains most of the same information, with the Third Edition available, booksellers should be discounting their stock of the older book...

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer doctor

Posts.Content: There are several factors to consider..His age, and the fact that Gleason 10 prostate cancer tends to be terminal in a year or two if left untreated. 70% of PC victims have Gleason 6 or 7 cancers that behave MUCH differently than Gleason 9 & 10 do....Most of what you will find on the internet is aimed at that 70% with less aggressive cancers...Aggressive treatment can extend your Dad's life for many years..The only real question is how well he can tolerate the side-effects of such treatment...Radiation, administered by an expert Radiation Oncologist, usually has very moderate side-effects.. The so-called "hormone treatment" while very effective at controlling the cancer, also has a full plate of side-effects but they can be dealt with too....The sooner the HT is started, the better as it will quickly stop the progression of the cancer and make the upcoming RT more effective..

This could be a revolutionary development for stage 4 guys who have become hormone refractory...Google it.... A side benefit is it's cheap..A shot of testosterone runs $20-$30, not $8000 like Zytiga and Xtandi....

Posts.Title: PSA of 22.39

Posts.Content: The chaarted study (google it) supports the findings your oncologist is talking about....BUT, your PSA is currently undetectable and your lifestyle is still half-way decent, right? Chemo means 3 or 4 months of going through hell, your summer is shot....I should mention that administering Chemo is a Gold Mine for the facility that performs the procedure...So the choice is up to YOU....Go for the possible improvement in your survival time or preserve the the quality of life you have now.......It can be a tough choice...One more thing, be sure to find out what your co-pays will be, you don't want to be blindsided by big medical bills....

Posts.Title: PSA .7 DRE showed Mass

Posts.Content: This question has been researched at length. Biopsies leave needle tracks in the prostate gland. When cancer is found and the gland surgically removed, a close examination of those needle tracks never finds any cancer in them..The needles come out clean. The same holds true for the numerous other types of cancer that needle biopsies are used to detect and verify..Cancer spreads to other parts of the body when metastasis occurs, not from needle biopsies..

Posts.Title: PSA of 22.39

Posts.Content: Your PSA should have dropped to zero after surgery with no help from the HT..It did not...So....There is cancer someplace. it will be hard to find with the HT suppressing it. I would ask about stopping the HT and monitoring your PSA and see if it comes back quickly. If so, one of the new sensitive scans might be able to spot the exact location of your cancer so the R.O. can target it..From here on I would let your Oncologist take over the roll of directing your treatment..You will discover that Urologists and Oncologists compete with each other when it comes to treating prostate cancer patients but since your surgery failed to cure you, your urologist is working outside his area of expertise. By professional courtesy, he may continue to administer your Lupron shots which are very profitable and easy money....But I would let the Oncologist call the shots....I am not a doctor and this is just my opinion....

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: The chaarted study (google it) supports the findings your oncologist is talking about....BUT, your PSA is currently undetectable and your lifestyle is still half-way decent, right? Chemo means 3 or 4 months of going through hell, your summer is shot....I should mention that administering Chemo is a Gold Mine for the facility that performs the procedure...So the choice is up to YOU....Go for the possible improvement in your survival time or preserve the the quality of life you have now.......It can be a tough choice...One more thing, be sure to find out what your co-pays will be, you don't want to be blindsided by big medical bills....

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: The PSA of 55 is not good...But if the scans come back clean he can still be cured, it's not hopeless....His treatment path and prognosis will be determined by a detailed analysis of his biopsy report and the results of those scans...Read Dr. Walsh's book and get ready for a heck of a fight.... I would at least consult with a Medical Oncologist at this point just to get his opinion and viewpoints. Your Urologist may not agree, so get the referral from your primary care physician. Bring your copy of the biopsy report with you...

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: The procedure and drugs used and their dosages should be published and all Oncologists with stage 4 terminal prostate cancer patients should be encouraged to try this treatment procedure NOW...Why wait for the stage 2 and then stage 3 trials to be concluded..We are not evaluating a new drug here. If the treatment works on the majority of the men in the trials now, that's good enough..The drug used, a synthetic form of testosterone taken by hundreds of thousands of men who feel they have "low T" is now a generic and it's safety is not an issue..The men this treatment is aimed at are those who have been on ADT and that treatment has failed or has begun to fail...This group of men have pretty much run out of treatment choices, they have nothing to lose by trying this new approach to Hormone Treatment....Waiting for years for a series of studies to be completed and the results analyzed in fine detail is fine but it's NOT a reason to withhold this treatment from tens of thousands of men who might benefit from it greatly NOW......

Posts.Title: New to Forum: Anyone esle taking Erleada?

Posts.Content: Welcome Omegaman...You have already been given lots of good info...As you research your treatment options, keep in mind that the apex is a difficult spot for a surgeon no matter what method of surgery he is using..Aggressive surgery here can result in incontinence as the urinary sphincter is close by..The BEST surgeons can deal with this so chose your surgeon carefully...I would also consult with a Radiation Oncologist and perhaps a Medical Oncologist to get their viewpoints..Be aware that these specialists will try and sell and promote their method of treatment but you should hear what they have to say... At age 50 surgery will probably be the favored treatment, but not always. Radiation has made great improvements lately..Also, investigate how much of this your health insurance is going to cover..Better to know these things beforehand and not get blindsided with a huge bill...Best of luck to you...And yes, read Dr. Walsh's book...

Posts.Title: New to this: clinical T2 prostate cancer Gleason 3+4 = 7/10 and 3+3 = 6/10

Posts.Content: Once you have been diagnosed with PC, the roll of the PSA test changes. It is used to judge how effective the treatment is and how fast the cancer is progressing. You should know that some forms of PC, especially the most aggressive forms, do not make much PSA and therefore PSA is not as useful in determining cancer progression....A yardstick to watch, what is his PSA now and what it is 3 months after the start of HT.......

Posts.Content: This procedure is under clinical trial at Johns-Hopkins right now...They are getting excellent results..It's called "BAT" Bipolar Androgen Therapy.. This could be a revolutionary development for stage 4 guys who have become hormone refractory...Google it.... A side benefit is it's cheap..A shot of testosterone runs $20-$30, not $8000 like Zytiga and Xtandi....

Posts.Title: diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 41

Posts.Content: Enzo, trade name Xtandi, has been on the market for a number of years. Yes, it can be very effective at extending the lives of those with aggressive, advanced, prostate cancer for a period of time but it seldom produces a durable remission. Claiming it "saved the lives" of 70% of PC victims is stretching it a bit....The newspaper article makes it sound like enzalutamide, is a new, breakthrough drug. It is not...

Posts.Title: hope for high risk

Posts.Content: I suspected you lived in the UK when I read your first post...Radiation treatment is costly and time consuming..There may not be enough treatment slots open for everyone desiring treatment...So a group of doctors and NHS administrators will decide where the available LINAC time will do the most good...The squeaky hinge gets the oil....If all the local radiation machines are booked up, perhaps your dad could travel to a location with some unused treatment slots..In the States, a 40 treatment, 72 Gray treatment protocol costs around $100K dollars...There are enough LINACs available so that if you have the money or insurance there is no waiting for treatment.....

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with enlarged prostate

Posts.Content: Persistent PSA after treatment is never good but PSA velocity is perhaps more important..I would not get too excited until it hit say 3.0 Then you KNOW your treatment failed and it's time to move on to systemic forms of treatment..That's when you say goodby to the Urologist and let a Medical Oncologist take over responsibility for your treatment...Actually, that's not right either..YOU are the one who is responsible for the path your treatment will take....The doctors will all recommend the treatment that they provide.....The next step for you will be hormone therapy if the PSA continues to rise. When you start that treatment is up to you...

Posts.Title: Had Prostatechtomy & Radiation, but PSA still climbing

Posts.Content: Yes, radiation is in your future...As you know, the question is when... Radiation will stop the healing process right where it is, any lingering Incontinence and impotence will be locked in...So it's a balancing act..The sooner you start, the better the chance for a cure..But quality of life is important, especially incontinence, it's up to you to decide..Combining radiation with ADT (hormone) therapy improves outcomes by a big percentage. You can start the ADT anytime, which will control the cancer while you are waiting to heal...Talk to your RO about that...
