Posts.Title: Daddys PSA results and HT question :)

Posts.Content: A biopsy will be needed to determine the Gleason score...I would insist on a biopsy.....Castration IS hormone therapy..Drugs can be used to achieve the same end, but they are expensive and don't work as well as castration.. Before your Dad submits to castration, it must be verified by a biopsy that he actually has prostate cancer..
Posts.Title: Psa 300+

Posts.Content: I would carefully and truthfully tell the urologist about ALL your urinary problems..He may do an exam of your urinary track using a 'scope (it's not as bad as it sounds) which will allow him to see exactly what is going on all the way up into your bladder..When a 26 year old has a PSA of 10.1 there has to be a reason. Let the urologist determine what that reason is..There ARE cases of men with high PSA readings, much higher than yours, that have had multiple biopsies over a period of years and no cancer can be found...These are unusual but doctors have no explanation for them.. Good Luck and let us know how you make out...

Posts.Title: Digital Rectal Exam Question

Posts.Content: The procedure and drugs used and their dosages should be published and all Oncologists with stage 4 terminal prostate cancer patients should be encouraged to try this treatment procedure NOW...Why wait for the stage 2 and then stage 3 trials to be concluded..We are not evaluating a new drug here. If the treatment works on the majority of the men in the trials now, that's good enough..The drug used, a synthetic form of testosterone taken by hundreds of thousands of men who feel they have "low T" is now a generic and it's safety is not an issue..The men this treatment is aimed at are those who have been on ADT and that treatment has failed or has begun to fail...This group of men have pretty much run out of treatment choices, they have nothing to lose by trying this new approach to Hormone Treatment....Waiting for years for a series of studies to be completed and the results analyzed in fine detail is fine but it's NOT a reason to withhold this treatment from tens of thousands of men who might benefit from it greatly NOW......

Posts.Title: Zero Club Membership Renewed - SRT Question

Posts.Content: "show that the aggressiveness of a prostate tumor could be established at the time of tumor formation." This is not exactly a new discovery..Dr. Walsh, in his popular book, has suspected this for a long time..When a cancerous prostate gland is removed and biopsied, on average, there are 7 distinct and separate tumors..They can be grade 3, 4 or 5 or a mix of the three grades all in the same gland..Many feel it is rare for a Gleason 6 (3+3) to mutate into a more aggressive grade tumor. What is more likely, there was an undiscovered tumor of higher grade hidden in the prostate all along... If a cancer is not discovered very early, the more aggressive tumors can spread and overwhelm the less aggressive cells, merging into one mass of high-grade tumor cells....This does not mean the Gleason 6 cancer turned into a Gleason 9 cancer..It means the G-9 tumor, undetected at first, overwhelmed the nearby G-6 tumor.... Those on AS, Active Surveillance, should have annual biopsies to be sure this progression is not occurring....When G-6 patients choose to have surgery, 30% of the time when the pathology report comes back, more aggressive cancer is found that the original biopsy missed...

Posts.Title: Happy Dance for HT Holiday

Posts.Content: Gleason 9 puts you in the high risk group....Studies have shown that when RT is combined with a 2 or 3 year period of hormone treatment the cure rate is considerably better..Even just 1 year on HT results in improved outcomes...At the moment, the Lupron has reduced your PSA to undetectable. I have gone through the same thing thing you are going through, only I had surgery (failed) before the radiation and HT. After 18 months on HT I said no more.....I was in the zero club (undetectable PSA) and thought I was cured. Six months later my zero club membership was revoked and it was back on Lupron and Casodex, probably for the rest of my life... Your "T" level is still 23.7 which is not ideal for fighting PC..It should be below 20 and below 10 is even better. If you choose to stop HT then it's not an issue but if you continue, you might ask about a different drug which might give better testosterone suppression.. Your case is different because you still have a prostate gland. So you can expect your PSA to become measurable when you stop the HT. If your RT was successful, your PSA should level off at some low figure called "nadir". But if your PSA resumes a steady climb then it's back on HT forever..

Posts.Title: Happy Dance for HT Holiday

Posts.Content: I would wait a month and have another test..If it returns 0.3 or something in that neighborhood, then it's time to see a Radiation Oncologist..Be as careful choosing one as you were your surgeon..Be sure he or she will be using the latest LINAC, the machine that delivers the radiation dose....The LINACS have made big improvements over the last 7 or 8 years... The typical dose is around 75 Gray given in 40 fractions...That's 40 trips to the treatment center. Side-effects from radiation (today) are usually minimal..Wherever he stands now with impotence and incontinence, that's where he will stay..The radiation sort of freezes things where they are....

Posts.Content: Has his Onco tried adding Casodex (bicalutamide) along with the Firmagone? Sometimes a good response can be had by adding this inexpensive drug..A supplement called "Pomi-T" can't hurt anything...Make sure his testosterone levels are truly at "castrate level".. Chemo, seldom used on prostate cancer in the past, today it's being used in various combinations more frequently and getting worthwhile results...

Posts.Title: Gleason score was 9 in April 2013. Had radiation and Lupron injections

Posts.Content: " It has metastasized to the ribs/lymph nodes/spine/bladder but after the last scans it shows most of those areas are clear/smaller. I just don't understand why he is still so very sick if things have shown improvement. " It is probably the Xtandi that is controlling his cancer now...It has a low side effect risk..Perhaps some of the other 14 drugs he is taking are interacting and making him feel terrible...You should find out if some or most of them can be removed from his pill box... The big immunotherapy breakthrough being worked by Dr. Ronald Levy at Stanford University has moved on to human trials on Leukemia patients..It uses a minute dose of already FDA approved (and off patent) compounds injected directly into cancer tumors. This seems to teach the "T" cells already in the tumor that the tumor cells are foreign material and the T-cells mount a vigorous attack on those cells. Not only that, as the newly activated T-cells circulate in the bloodstream, they seek out and attack any mets they find while leaving healthy cells alone. In 90% of the lab rats, this resulted in a CURE, not just a remission. All this is great news for lab rats, now, will it hold true for humans also.......??

Posts.Title: What is running like after radical prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: The machines that deliver radiation treatment are called LINAC's, Linear Accelerators, and they come in different flavors. The newest models are greatly improved over those produced 10 years ago..I would find out how old the equipment available in your town is...Some locations, like Denver, are awash in the newest equipment and getting time on one is no problem..

Posts.Title: 1st PSA 3 months post RALP = 0.3. What to do?

Posts.Content: Remember this..All the specialists will recommend whatever treatment they perform...Business is business..To me, and I could be wrong, when they need to implant the gold markets, they are using an older LINAC (the machine that administers the radiation). The newest equipment no longer needs the markers to accurately aim the beam....Also, today, brachytherapy, seeds, have made big improvements especially when combined with beam radiation. The two used in conjunction can deliver the highest overall dose while maintaining lower side-effect risk..If your RO is shy about Brachytherapy, it's probably because he does not perform the procedure..I would locate and consult with an RO who does perform it AND IS EXPERT AT IT.... One more thing to investigate..Radiation treatment is very expensive. Always get preapprovals from your insurance company. Find out what your payment responsibility will be before you agree to any treatment.....Best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: Prostate 3T MRI exam

Posts.Content: With G9 and a positive margin, hormone and radiation are pretty much standard...But since his PSA rise is very slow, and the side-effects from HT & RT can be pretty rugged, I don't think there is much to be gained by rushing into secondary treatment..But I'm not a doctor.....Some doctors feel "hit it as hard as you can as soon as you can with everything you have" is the best course of action...Using the ultra-sensitive test can create a lot of "PSA Anxiety"...The numbers just bounce around too much...Chances are, no further treatment will begin until he hits 0.1 using the standard test, so many docs just use the standard measurement to begin with...Using that yardstick, your dad's PSA is undetectable..

Posts.Title: rising psa

Posts.Content: You have metastasized Gleason 9 cancer..Radiation may still be able to play a role here and maybe not..But either way, you are going on ADT, probably for the rest of your life....If you choose not to treat it and let Nature take its course, that journey will not be very long....I have a similar case history and have used every tool available to me to extend my survival..So far, the wonderful doctors have kept me going for 8 years. Has it been a fun ride ?? Heck no but I've dealt with the side-effects and I'm still enjoying life...

Posts.Title: Should I do a Prostate Biopsy ? are my chances for recovery better if diagnosed early

Posts.Content: Salvage radiation treatment (SRT) is effective about 50% of the time...That's just the way it is..But radiation treatment takes time to work..It does not kill cancer cells directly. It prevents them from reproducing and multiplying.. So before the PSA starts dropping, the existing cancer cells have to die of old age..It can take up to a year and a half before you reach "nadir" , the low point at which PSA stabilizes..During this period, if the treatment was successful, you should see a slow, steady decline in PSA levels.. The best of luck to you...

But overall number of cases is still lower...

Posts.Title: PSA following prostrate surgery and radiation therapy

Posts.Content: Surgery is NOT your only option...If 17 of 20 cores revealed Gleason 9 cancer, then Salvage Radiation is a very high probability. Have you had a long talk with a Radiation Oncologist?? If surgery only gives you a 50% chance of a cure, why mess with it? Demand your surgeon talk straight with you..You DO have other options...Brachytherapy (seeds) combined with IGRT is an option you should consider...Gleason 9 means you are in a fight for your life and you have to get it right the first time...Do your homework... Having said that, I will also say this: By removing (surgery) the cancerous prostate gland, you will be removing a large, perhaps 100%, of the cancer in your body. You will have a complete pathology of the gland. Any necessary followup treatment will be dealing with a greatly reduced tumor burden as the main tumor is GONE...There are lots of things to consider....

Posts.Title: pre opp prostate

Posts.Content: With Urologists, 2 weeks is the normal wait for a biopsy so 3 weeks, especially in the summer, is not too bad.. A PSA of 118 is never good news....Prostate cancer is not guaranteed but it's highly likely..While you are waiting, read Dr. Walsh's book, Surviving Prostate Cancer..Hopefully you won't need the information it contains but at least you will know how this game is played.. Depending on your medical insurance, you could shop around among the local Urologists and maybe find one who can see you sooner..Best of luck to you..

Posts.Title: symptoms then psa

Posts.Content: With G9 and a positive margin, hormone and radiation are pretty much standard...But since his PSA rise is very slow, and the side-effects from HT & RT can be pretty rugged, I don't think there is much to be gained by rushing into secondary treatment..But I'm not a doctor.....Some doctors feel "hit it as hard as you can as soon as you can with everything you have" is the best course of action...Using the ultra-sensitive test can create a lot of "PSA Anxiety"...The numbers just bounce around too much...Chances are, no further treatment will begin until he hits 0.1 using the standard test, so many docs just use the standard measurement to begin with...Using that yardstick, your dad's PSA is undetectable..

Posts.Title: PSA of 0.28 2yrs. after Prostrate removal

Posts.Content: Just a few years ago, there were only 4 or 5 Proton Machines in the country and they were not used for prostate cancer salvage treatments. The facilities that owned these machines started promoting them (you witnessed some of that) as being suitable for a much wider range of cancer treatment in order to keep the machines busy in order to defray the extremely high cost of building one.. Recently, many more large hospitals and treatment centers have jumped on the bandwagon and "invested" in a Proton treatment machine. These Cyclotrons cost over $150 million to build....So keeping them busy 12 to 18 hours a day is important..The advantage in using one of these machines for prostate cancer salvage radiation has yet to be demonstrated. The latest generation of LIMACS, Linear Accelerators, the machines that administer IGRT and IMRT are MUCH improved over those in use just a few years ago so the radiation horror stories are not heard much anymore..They are more suitable in administering radiation over a wider area (prostate bed) than the "pencil beam" proton machines are... You need to be careful when navigating in these waters as SERIOUS money is on the table here. $130,000 for IMRT and $200K and up for a series of proton treatments..Do your homework...

Posts.Title: Proton vs IMRT for Salvage treatment?

Posts.Content: Urologists try to hang onto their cancer patients for too long....As soon as it becomes apparent that the surgery has failed to cure the cancer, a Medical Oncologist should take over the lead position in determining treatment going forward...
Posts.Title: Proton vs IMRT for Salvage treatment?

Posts.Content: The "Cyber Knife" system uses a small LINAC, Linear Accelerator mounted on a robotic gantry. It can deliver a small radiation beam with great accuracy..It excels at treating very small cancers in difficult places.. But for prostate cancer, a fairly large area is targeted deep inside the body and a conventional LINAC is perhaps better suited to provide this treatment..The newest LINACS such as the Varian Rapid Arc use a computer controlled beam guided by a realtime CAT scan to provide effective treatment while minimizing exposure to healthy tissue.. Radiation treatment is VERY expensive, the machines that perform it (LINACS) are very expensive and competition for patients is keen...Radiation Oncologists are among the highest paid medical specialists. This all adds up to patients seeing some high-pressure salesmanship as they make their treatment decisions...

Posts.Title: Wondering about Cyber Knife

Posts.Content: Welcome to the other side njs... Very, very few of us can travel around the country visiting with world renowned doctors and institutions before we make our treatment decisions..We find out what our insurance will pay for, who is on the approved list, do a little research and choose a local surgeon or oncologist to treat us..Even a Cow Town like Denver where I live offers some truly outstanding treatment choices...They may not publish books or research papers but they get the job done... In your first post, you used the term "Successful Surgery" when you are 2 weeks post surgery..And with your G-6 cancer, you like 90% of the men with similar numbers as yours enjoy "Successful Surgery", their PC cured never to return..There are three key milestones you must pass first..The 8 week PSA test comes back undetectable, the two year test comes back the same way as does the five year test....THEN you can break out the Champagne and we will all drink a rousing toast to your good fortune..But until then, sure, ride along with us and help the new guys, terrified and afraid, unsure what awaits them on this unsure journey...

Posts.Content: Chief, consider Johns advise carefully...There is NO SENSE in undergoing BOTH surgery AND radiation...Choose the treatment that offers the BEST CHANCE of producing a CURE...It is very hard to justify doing surgery when even the surgeon expects radiation will be needed to finish the job....Laying radiation on top of surgery really compounds the side-effect issues..It is the skill of your doctors that will determine your outcome, so choose them carefully..Best of luck to you..

Posts.Title: This sure is happening fast!

Posts.Content: Salvage radiation treatment (SRT) is effective about 50% of the time...That's just the way it is..But radiation treatment takes time to work..It does not kill cancer cells directly. It prevents them from reproducing and multiplying.. So before the PSA starts dropping, the existing cancer cells have to die of old age..It can take up to a year and a half before you reach "nadir" , the low point at which PSA stabilizes..During this period, if the treatment was successful, you should see a slow, steady decline in PSA levels.. The best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: PSA following prostrate surgery and radiation therapy

Posts.Content: Remember this..All the specialists will recommend whatever treatment they perform...Business is business..To me, and I could be wrong, when they need to implant the gold markets, they are using an older LINAC (the machine that administers the radiation). The newest equipment no longer needs the markers to accurately aim the beam....Also, today, brachytherapy, seeds, have made big improvements especially when combined with beam radiation. The two used in conjunction can deliver the highest overall dose while maintaining lower side-effect risk..If your RO is shy about Brachytherapy, it's probably because he does not perform the procedure..I would locate and consult with an RO who does perform it AND IS EXPERT AT IT.... One more thing to investigate..Radiation treatment is very expensive. Always get preapprovals from your insurance company. Find out what your payment responsibility will be before you agree to any treatment.....Best of luck to you !

The all important < 0.1 lets you get better sleep...

Posts.Title: Prostate

Posts.Content: Is your dad being treated in the U.S.? Have they tried a run of antibiotics to rule out infection? If the standard trans-rectal biopsy revealed nothing, the next one should be a saturation biopsy which takes 40 core samples instead of 10. It can also reach areas the transrectal probe can not...Don't start treating Dad for prostate cancer until it is proven he HAS prostate cancer....

Posts.Title: Dads PSA 43, worried about his wellbeing. Need help!

Posts.Content: Once upon a time there were a few oncologists that specialized in treating PC only and a few of them were not afraid to try alternative treatments like estrogen in various forms including trans-dermal patches.. There were a few who claimed it produced some benefit but as I remember most suffered side-effects that for the most part limited its use. The doctors and patients who used it were working outside the mainstream that's for sure... My only defense against bone loss has been taking three 600mg calcium + D tabs every day..My last bone density test a couple of months ago looks okay.... Before I ventured out into left field I'd do a lot more research..

Posts.Title: Harmone Shots After Cyber Knife Radiation

Posts.Content: G-8 is considered high-risk so you will receive more aggressive treatment than someone who was diagnosed a G6....It has been demonstrated that HT when combined with radiation makes the radiation more effective. 50% more effective....They usually start the HT before the radiation and continue it for a year or two..The side-effects are bad, BUT NOT TOO BAD over a one year span..Hot flashes, loss of sex drive and ability...When they take you off the HT drugs, things USUALLY get back to normal, as long as your PSA remains where it belongs.. Urologist like to maintain control of your treatment until it has been demonstrated your cancer has metastasized..Then they will hand you off to a medical oncologist..But most of us have learned, the sooner you start seeing a medical oncologist, the better. Their training is focused on cancer. Not so with a urologist...Best of luck to you...
Posts.Title: Harmone Shots After Cyber Knife Radiation

Posts.Content: Your biopsy showed you were a "hard" Gleason 7, 4+3,...And all 12 biopsy cores were positive.... So now, with the entire gland biopsied, was there any more aggressive cancer found? G-8 or G-9? Or did the original G-7 hold up? Did the pathologist find any positive margins in the tissue sample delivered to him? I hate to say this, but when all 12 biopsy cores are positive, it's very difficult for a surgeon to achieve clean margins....But it is possible so lets hope that's the case !! So now, really, it's just a matter of getting healed up and waiting for that first 3-month PSA test......Try to enjoy the summer !

Posts.Title: 44yrs old with prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: NJS, your posts carry much useful information for the new guys..A wake-up call as to how important having an expert surgeon is..I hope everyone takes the time to read your entire series of posts and look up what "PSM rate" means... Surgeons who limit (or try to limit) there practices to G6 and low-risk G7 patients while turning away G8, 9 & 10 patients are certain to have fewer Positive Surgical Margins than surgeons who are willing to take a shot at curing those in the high-risk group....So by cherry-picking the customer base they can make themselves look very good indeed..Being a G9, my surgeon let me know my chances for success (surgical cure) were only 50-50 and that I would probably need follow-up radiation..But I figured 50-50 was better than nothing so I opted for the surgery (after doing a considerable amount of research). As it has turned out, my surgeon was correct and I messed up his PSM rate a little...

AgeInfo.Phrase: success  surgical cure  were only 50 50 and that I would
up radiation  But I figured 50 50 was better than nothing

Posts.Title: 40 yrs old, 2 weeks post-op (my story)

Posts.Content: NJS, your posts carry much useful information for the new guys..A wake-up call as to how important having an expert surgeon is..I hope everyone takes the time to read your entire series of posts and look up what "PSM rate" means... Surgeons who limit (or try to limit) there practices to G6 and low-risk G7 patients while turning away G8, 9 & 10 patients are certain to have fewer Positive Surgical Margins than surgeons who are willing to take a shot at curing those in the high-risk group....So by cherry-picking the customer base they can make themselves look very good indeed..Being a G9, my surgeon let me know my chances for success (surgical cure) were only 50-50 and that I would probably need follow-up radiation..But I figured 50-50 was better than nothing so I opted for the surgery (after doing a considerable amount of research). As it has turned out, my surgeon was correct and I messed up his PSM rate a little...

Posts.Title: 40 yrs old, 2 weeks post-op (my story)

Posts.Content: Body hair is a secondary sexual characteristic. The ADT has removed the driving force behind male sexuality..(Testosterone). This leaves the male body looking like an Olympic swimmer...If you can deal with the side-effects, given your numbers, I would stick with it for 2 years at least...But I'm not your doctor..Best of luck to you....

Posts.Title: Hair loss

Posts.Content: Scan technology is advancing very rapidly..The one used to check prostates is called mpMRI and it's being used to avoid multiple biopsies on guys doing AS..Once you have had 2 or 3 annual biopsies as part of your AS check-ups it is now felt that a mpMRI can replace more biopsies as long as the PSA remains reasonably stable...But the mpMRI is NOT accurate enough to replace biopsies completely, especially the first 2 or 3 ...To answer your question, yes, there is a 30% chance if you have only had one biopsy..But as the number of repeat biopsies grows, that 30% figure diminishes rapidly..The more biopsies you have, the more confident your doctors become that there is no higher grade cancer lurking. Some guys REALLY hate biopsies (you can't blame them) and they want to depend 100% on the mpMRI to spot any high-grade tumors...Because of that 30% figure, that is a high risk option.....

Posts.Title: Current perspectives on bone metastases in castrate-resistant PCa

Posts.Content: Welcome to the other side njs... Very, very few of us can travel around the country visiting with world renowned doctors and institutions before we make our treatment decisions..We find out what our insurance will pay for, who is on the approved list, do a little research and choose a local surgeon or oncologist to treat us..Even a Cow Town like Denver where I live offers some truly outstanding treatment choices...They may not publish books or research papers but they get the job done... In your first post, you used the term "Successful Surgery" when you are 2 weeks post surgery..And with your G-6 cancer, you like 90% of the men with similar numbers as yours enjoy "Successful Surgery", their PC cured never to return..There are three key milestones you must pass first..The 8 week PSA test comes back undetectable, the two year test comes back the same way as does the five year test....THEN you can break out the Champagne and we will all drink a rousing toast to your good fortune..But until then, sure, ride along with us and help the new guys, terrified and afraid, unsure what awaits them on this unsure journey...

Posts.Title: 40 yrs old, 2 weeks post-op (my story)

Posts.Content: Very few scans, if any, are reliable indicators with a PSA of 0.4 They just can't find it yet....And when they DO find it it's usually too late to do anything about it..Yes, doing SRT and HT is a shot in the dark but it CAN result in a cure....What are you waiting for? Yes, the side-effects can be terrible but not nearly as terrible as the alternative.... On the bright side, guys that had positive margins have a better cure rate than guys who didn't.

Posts.Title: Recurrence after Surgery - Now what?

Posts.Content: A common HT drug, Bicalutamide, also known as Casodex might have been what you were taking..How long have you been on HT? While this treatment is usually very effective, it does not work forever..The cancer cells, some of them, learn how to reproduce without any testosterone and your PSA starts to move upward...This condition is called "Hormone Refractory".. Yes, there are several new drugs and treatments that can be used today to prolong survival after HT has failed to control the cancer..Chemo is still used when all else fails and it's effective on some forms of PC....Another thing to look at is your testosterone level..Sometimes the HT drugs do not work and this allows the cancer to grow..Typically, the Lupron injection lowers your testosterone to less than 20 (less than 10 is better) and the Casodex blocks the rest..

Posts.Title: First PSA post-brachytherapy

Posts.Content: You are 55 years old..Hoping your cancer will stay benign without treatment for the next 20 or 30 years is wishful thinking in my opinion..The sooner you treat it, the more effective that treatment will be...You can't run any marathons if you are dead.....You should consider other forms of treatment, surgery is not the only way....But for someone your age, it's probably the best way..The uglier side-effects of radiation manifest themselves 15 or 20 years out....Read Dr. Walsh's book. If you decide on Surgery, find the best surgeon available to you...They are not all the same..

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: The HT will suppress your PSA and mask whether the radiation worked or not..While there is no debate whether HT improves the effectiveness of RT (it does) there is considerable debate as to how long the patient needs to stay on HT...I believe that newer studies show an 18 month HT treatment is almost as effective as a three year run...The problem with HT, after three years, its effects can become permanent. Testosterone levels no longer recover when the Lupron is stopped... I agree that the ultra-sensitive test can create a lot of PSA anxiety as the numbers bounce around. At this point in your treatment, the standard test will provide all the information needed to make decisions on further treatment...

Posts.Content: Hormone Therapy, lowering his testosterone level to near zero, one way or the other, can provide several more "good years" without cancer symptoms. But the side effects can be pretty bad..So you need to discuss the benefit provided compared to the side effects endured..Along with the hot flashes, your husbands ability and desire to have sex will simply fade away..Some marriages can survive this and some can not....

The income requirements are quite liberal, approval comes in a few minutes...The co-pays on some of these drugs can amount to thousands of dollars.. https://www.panfoundation.org/

Posts.Title: Drug Cost Co-pays Too Much?

Posts.Content: The argument rages around the fact that testing can and does lead to overtreatment..This overtreatment leads to needless suffering from the side-effects of the treatment and a tremendous transfer of wealth in the process.. The "Don't Test" proponents seem to forget that a PSA test by itself is harmless...It's what happens after the test that can sometimes lead to problems with over-treatment...

Posts.Title: Value of Testing and Treatment

Posts.Content: Here is how I see it..In most countries, if all prostate cancers are detected and treated, the costs of providing this treatment soon get out of hand..By withholding PSA testing, a huge cost savings is realized... They justify this by saying: "Even if millions of prostate cancers are allowed to run their course undetected and untreated, the overall mortality rate of males, statistically, does not change at all. Overall, it makes no difference in males lifespans whether these cancers are detected and treated or not detected and treated...." My reply is, well, it may not make any difference to the male population as a whole, but as an individual who is but a tiny, insignificant part of that population, PSA testing can make a HUGE difference in how long you live and in how well you live...If cost control is a must, that can be accomplished without denial of service..

Posts.Title: Well Crap!

Posts.Content: Prostate cancer is multi-focal. The 12 core TRUS biopsy can not be expected to sample all the tumors that might be present. 30% of the time, after a prostatectomy when the entire gland is biopsied, more extensive and higher grade cancer is found. That does not mean the original Gleason 6 cancer changed to Gleason 7 or 8 or 9. That simply means the original biopsy missed these other tumors..That's why anyone contemplating AS needs to verify by other means that ALL his cancer is Gleason 6 and there are no undiscovered high-grade tumors waiting to cause trouble...

Posts.Title: Questions on upcoming salvage radiation

Posts.Content: They have a system. The insurance companies won't pay for any of this stuff unless it's done in the proper order..Each step in the process justifies the next step..First, comes the biopsy..If it's negative, you will be told to come back in 6 months for another PSA test and DRE.. If it's positive, then some more extensive scans can be justified and prescribed..You did not mention your PSA level, but if it's under 10 or 15, metastasis to your neck glands is unlikely..if it's under 10, the scans are unlikely to show anything at all..Most Urologists will try a run of antibiotics before they perform a biopsy just to see how the PSA responds to that... The waiting is the worst part, try to put it on the back burner and not worry about it..Best of luck to you..

Posts.Title: how to interpret second opinion

Posts.Content: You need to realize.....That 230,000 men will be diagnosed with PC this year but only 32,000 will die from it... About 55% of the men diagnosed with PC will die from something else before their cancer kills them, Gleason 6, small percentage of the prostate involved. They need little or no treatment. Roger Mason can "cure" them.... But the other 45%, the guys with 3 or 4 positive cores, the Gleason 7, 8 and 9 guys, they are going to need more than diet and OTC supplement pills to keep this killer at bay..Prostate cancer is slowly being brought to heal thanks to aggressive medical treatment and timely diagnosis..

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: The Lupron & Casodex have very few side-effects..The lack of testosterone is what causes the side-effects..At this point, hot flashes...Most men can tolerate the chemo pretty well..That Chaarted study proves it's worth doing..Some doctors will stop the Casodex now, relying on the Lupron alone to control the cancer. Then, at the first sign the Lupron is starting to fail, the bicalutamide is resumed which can give you another year in remission..When that begins to fail, two new drugs Zitiga and Xtandi are available and have proven to be very effective in many PC patients...

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Therapy in Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: All men respond to treatment differently..Some become hormone refractory in a year or two..Others can achieve complete suppression for ten years or more..It's very hard to accurately predict.. A good medical oncologist can manipulate the drugs used (which may include estrogen) to keep the cancer in check for many years. New treatments for advanced PC are being approved everyday..So don't try to look too far ahead with today's knowledge because that understanding is changing rapidly and the treatments available are changing rapidly too.. With ADT, it's important that testosterone levels be suppressed as low as possible..It is not safe to ASSUME the drugs are working as intended..The "T" level should be monitored regularly to be sure it drops to and stays at castrate levels...

Posts.Title: Shrinkage following DaVinci

Posts.Content: Cipla, a huge Indian drug manufacturer makes most of the "generic" ED and many of the other drugs sold by popular online Indian pharmacies..They developed and manufacture the "one pill a day" combination HIV drug that has saved the lives of millions of Africans and others who can afford to pay the $1/day or less cost..HIV victims in the States must pony up $30,000 a year for the same drugs unless they too can find alternative sources.. Viagra and it's clones is now the most popular prescription drug in the world..Even in it's fifty cents each generic form it generates fantastic profits for the drug companies who make it..Sidenafil Citrate is not difficult of expensive to make...Kind of like aspirin..

Posts.Title: Ouch!

Posts.Content: 90% of the time, there is little or no pain, you can walk as soon as you wish and in fact walking is usually recommended to speed recovery..When they instruct you on how to deal with "The Bag" get as much "stuff" out of them as you can! This may be your only chance! You want a large "overnight" bag and a strap-on leg bag for moving around..A couple of velcro straps to secure the catheter up high on your thigh and the bag (leg bag) those extra straps are important..You don't want the catheter supported by your Johnson..You want a strap for that... A pair of baggy "sweat pants" to go home in..Elastic waist, no belt.. You will meet your anesthesiologist just before the surgery..Ask him to be careful of your vocal cords when he inserts the breathing tube..I talked like Donald Duck for two weeks.. Your appetite may be lacking for a while..

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: 52 years old, G-6, 30% in 2 cores, PSA 7.4....I would be interviewing surgeons, find the best one you can and get yourself cured or at least try for that goal. PC does not improve over time. Your odds don't get better by waiting..Just my layman's opinion....If the 50% risk of impotence is to much for you, look at Brachytherapy, possibly combined with IMRT. But at 52, the side-effects of radiation have a lot of time to manifest themselves and can be VERY hard to treat... It's a tough choice and we all have to face it and deal with it. Here is a good book, up to date..Gerald Chodaks's "Winning the battle against prostate cancer"...Dr. Partick Walsh's book, a few years older but he covers everything in fine detail.."Guide to surviving prostate cancer.." The information in these books will give you a good foundation to base your decisions on...

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: I agree, have another PSA test in 3 months and if it moves up it's time to see a Radiation Oncologist. Be sure the RO you choose has plenty of experience with prostate patients and has access to the latest equipment (LINACS) used to administer the radiation treatment.. If you have not yet consulted with a Medical Oncologist now might be a good time to do so, even if your urologist / surgeon disagrees. Ask HIM (the MO) who might be the best R.O. around...Don't be surprised if these actions puts you into a certain degree of conflict with the urologist surgeon as these three specialists compete with each other for patients...A good Urologist will welcome your desire to seek other opinions...

Posts.Content: Yes, you want the best Radiation Oncologist you can find, one who has successfully treated a large number of PC patients.. Posts.Title: What I learned about LEG PAIN after months of Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: The Lupron & Casodex have very few side-effects..The lack of testosterone is what causes the side-effects..At this point, hot flashes...Most men can tolerate the chemo pretty well..That Chaarted study proves it's worth doing..Some doctors will stop the Casodex now, relying on the Lupron alone to control the cancer. Then, at the first sign the Lupron is starting to fail, the bicalutamide is resumed which can give you another year in remission..When that begins to fail, two new drugs Zitiga and Xtandi are available and have proven to be very effective in many PC patients...

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Therapy in Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: HHhhmmmmm.. It seems to me they are trying to do two things at once....Narrow the radiation beam a little to limit unwanted tissue and organ damage. And shorten the ADT time to reduce the unpleasant side-effects...But since they are doing two things at once, how do they tell which treatment change produced the favorable or unfavorable result ?? If the trial fails, do they blame it on the radiation part or the ADT part? Another consideration, these trials are usually performed free to the patient..So depending on your health insurance, there may be a huge difference in your overall expense for being treated...Personally, I don't think there will be a big difference in the outcomes between the standard treatment and the trial treatment..One thing we all have learned here, every case is different so it's very hard to accurately predict outcomes...

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: PSA 0.1 is not something to get all panicked about, especially 4 years out...If there is something going on, it's going on very slowly and it's probably not going to kill you...Your next 2 or 3 PSA tests are important as they will establish a trend and possibly a doubling time..It's not to early to seek out a good Radiation Oncologist and have a talk with him. Does he have access to a newer LINAC, the radiation machine used to treat you..I would insist on a Varian RapidArc or better...After all, it's your money...I took 72 Gray to the pelvic bed with little difficulty (using the machine mentioned)..If salvage radiation is offered, it's 50% successful, more if combined with HT for a year or two, try to get morning appointments..Everyone is fresh and awake and things seem to go smoother...

Posts.Title: Uh-oh, PSA is detectable again.

Posts.Content: 52 years old, G-6, 30% in 2 cores, PSA 7.4....I would be interviewing surgeons, find the best one you can and get yourself cured or at least try for that goal. PC does not improve over time. Your odds don't get better by waiting..Just my layman's opinion....If the 50% risk of impotence is to much for you, look at Brachytherapy, possibly combined with IMRT. But at 52, the side-effects of radiation have a lot of time to manifest themselves and can be VERY hard to treat... It's a tough choice and we all have to face it and deal with it. Here is a good book, up to date..Gerald Chodaks's "Winning the battle against prostate cancer"...Dr. Partick Walsh's book, a few years older but he covers everything in fine detail.."Guide to surviving prostate cancer.." The information in these books will give you a good foundation to base your decisions on...

Posts.Title: Prostate removal question.

Posts.Content: John's advise was excellent as usual...One SLOW DOWN...With Gleason 6, there is no hurry. Pick up a copy of Patrick Walsh's book (Guide to surviving prostate cancer, 3rd edition) and read it. With surgery, it all depends on the skill of the surgeon (and luck) as to the results achieved and side-effects endured. Same with radiation, really...Today, many Radiation Oncologists are combining seed implants along with beam radiation, a one-two punch that is VERY effective. Some doctors are adding Hormone Therapy to the radiation and getting even better results... So you have lots of options to sort out. Surgery might be one of them but don't rush into it before you have a complete understanding about what is going on. Read the book I recommended to get a solid background about what your are facing before you make a treatment decision..Be warned, the doctors will all push the product they are selling... I have used alldaychemist for various drugs including Cialis without any problems. But others have had problems. You might want to pay using a pre-paid, disposable credit card..Most of the problems occurred earlier before they switched to secure servers.. There is always a chance that Customs will seize your order..If that happens, ADC will usually replace the "lost" shipment..

Posts.Title: Help newbie need advice

Posts.Content: There are two schools of thought for cases like yours...One, you start with surgery to remove as much of the cancer as possible and, if you get lucky, maybe they get all of it..But since you are considered 'high risk", followup with both radiation and HT is highly likely..This three pronged attack gives you your best chance.. The Radiation Oncologists will tell you since the surgery is likely to fail, why even bother with it.. Why expose yourself to the complications and side-effects of surgery? The surgeons will reply "PC is a lot easier for radiation to cure if we remove 98% of it first..Some experts agree with that, some don't.. I'm a G-9 and I have had the Full Monty, surgery, hormones, radiation..My surgery had complications, major infection, back in the hospital for a week. I'm now 2 years past diagnosis, PSA undetectable, (cancer free) and impotent. I'm 100% continent. No treatment at present time... Your upcoming bone and cat scans will determine your treatment options... Read Walsh's book, choose your medical team carefully and the best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: I need some support...

Posts.Content: The good news is the Gleason 6.. 97% of the guys with G-6 PC live to die of something else...So virtually any treatment you choose works equally well..Many G-6 patients can go on AS, active surveillance and go for years without any treatment..But your numbers look a little more advanced so some form of treatment is in your future. The big side-effect risk with surgery is impotence..in the real world, about 75% of the men who have had surgery suffer from it in one degree or another..Surgeons of course will tell you the impotence is much less, the "nerve sparing" technique, yada yada yada ...But it's still 75%... The BEST surgeons can cure your cancer and leave you both continent and potent..But during the surgery, they are trying to cure you, to save your life..They are not going to forgo that goal to save your potency..Read a couple of books.."A guide to surviving Prostate cancer" by Patrick Walsh and "Winning the battle against prostate cancer" by Gerald Chodak. To create a signature, go to "Settings", scroll down the left hand side.."Edit Signature"
Posts.Title: Choosing A Surgeon For da Vinci Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: You are accepting it as Gospel that your cancer is being accurately described and diagnosed by the biopsy results..Frequently, after surgery, the more complete biopsy reveals the cancer is more extensive and more dangerous than the original biopsy discovered..Talk this over with your doctors....

Posts.Title: Two negative biopsies, but....

Posts.Content: First, you should know that very few men ever die from Gleason 6 prostate cancer..That grade of tumor very seldom if ever metastasizes and spreads to other organs or bones. BUT, you can never be sure, from a 12 core biopsy, that all of your cancer is Gleason 6. The biopsy performed after a prostatectomy when the entire organ is examined 30% of the time will be upgraded to a higher Gleason score. Your biopsy, with cancer found in 8 of the 12 cores points to fairly extensive (but low risk) cancer. You have probably had it for quite a while...So waiting another 6 months before treatment is not that big a deal but it does add to the risks involved... Having a consultation with a Medical Oncologist (ask your primary care physician for a referral) can be enlightening. They work with both surgeons (Urologists) and Radiation Oncologists and they have seen it all. Their insights can be very helpful..... Urologists can also be surgeons. Radiation Oncologists are a different specialty. They frequently work with Urologists, sometimes in the same treatment center. Medical Oncologists take over when the other two have failed to provide a cure.. While Hormone Therapy is very effective at suppressing prostate cancer, it comes with a heavy side-effect load...Many doctors will shy away from it except as a last resort because of quality of life issues..It also makes treatment more difficult because it masks whether the primary (curative) treatment is working or not... How dangerous is your cancer? That's hard to say without more information..Have you had previous PSA tests before the 5.6 one? If so what are those numbers and when were they done? PSA velocity is important. As a general rule, the quicker your PSA rises, the more aggressive your cancer...Have you read Dr. Walsh's book? It's the best money you will ever spend...

Posts.Title: New here - H has rising PSA following surgery

Posts.Content: Hubby is in a fight for his life...Use all the tools that are available. You only get one chance at this...The fact that he had 3 positive margins is actually good news in a perverse way...It means the PSA is probably coming from those areas which are relatively east to treat with radiation. Had he had clean margins and a recurrence, then the cancer could be anywhere and much more difficult to treat..Nothing (yet) knocks out distant mets permanently. Once PC has metastasized, you are just fighting for as much time as possible...The purpose of Adjunct HT combined with RT is because several good studies have shown that the addition of HT increases the effectiveness of the RT by a considerable amount...The argument against it is the quality of life loss (from the HT) is not worth the benefit it provides. You will have to make your own choice..

Posts.Title: Early recurrence, rapid doubling time - questions

Posts.Content: How old are you? I would guess 64....Urologists like to save ADT until LAST, when other efforts to achieve a cure have failed..Going on ADT produces a lot of nasty side-effects that surgeons don't like to deal with. They say it makes your prostate gland "sticky" and hard to operate on, although the best surgeons manage to deal with it if they have to...Radiation Oncologists on the other hand feel HT makes their radiation treatment more effective so they are more likely to approve of your "holding action" plan....You are going to discover that Urologists (many of whom are also surgeons) Radiation Oncologists and Medical Oncologists all compete against each other for the patients dollar so it's hard to get all three specialists to agree on a course of treatment.. While Dr. Walsh's book is "The Bible" of prostate cancer, Dr. Gerald Chodak's book "Winning the battle against prostate cancer" is shorter and sticks with all the treatment options and deals with them in an unbiased way. You may find some insights in that book to help you through the next 12 months.. If waiting 12 months to begin treatment feels to be just too risky for you, traveling to a foreign country like Thailand or even Mexico for the operation might be an option you may wish to consider....

Posts.Title: More confused than ever.

Posts.Content: The upgrade from G-6 to G-7 changes the game a little.."Positive Margins" How many positive margins? How large an area did the positive margin encompass? Was the margin area classified grade 3 or grade 4? Radiation may very well be in his future..But healing is important first..Any incontinence or impotence issues need to considered before radiation because radiation treatment will stop further progress in those areas.. His PSA is undetectable using the Ultra-Sensitive test...As long as it stays there, there is little risk..But ANY increase should signal the need for radiation ASAP...... When + margins are very small they can be meaningless...The surgeons blade killed any cancer cells at the margin, none survived to start growing again...

Posts.Title: diagnosed today feb 22nd 2013

Posts.Content: "A higher voltage of electroporation was found in pigs to irreversibly destroy target cells within a narrow range while leaving neighboring cells unaffected, and thus represents a promising new treatment for cancer, heart disease and other disease states that require removal of tissue.[5] Irreversible electroporation (IRE) has since proven effective in treating human cancer, with surgeons at Johns Hopkins and other institutions now using the technology to treat pancreatic cancer previously thought to be unresectable.[6] A recent technique called non-thermal irreversible electroporation (N-TIRE) has proven successful in treating many different types of tumors and other unwanted tissue. This procedure is done using small electrodes (about 1mm in diameter), placed either inside or surrounding the target tissue to apply short, repetitive bursts of electricity at a predetermined voltage and frequency. These bursts of electricity increase the resting transmembrane potential (TMP), so that nanopores form in the plasma membrane. When the electricity applied to the tissue is above the electric field threshold of the target tissue, the cells become permanently permeable from the formation of nanopores. As a result, the cells are unable to repair the damage and die due to a loss of homeostasis.[7] N-TIRE is unique to other tumor ablation techniques in that it does not create thermal damage to the tissue around it."................WIKIpedia

Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: The upgrade from G-6 to G-7 changes the game a little.."Positive Margins" How many positive margins? How large an area did the positive margin encompass? Was the margin area classified grade 3 or grade 4? Radiation may very well be in his future..But healing is important first..Any incontinence or impotence issues need to considered before radiation because radiation treatment will stop further progress in those areas.. His PSA is undetectable using the Ultra-Sensitive test...As long as it stays there, there is little risk..But ANY increase should signal the need for radiation ASAP...... When + margins are very small they can be meaningless...The surgeons blade killed any cancer cells at the margin, none survived to start growing again...

Posts.Title: Psa post robotic prostate removal

Posts.Content: It IS possible to have a very high PSA number and not have prostate cancer..My urologist has two patients with PSA readings in the hundreds, multiple biopsies including saturation biopsies and no cancer found. So it IS possible..But their prostates are much larger than 70cc...In most cases with a PSA that high, the cause is prostate cancer. In it's early stages it causes no symptoms. You will just have to sweat it out until all the tests come back. There will be a bone scan, some X-rays, maybe a MRI and CAT scan. These tests will look for signs that the cancer may have spread beyond the prostate. The results of the biopsy, the Gleason score it reveals, and the results of the other tests I mentioned will allow his doctors to recommend a treatment program that will be the most effective for him...Do not jump to conclusions that this is a death sentence. It is not. This cancer is very treatable, generally slow-growing, most men live with it for many years.. A good book on the subject is "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" by Dr. Patrick Walsh..Any library or book store or eBay/Amazon..

Posts.Title: Please help

Posts.Content: Antibiotics treat prostate infections, not tumors..The reduction from 75 to 70cc is insignificant, don't worry about that.. The chances are good he has had PC for many years. That's why PSA screening every year or two is so important, so you find it at the very beginning when it's much more treatable..Every male should get a PSA test at the age of 45 or 50 to establish a base line, a reading that is "normal" for him. Then as the years go by, a PSA velocity can be established, the rate at which the level is increasing. This way, any suspicious changes are very easy to spot before things get out of hand..

Posts.Title: Please help

Posts.Content: For many men, Zytiga can be wonderful stuff...Your journey is amazing.. Your biopsy experience is pretty much standard. They can numb you up and give you an "anxiety reliever" to make the experience less of a trial. I've had 3 of them..You forgot to mention the blood clots in your semen for several ejaculations..That's pretty nasty... As for it being your worst medical experience, I'm not sure about that...For me, the ADT, the hormone treatments, the slow conversion from a man to a woman, that's the worst thing by far...The biopsy is over in 15 minutes. But the debilitating effects of ADT go on FOREVER...

Posts.Title: Blog post on biopsy

Posts.Content: A third biopsy is probably called for at this time...I would ask for a "saturation biopsy" which takes more samples and reaches places the standard trans-rectal biopsy can not. It is performed differently, in a hospital under general anesthesia.. Some Urologists like to perform a "T-3 MRI" before the biopsy to try and locate any possible cancer beforehand so the biopsy needles can be targeted more accurately...Your urologist may want to put you on antibiotics to rule the chance infection is causing the rapid PSA rise....The squeaky hinge gets the oil...Start squeaking....Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: You can STILL get a second opinion on those original biopsy slides by an expert lab. If they confirm you have PC, then you know where you stand..Or you could just get a second biopsy and see if things have changed..In the world of prostate cancer, having multiple biopsies is not that unusual..MRI's are not a substitute for a biopsy....

Posts.Title: Prostate Biospys safe?

Posts.Content: MRI's are wrong 30% of the time and because of this, many doctors have little faith in them..There are a handful of Urologists that use a Color Doppler Ultrasound machine to guide their biopsies and they seldom miss any cancer if cancer is present..Others use a saturation biopsy (40 cores) if they suspect cancer after a standard 12 core biopsy fails to find it..Many of us have endured multiple biopsies before our cancer is found...

Posts.Title: 65 Years Old Male PSA 12, DRE feels hardness on the right side, waiting for biopsy

Posts.Content: To answer your question, Zytiga should not be a problem with radiation...If it is, you will be one of the first ones to know as it's normally is not prescribed as a primary treatment with radiation....The combination of Eligard (Lupron) and Casodex usually works just as well until you become hormone refractory and insurance companies usually insist on this approach before approving Zytiga. However, some recent trials have shown that when Zytiga is substituted for Casodex during salvage radiation treatment, the cure rate improves. This fact is probably how your RO got the drug approved...Good for you and Good Luck !

Posts.Title: Zytiga and Radiation, safe?

Posts.Content: You need to find out 2 numbers. His PSA number and his Gleason score when he was first diagnosed. A Urologist usually does this. You could locate this doctor, explain the situation, and ask for that basic information without going through any legal formalities.. If his PSA was over 20 and his Gleason score was 8, 9 or 10 his cancer may have been aggressive and incurable right from the start...Also a factor, did he have medical insurance when he was first diagnosed? Unfortunately, for many people, this determines what type of treatment will be available to them...

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer death

Posts.Content: " I'm not there yet, but is there anything I can be doing to slow down the PSA doubling time? I started drinking pomegranate juice and just ordered several antioxidants (Lycopene and Resveratrol Defense + Vitamin C). I also increased my Omega-3 fish oil to 1000 mg daily. My urologist isn't into supplements and I just want to do everything I can to slow the cancer down before radiation is recommended. Let me know your views and anything else I might try. Thanks. " It was the OP who brought the subject up.. I agree with Mikla that dropping the US-PSA test would be a good first step in relieving his anxiety..Doing full pelvic radiation with any cancers actual location based on guesswork is not very effective treatment IMHO......With the standard PSA test, the need for further treatment will be known soon enough and at this point it might be possible to localize the location of the problem and focus treatment on that area....In the OP's case, a very localized G-6 cancer removed with 100% clean margins, perhaps moving on to SRT sooner rather than later is justified as any cancer is probably located in the pelvic area..

Posts.Content: While going on "Hormone Therapy" voluntarily will certainly destroy your libido, it also has other serious side-effects that can be life-threatening by themselves..Weight gain, bone rot, heart attacks and strokes, heavy hot flashes, emotional upsets, a whole package of nasty things..If your wife just has no sympathy for your condition, (is that the REAL problem here?) then cut her loose... Have you given the injections a fair chance? Trimix has a reputation of achieving an erection in a cadaver when properly used..Most Uro's work with sex therapists who are experts in instructing how to use this technique and achieving the results you are looking for...

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Most journeys have a beginning, a middle part and an end...I'm writing this down while I still can remember the details with some degree of accuracy...At age 55, my health insurance family plan (I was self employed), always expensive, doubled in price, making it unaffordable for my wife and I to maintain. That was 20 years ago....I had a complete physical as a precaution before I canceled the insurance, everything was fine but my doctor voiced some concern over my PSA number which was 3.5, something like that..The DRE was fine....So over the next 9 years I did get the occasional PSA test, usually at a free screening or health fair...The number went up very slowly, not enough to trigger any concern. Then, at age 64.5, at another free prostate cancer screening the Uro listed my DRE as "abnormal" and the PSA came back 6.8.. He said I should "see my doctor" about further investigation..I had spent a lot of time investigating what form of Medicare to choose, so many choices, finally I chose one recommended by my family doctor, a Medicare Advantage Plan run by United Health care and accepted by my family doctor..The day my membership card arrived I made an appointment to see him, he referred me to a Urology clinic where they quickly scheduled me for a biopsy. It came back negative ! I was off the hook ! But the urologist cautioned me, something is going on, we need to watch it. I also had a mild case of BPE so he put me on Finasteride which, as expected, lowered my PSA by half, down to 4.5 or so. A year went by, PSA started moving up a little, another biopsy, again no cancer but there was some high-grade PIN..Nine more months pass, more concern, the Uro wanted a third biopsy, I resisted but finally agreed, this time he really was aggressive with the wand and the results came back positive in 4 cores, two were G-6, one G-7 and one G-9... This was nine years ago, going on ten....Back then, in Denver, I had 2 choices, surgery or radiation..One of the partners at the Urology clinic was a top notch surgeon with a good reputation who actually taught other urologists how to perform the surgery using the then fairly new da Vinci surgical robot . He tried to talk me out of having surgery, saying that G-9 cases like mine could only expect a 50-50 chance of a cure. At that time radiation offered about the same odds.. I chose surgery anyway, 50% being better than nothing and I always could fall back on radiation if necessary...The actual surgery went well, although it resulted in a nasty staph infection that put me back in the hospital for a week, then a month of IV antibiotics at home..First post surgery PSA came back 0.9 Ouch ! Nine months passed while I healed/ recovered from the surgery while I searched for the best R.O. I could find. I found one who was the director of radiology at a big local hospital that had just installed the latest Varian LINAC Rapid Arc I did 40 fractions SRT + ADT He wanted 2 years ADT but after 18 months of undetectable PSA checks he relented and my active treatment ended. Two more years went by with undetectable PSA tests, things were looking good.....Then the monster came back....Back on ADT, Lupron only, PSA went undetectable again for almost 2 years. When PSA again was detected, Casodex was added, and PSA again dropped to undetectable.. A single bone met was found in a neck vertebra, my R.O. gave it 5 shots of SBRT and it disappeared..PSA back to undetectable (all PSA's using the standard assay). About a year later, PSA returned and Zytiga replaced the Casodex. At this point I was no longer seeing any urologists, relying on a young, aggressive M.O. instead. I had a nice remission with the Zytiga, almost two years undetectable or at least less than 1.0.. Late last year the Zytiga stopped working, switched to Xtandi, got a fair but short-lived response. PSA moving up rapidly now..It was 54 two weeks ago... Two years ago, I was seen by a VA oncologist. I needed to do this in order to have the VA supply the Zytiga and Xtandi which even with Part D Medicare I could not afford those co-pays and doughnut holes..I got to like and trust the VA doctor. Both my Medicare oncologist and my VA oncologist agree chemo (Docetaxel) is my next step. Since Quality of Life takes a huge step backwards with this, I have been resisting implementing it, hoping one of the new immunotherapy treatments became available. Yes, I know about Provenge but it's not available through the VA and my Medicare doctor has little faith in it, especially considering its cost. It's very hard to walk into the Chemo Lounge when you have no symptoms and let them push a bag of poison into your veins knowing it will make you sick as hell.. So that's pretty much my journey so far..I just thought I would share it with everyone..I have learned so much from the guys who are on the same journey, thank you all.... Fairwind...

Posts.Title: I am worried about Biopsy and prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Have you had a DRE and was the result "normal" or "abnormal"? TRT is harmless unless you have prostate cancer or BPH. Then it becomes counter-productive. All of the TRT products come with a list of warnings that would give most men pause about taking them...Your PSA of 5.6 is an alarm bell going off and I suspect a prostate biopsy is in your near future..You can't blame the low "T" on all your other health problems. Step one is to shed those extra pounds you are carrying...Everything works better then...

Posts.Title: coping with celibacy

Posts.Content: Gleason 9 prostate cancer is a 50-50 bet when it comes to using the word "cure"..Your partner's biopsy results showed that a cure was highly unlikely, the cancer was just too far along..The surgery was in fact a debulking procedure which is worthwhile but was unlikely to be curative.. In the States, if the person had adequate insurance, an aggressive treatment would be mounted aimed at preventing or slowing metastasis to the bones..While castration is still the most effective hormone treatment, chemical castration in the form of ADT-3 is widely used to extend the survival time as long as possible..ADT-3 uses three drugs to achieve the same result as surgical castration..Lupron, Casodex and Finasteride are typically used.. Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" will provide both you and your partner with the necessary knowledge to help you guide your doctors into providing the treatment that's best for you..The later chapters in the book deal with how advanced prostate is treated..

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Long story short: Diagnosed a G-9, PSA around 10..had surgery, positive margin, positive vesicle..Had combo HT-RT PSA went to zero for 18 months. Stopped HT. I'm not sure what's going on but for now it looks pretty good....

Posts.Title: Advise on Lupron (Eligard) usage

Posts.Content: Pain is unusual with PC unless it has spread to the bones or other organs. But you said his scans were clear..So perhaps the pain is being caused by something else..The infected bladder, kidney or bladder stones, some other medical problem not related to the cancer..Did this pain start soon after his radiation treatments started? If so, it may be time for a complete review of his radiation treatment plan, recheck everything including the machine being used to treat him..Sit down and have a talk with his radiation oncologist to be sure the radiation is not the problem..On another forum there is a member, Purgatory, (David) who's radiation treatment got sideways and caused him severe injury..You can find him at www.healingwell.com...click on forums, then prostate While stronger narcotics can control his pain, I would ask his doctors to determine the REASON for the pain first..Failing that, ask for some Fentanyl patches..They work, but they are very addictive and "brain fog" is a part of all narcotic pain killers..

Posts.Title: I was wondering if anyone else experienced this as a symptom of Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: The Book is "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Pat Walsh.. They may want to do a bone scan and a full-body MRI to see if any metastasis (spread) shows up. Just a CYA procedure in your case...Then you will have to decide what form of treatment you will undergo..Assuming you have decent medical insurance, your choices will be surgery to remove your prostate and hopefully all the cancer, resulting in a cure..Or radiation..Works as well as surgery but is more expensive, takes longer and has a different side-effect profile. There are other types of radiation, Brachytherapy or "seeds". Fast and effective. Radiation seems to be even more effective when used in conjunction with "Hormone Therapy", which comes with major side-effects..If you start with surgery and it fails to deliver a cure, you can move on to "Salvage Radiation" and see if that works for you..But if you begin with radiation, surgery generally can't be used as a backup..Your Urologist may or may not want to perform the surgery himself. Most urologists are also surgeons. But you want an EXPERT surgeon, so do a little research before you commit to a surgeon or Radiation Oncologist..Today, 80% of the Prostatectomies are performed with a DaVinci Surgical Robot..But there are those who feel the old "open" technique produces better results..Again, do your homework.. When you get done with Walsh's book, you might want to read Dr. Gerald Chodaks, "Winning the battle against prostate cancer". He concentrates on ALL the treatment options, their effectiveness, side-effects, in a completely unbiased way.. With a PSA under 6 and only 2 cores malignant, you cancer sounds to be very curable..But PC is tricky..No two men respond exactly the same..Outcomes can be very hard to predict...One benefit with surgery, the entire gland is removed and can be biopsied in detail..Then you know for sure just how dangerous your cancer was or was not...Best of luck to you!

Posts.Title: How often does THIS happen ??

Posts.Content: Our cases are similar...All (3) of my doctors prefer the standard test. For the reasons your Uro-surgeon mentioned..If your standard test comes back <0.1 (undetectable) that means you are cured or at least in remission. Enjoy that state of being and move away from worrying about PC until you have something to worry about...The ultra-sensitive test may indeed show something...Oh My God, what am I going to do now??? Months of useless, needless worry, THAT'S all you get with the ultra-sensitive test...Instead of enjoying life, you spend 24 hours a day worrying about when you should get yet another test.. The chances of any further treatment starting before the PSA level climbs above 0.2 are very slim..So watching it slowly (or quickly) move to that level just robs your good time and sends you spinning into the black hole of PSA anxiety..Take "undetectable" for what it is and enjoy it for as long as you can... I don't blame you for wanting to get off HT as quickly as possible, but 6 months may not be as effective as a year or 18 months..If you think your testosterone is going to come roaring back in a couple of weeks, that's not how it works..It will take two or three months before it returns to normal levels..So you might as well do 6 more months and get maximum benefit from it..

Posts.Title: PSA rising 2 1/2 weeks before next Lupron shot

Posts.Content: Your PSA numbers support the need for a prostate biopsy..At some point you will have a DRE, a quick, painless exam of the prostate done with the physicians index finger..This simple procedure coupled with the ultra-sound mapping and Biopsy will find out why your PSA is so high. There is a fairly high probability that prostate cancer will be found but it's by no means certain..It's possible to have an elevated PSA reading and not have prostate cancer..The IV antibiotics used to treat your discitis would have also eliminated infection as the cause of the high readings..Have you had a DRE? was it "normal" or "abnormal" ? Is medical insurance an issue here?

Posts.Title: Discitis Then Raised PSA's

Posts.Content: One, you have plenty of time to consider ALL your options..Don't let anyone rush you into anything... One point to consider...The needle biopsy found some cancer in your prostate gland...But needle biopsies can not be counted on to have discovered ALL the cancer that may be present..Prostate cancer tends to be multi-focal, there is usually more than one tumor developing at any given time....While your biopsy points to a very early stage there is a 30% chance of more advanced disease..Further testing can narrow this down before you submit to a radical prostatectomy.. No one has yet mentioned the the need for a second opinion on your biopsy slides...Most of the time, the findings are strong enough so this step is not necessary but when a small amount of Gleason 6 is the basis for a cancer diagnosis, you want to be SURE the pathology report is accurate because you and your doctors will be basing your treatment on what the biopsy revealed. So it's very important these findings are correct..There are two "expert" pathology labs that specialize in analyzing prostate biopsies. Epstien at Johns-Hopkins and Bostwick Labs. Ask your urologist to arrange for the second opinion at one of these labs...

Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: Radiation treatment still offers you the possibility of a cure...If you wait too long, that opportunity is lost..The LINACS used today by most hospitals are MUCH improved over the equipment they were using just 10 years ago when most of the radiation horror stories were written. They can pinpoint their target and avoid damage to healthy tissue much better than in the past. You owe it to yourself to at least talk to a Radiation Oncologist about Salvage Radiation..It's not the horror show it once was..They might want to put you on HT for 12 months or so along with the radiation..The combined treatment works considerably better than either one alone..For sure it's no fun but it's better than dying..

Posts.Title: Reluctant new member questions, including second opinion on biopsy and stage of PC

Posts.Content: There are dozens of products like TBL-12 (sea cucumber extract) that claim to cure cancer...Save your money and stick with treatments that been proven to work... Two books for you to read. Surviving prostate cancer by Dr. Pat Walsh and Winning the battle against prostate cancer by Dr. Gerald Chodak. This will give you the background information you need to make an intelligent treatment choice..

Posts.Title: Not me

Posts.Content: Not all surgeons are created equal...If you choose surgery, and can get your insurance company to agree, I would seek out a recognized expert to perform the surgery..This is easier said than done..Another form of radiation treatment, Brachytherapy, and brachy combined with external beam can deliver results equal or better than surgery with less side-effect risk..Again, seek out the best doctors you can find and can afford... One other thing to consider..Your G-6 biopsy puts you in low risk, few men ever die from this category..But unless the prostate is removed and the entire gland biopsied, you can't be SURE there is not some higher grade cancer lurking..It is not unusual for pathology reports to be changed to a more threatening form of PC when the organ is removed and examined closely. With radiation, you have to take that needle biopsy at face value and hope for the best and the majority of the time, that's fine... Winning the battle against prostate cancer by Dr. G. Chodak is an up to date book that explains all the treatment options and favors none. Just the facts.....Dr. Walsh's book is more detailed but he is a surgeon so it slants that way a little...Making this decision is the toughest part. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: There is a BIG difference in the LINACS (the machines that produce and deliver the radiation...I would insist on a Varian Rapid-Arc or its equivalent.. Something less than 5 years old....The newer machines do a much better job at limiting damage to healthy tissue..Just as important is the skill of the Radiation Oncologist who is writing your treatment program, giving the machine its instructions...This is a $100,000 procedure, don't settle for being treated on obsolete equipment even if you must travel to get the best....While ADT (added to boost the radiation treatment) is indeed unpleasant, it might be worth looking into as your pathology is less then ideal.....

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: I think .003 is the low limit for the ultra-sensitive test.. Undetectable is written <.003 which means below the tests threshold..You are just coming off HT, it takes a while for your testosterone level to recover from that stuff..Mine skyrocketed to twice what it was before I was diagnosed! Alas, my PSA also moved off the undetectable peg also so I'm back on HT..But figure 3 or 4 months after the shot wears off before your "T" will recover..You should check your "T" level along with your PSA...The longer you were on HT, the longer it takes to recover..After 3 years, few men ever recover, the effect becomes permanent.. Since you have had radiation treatment, you need to be careful with anything that can lead to bleeding, aspirin, fish oil..A condition called "Radiation Cystitis" is common and may be aggravated by aspirin..Symptoms include blood in your urine, hematuria...I would talk with my RO & Uro both about doing an aspirin regimen..

Posts.Title: Current perspectives on bone metastases in castrate-resistant PCa

Posts.Content: Apalutamide was called ARN-509 in it's early trials It showed great promise and was very effective. They announced a phase 3 trial but I'm not sure it's taking place..You may find different answers as to its status and availability..Some guys have had success with estrogen patches..You need an oncologist who is willing to work outside the margins to a certain extent... There IS an active trial, a big one, 274 locations so there is one near you... https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/...ow_locs=Y#locn
Posts.Title: What's next?

Posts.Content: PC is multi-focal.. When the entire gland is examined after it has been removed, there is a average of 7 separate and distinct tumors found. These individual tumors can be of different Gleason grades..So later on it might look like a G-6 tumor has progressed into a grade 4, G-8 tumor, what really happens is the higher grade tumor was missed during the needle biopsy. With the standard 12 core needle biopsy, 30% of the time, a more aggressive, higher grade tumor goes undetected...it's not that a indolent G-6 grade 3 tumor progressed into a more threatening G-7..The higher grade tumor was there all the time, undiscovered.. That's why guys doing A.S. have to keep a sharp eye on things in case their tumors are not as harmless as they think...
