Posts.Title: What does your Gleason score actually mean?

Posts.Content: Radiation "works" by damaging the DNA in the cancer cells so they can't reproduce..It does not kill all the cancer cells instantly. So PSA seldom plummets after R/T. Rather, there is a slow, steady decline to "nadir", some low point that remains stable for years...When R/T is used as a primary treatment, the prostate gland is still able to produce some small amount of PSA and this is what shows up on subsequent PSA tests. If it's used as salvage (trying to salvage a failed surgery) the prostate gland has (hopefully) been completely removed so there is no source of residual PSA..In other words, PSA should drop to zero or very near zero and stay there..When HT is added as an adjunct to radiation, PSA usually drops to a very low number very quickly and will stay there as long as the HT continues. This effect masks whether or not the R/T was effective..You don't really know until you are taken off the HT and the results of the radiation must then stand on their own..... One way to judge whether radiation worked or not, PSA should never rise above what it was before treatment started....If it does, the cancer is still active and further treatment may be necessary....

Posts.Title: Is second opinion for pathology need post surgery?

Posts.Content: At 78 years, Dad may indeed have PC...But treating it could very well cause more problems than the cancer will ever cause him..His PSA is well within the normal range for a 78 year old with an enlarged prostate..His urologist may prescribe Avodart, a mild form of hormone therapy, which will shrink his prostate and relieve the urination problems and also suppress any possible prostate cancer without introducing any severe side-effects...Usually, this drug will cut his PSA number in half.. Dad's going to be fine. Focus your attension on your Mom....Best of luck to you and your family...

Posts.Title: Maybe, maybe not? Whats up?

Posts.Content: 90% of the time, there is little or no pain, you can walk as soon as you wish and in fact walking is usually recommended to speed recovery..When they instruct you on how to deal with "The Bag" get as much "stuff" out of them as you can! This may be your only chance! You want a large "overnight" bag and a strap-on leg bag for moving around..A couple of velcro straps to secure the catheter up high on your thigh and the bag (leg bag) those extra straps are important..You don't want the catheter supported by your Johnson..You want a strap for that... A pair of baggy "sweat pants" to go home in..Elastic waist, no belt.. You will meet your anesthesiologist just before the surgery..Ask him to be careful of your vocal cords when he inserts the breathing tube..I talked like Donald Duck for two weeks.. Your appetite may be lacking for a while..

Posts.Title: Question about recurrence post RP

Posts.Content: Pick up a copy of Walsh's book and learn all you can..."Hormone Therapy" is nice talk for castration...Today it's done with drugs, Lupron, which when used short term, the effects are reversible. In the later stages of prostate cancer, HT is used to temporarily put the cancer into remission. It can effectively control the cancer for anywhere from 2 to 10 years.. But we are talking about something different here..It has been found that when HT is combined with RT in a salvage attempt at a CURE, the radiation treatment's effectiveness is increased by 50% or more.. Researchers are not exactly sure what the mechanism is, but it is felt that the HT weakens the cancer cells and makes them more susceptible to the radiation, improving results.. For a 74 year old man to withstand the side-effects of all three treatments (surgery, radiation, hormone) and end up with a net benefit is a job for you, him and his doctors to discuss and decide...

Posts.Title: What happened?

Posts.Content: It was the HT that pushed your PSA down to .02, not the radiation..Radiation treatment does not necessarily kill the prostate gland completely so it is quite possible your PSA could level off at 2 or 3 and remain there for years....You said your "oncologist" tried to put you back on HT but the insurance company squawked..Was that your Radiation Oncologist?? They should know that when radiation is the primary treatment, some residual PSA is quite normal as you still have a prostate gland... I would certainly get a second opinion on the appropriateness of going back on HT at this time..It is my understanding that it takes at least 2 years for PSA to stabilize after radiation treatment...This fact might have something to do with why the insurance company balked at re-starting the HT...Again, get a second opinion from a Radiation Oncologist.....

Posts.Content: There are areas off the prostate that the trans-rectal needle biopsy simply can not reach..100% of the gland is NOT sampled, so a needle biopsy can not be relied on to give a 100% reliable result.. It is quite common that after surgery when the entire gland can be examined, 30% of the patients are upgraded to a higher grade of cancer or a more extensive cancer..This is what makes AS a real gamble unless you spend the time and money to verify the needle biopsy results.....

Posts.Title: How many military vets are here?

Posts.Content: Prostate cancer is multi-focal. The 12 core TRUS biopsy can not be expected to sample all the tumors that might be present. 30% of the time, after a prostatectomy when the entire gland is biopsied, more extensive and higher grade cancer is found. That does not mean the original Gleason 6 cancer changed to Gleason 7 or 8 or 9. That simply means the original biopsy missed these other tumors..That's why anyone contemplating AS needs to verify by other means that ALL his cancer is Gleason 6 and there are no undiscovered high-grade tumors waiting to cause trouble...

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: Urologists and Radiation Oncologists do indeed work and play golf together. But Medical Oncologists, whose specialty is treating cancer with drugs, are seldom invited to join in these activities...Call it friendly competition for the patients dollar. But they have insights you will not hear from the other two...The gold markers are one way to position you for the R/T but the latest LINAC's (radiation machines) no longer need them...For the $100,000 Medicare will be billed, you might as well be treated on the latest equipment..Am I a little cynical? Yes indeed....But I'm 3 years further along on this journey than you are... It's very important to establish good rapport and trust with your doctors..But if they balk at you getting second opinions (your life is on the line here) then they are not the wonderful people you think they are...The best doctors will welcome second opinions. It protects them and enhances their reputations if the second opinion agrees with them.. Do you have your own copy of your biopsy report? If not, ask for one. You paid for it, It's yours..Your Urologist should have no qualms about giving you a copy. Should you decide to get a second opinion from another doctor, bring that report with you as the doctor will need it...Best of luck to you and please let us know how your journey progresses..

Posts.Title: Does anyone know what kind of pill or capsule I will be taking with my Hormone T,

Posts.Content: The Lupron & Casodex have very few side-effects..The lack of testosterone is what causes the side-effects..At this point, hot flashes...Most men can tolerate the chemo pretty well..That Chaarted study proves it's worth doing..Some doctors will stop the Casodex now, relying on the Lupron alone to control the cancer. Then, at the first sign the Lupron is starting to fail, the bicalutamide is resumed which can give you another year in remission..When that begins to fail, two new drugs Zitiga and Xtandi are available and have proven to be very effective in many PC patients...

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Therapy in Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Prostate cancer is multi-focal...When cancerous prostate glands are removed by surgery, the AVERAGE gland contains 7 distinct and separate tumors. These tumors can and frequently do have different Gleason scores... When a needle biopsy reveals grade 3, 4 and sometimes 5 cells, those needles have passed through different tumors. That's why you can't depend on a needle biopsy to be 100% accurate in producing a reliable Gleason score. The needles seldom penetrate all the tumors that are likely to be contained in the prostate...That's why, after surgery, in 30% of the cases, the Gleason score is changed to a higher number after the pathologist examines the entire gland....He finds tumors the biopsy needles did not...

Posts.Title: Upgrade to higher Gleason

Posts.Content: I think you would want the incontinence issue resolved before you start any R/T. The radiation tends to freeze any further improvement with the incontinence..Since your cancer was low risk, I would wait for those 3 and 6 month PSA readings before I seriously considered R/T..As long as the PSA comes back undetectable, I would take a wait and see approach... If, in the end, you decide R/T is needed, find the best R/O you can, one who has access to the newest radiation equipment that is capable of treating the prostate bed without administering a high dose to the colon and rectum..

Posts.Title: New to Site, Hello

Posts.Content: The exact procedure; You dad will lie on his side on a table..A well-lubricated ultra-sound probe will be inserted into his rectum and positioned against his prostate gland. The image of his prostate will be displayed on a small screen. The doctor will manipulate the probe and press a button which causes a needle to dart out of the probe and take a tissue sample of the desired area..Dad will hear a "click" as this happens and maybe feel the pin-prick. This is repeated 12 times, taking 12 sample cores. It takes less than 10 minutes...Be sure to tell the doctor about any blood thinners he is taking, even things like aspirin and fish oil as these will need to be curtailed or excessive bleeding can result.. Then you wait for the pathology report to come back from the lab..

Posts.Title: Time for another biopsy?

Posts.Content: Gleason 7 comes in two flavors..3+4=7 and 4+3=7 .. The 3+4 is a little less aggressive than the 4+3 variety..It would be unusual for bone mets to show up with a PSA of only 7.9. Usually (but not always) the PSA will be over 50 when bone mets become detectable..Before the doctors recommend treatment, they will do everything possible to correctly stage his cancer so the treatment will be effective..Read Dr. Walsh's book...

Posts.Title: Time for another biopsy?

Posts.Content: KLA, before we can offer advise and help, you need to clarify your Gleason score.. Gleason 5 (3+2=5 or 2+3=5) is seldom if ever reported as being positive for cancer. Few if any urologists would recommend surgery...But if ONE of the grades in your Gleason score is a 5, (4+5=9) then that is serious. You can get a copy of your biopsy report from your doctor simply by asking for one. If you have indeed tested positive for PC, now would be a good time to read "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Patrick Walsh. Try and get the newest (third) edition..

Posts.Title: Is improvement possible???

Posts.Content: Before Dr. Walsh developed his nerve-sparing technique, impotence was virtually guaranteed. It was part of the package. Now, with the new methods, impotence "only" effects 50% of those undergoing the procedure, nerve sparing or otherwise..Pills, pumps and injections have greatly reduced the impact of this surgery....Those who choose radiation over surgery suffer the same 50% ED figure, but it takes longer to develop, typically 3 years after treatment..

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: You are 55 years old..Hoping your cancer will stay benign without treatment for the next 20 or 30 years is wishful thinking in my opinion..The sooner you treat it, the more effective that treatment will be...You can't run any marathons if you are dead.....You should consider other forms of treatment, surgery is not the only way....But for someone your age, it's probably the best way..The uglier side-effects of radiation manifest themselves 15 or 20 years out....Read Dr. Walsh's book. If you decide on Surgery, find the best surgeon available to you...They are not all the same..

Posts.Title: Have PC

Posts.Content: Lupron is chemical castration, it's as simple as that..But it's still the most effective treatment for advanced prostate cancer and it's relatively cheap so it's widely used..If you are doing watchful waiting, you are a LONG ways from needing Hormone Therapy, (Lupron). Sometimes it's used as an adjunct to radiation treatment, it makes the radiation more effective at achieving a cure, the usual treatment time-frame is 2 years when used this way.

Posts.Content: If you wish to get the straight scoop on radiation, visit with a radiation oncologist not a urologist..There have been major improvements in radiation treatment over the past 10 years. When 2 types of radiation can be combined, SBRT and Brachytherapy, (seeds) the cure rate is now better than surgery with less side-effect risk...Do your homework..

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: The ED drugs are simple compounds easy to manufacture at low cost..There is no need to fake them...I have used alldaychemist located in India with no problems with the service or the products...We are talking about recreational drugs here, not life-saving emergency-room stuff....
Posts.Title: Prescription tip

Posts.Content: I agree, have another PSA test in 3 months and if it moves up it's time to see a Radiation Oncologist. Be sure the RO you choose has plenty of experience with prostate patients and has access to the latest equipment (LINACS) used to administer the radiation treatment.. If you have not yet consulted with a Medical Oncologist now might be a good time to do so, even if your urologist / surgeon disagrees. Ask HIM (the MO) who might be the best R.O. around...Don't be surprised if these actions puts you into a certain degree of conflict with the urologist surgeon as these three specialists compete with each other for patients...A good Urologist will welcome your desire to seek other opinions...

Posts.Title: New here - H has rising PSA following surgery

Posts.Content: Scan technology is advancing very rapidly..The one used to check prostates is called mpMRI and it's being used to avoid multiple biopsies on guys doing AS..Once you have had 2 or 3 annual biopsies as part of your AS check-ups it is now felt that a mpMRI can replace more biopsies as long as the PSA remains reasonably stable...But the mpMRI is NOT accurate enough to replace biopsies completely, especially the first 2 or 3 ...To answer your question, yes, there is a 30% chance if you have only had one biopsy..But as the number of repeat biopsies grows, that 30% figure diminishes rapidly..The more biopsies you have, the more confident your doctors become that there is no higher grade cancer lurking. Some guys REALLY hate biopsies (you can't blame them) and they want to depend 100% on the mpMRI to spot any high-grade tumors...Because of that 30% figure, that is a high risk option.....

Posts.Content: A lot depends on your age...Radiation is the gift that keeps on giving...The short-term effects are well known and usually very manageable..It's the long term effects, when you are 60-70 years old, 10-20 years out, that can get complicated and radiation oncologists seldom talk about...Do your homework well...

Posts.Title: Brachytherapy (Seed implants) for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Radiation works slowly..It could take up to 2 years for your PSA to bottom out. Most R.O.'s want their patients on HT for at least a year...If you stop the HT, it will take a month or two for your testosterone to BEGIN to recover...You should be checking your "T" level along with your PSA....If your PSA starts to climb, at some point you will go back on ADT-2, Eligard + Casodex, and more than likely stay on these drugs for the duration....At some point most men become Hormone Refractory, the drugs stop working, and your Oncologist, who will be your lead doctor by this time will move on to other treatments to try and keep the cancer from metastasizing..With an assortment of new drugs to choose from, they can keep us going a long time...
Posts.Title: Not sure I know where I am going

Posts.Content: Hormone Therapy, lowering his testosterone level to near zero, one way or the other, can provide several more "good years" without cancer symptoms. But the side effects can be pretty bad..So you need to discuss the benefit provided compared to the side effects endured..Along with the hot flashes, your husbands ability and desire to have sex will simply fade away..Some marriages can survive this and some can not....

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer t3b gleason 9

Posts.Content: Hubby is in a fight for his life...Use all the tools that are available. You only get one chance at this...The fact that he had 3 positive margins is actually good news in a perverse way...It means the PSA is probably coming from those areas which are relatively east to treat with radiation. Had he had clean margins and a recurrence, then the cancer could be anywhere and much more difficult to treat..Nothing (yet) knocks out distant mets permanently. Once PC has metastasized, you are just fighting for as much time as possible...The purpose of Adjunct HT combined with RT is because several good studies have shown that the addition of HT increases the effectiveness of the RT by a considerable amount...The argument against it is the quality of life loss (from the HT) is not worth the benefit it provides. You will have to make your own choice..

Posts.Title: Early recurrence, rapid doubling time - questions

Posts.Content: Just because your needle biopsy came back G-6, that does not guarantee that all the cancer in your prostate is G-6....After surgery, when the entire prostate can be biopsied, 30% of the time, the Gleason score gets upgraded.. Don't bet your life on the results of a needle biopsy....

Posts.Title: Blog post on biopsy

Posts.Content: Who, exactly, changed your pathology from Gleason 6 to Gleason 7? If you are going to pay for a second pathology report, I would be sure it was an expert lab that did the second opinion...A lot depends on the accuracy of this report... Ask your urologist how many robotic prostatectomies he has performed...If that number is less than 300, I would look for another surgeon with more experience...There is a lot riding on this....

Posts.Title: proton beam therapy for prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Not long ago, surgeons discouraged the use of ADT prior to surgery because they said it made the prostate gland " sticky" and considerably harder to remove...The staging done on the basis of a needle biopsy is mostly educated guesswork. The true "stage" can not be known until the gland is removed and a complete pathology workup done.. Of the 4 doctors you have seen, which one put him on the Casodex / Lupron? Did your surgeon have anything to say about this? As George said, I'm surprised your insurance company has not balked about covering this rather unique treatment plan...

Posts.Title: Pre-surgery chemo recommended

Posts.Content: You can send the biopsy slides off to Dr. Epstein if you like but in this case even if he makes some adjustments they are not likely to change the treatment options or the prognosis for your Dad....His treatment options now hinge on the upcoming scans..If no mets are found then some type of radiation treatment aimed at curing him is likely...If mets are found then they might do Chemo plus the ADT they are about to start..If you have not yet consulted with a Medical Oncologist now might be a good time to do so as the Urologist's job is pretty much over...

Posts.Title: Post Surgery Recovery

Posts.Content: Hormone treatment affects some men differently than others..But it has a major impact on all men who must endure it. Testosterone is the hormone that makes a man a man and when he is suddenly deprived of it, huge changes take place, some physical and some mental...Fortunately, most of these changes can be minimized through exercise, diet and perhaps anti-depressant drugs..With a little luck, the R/T will produce a cure and the Lupron injections can stop..Recent studies have shown that 18 months of HDT works as well as 3 years in most cases.. Your Dad should talk with his RO about when he can take a HT vacation.. Quality of life is just as important as keeping that PSA number down...

Posts.Content: Walk as much as you are allowed to..Most of us had no restrictions on walking. It makes a big difference in the speed of your recovery..Good Ginger Ale (Canada Dry) can settle your stomach. Posts.Title: Here for my husband

Posts.Content: Before surgery is offered, tests are performed to determine if the cancer is still confined to the prostate gland..If it is found that the cancer has already spread beyond the gland itself, surgery is seldom offered or performed....When surgery IS performed, the entire gland is carefully separated from the body intact, placed in a sealed plastic bag and is removed from the body with no spillage. In high-risk cases, adjunct radiation treatment is often performed after the surgery regardless of apparent surgical success..

Posts.Title: Surgery Problems

Posts.Content: You may indeed be able to obtain insurance sooner than your 65th birthday under Obamacare . When you turn 65, the provisions of your policy may change as Medicare takes over.. $2000 for your TRUP biopsy sounds about double what it should have been..In my case, 4 years ago, the total charge covered by Medicare and accepted by my Urologist was $750..Plus my $30 copay..So $780. The pathology labs bill was paid by Medicare and I never saw it..I believe the split was $400 for the Urologist services and $350 for the lab that performed the pathology. In my case, the pathologist was an employee of the lab and he did not bill separately. Today, many medical specialists like Pathologists, Urologists, Radiation Oncologists, Medical Oncologists et.al. refuse to become "employees" of hospitals or large treatment centers where they are expected to work for a fixed salary. Instead they become "private contractors", self-employed free-lancers that can charge whatever they want for their services. Many of these people will refuse Medicare patients period. Some are willing to accept Medicare Advantage patients because their insurance is administered by private insurance companies that pay quicker and in some cases pay more than regular Medicare does....Since your biopsy was not covered by insurance, there was no one involved who could bundle the various charges and submit them for insurance payment so you wound up taking the full hit... Most medical practices have a "Billing Clerk" as part of their staff, a trained and well-paid person who knows all the ins and outs of medical billing. This person can help you determine who is going to pay for what and how much..Before I was to undergo a major medical procedure, I always asked for "pre-approval" so there were no surprises..
Posts.Title: More confused than ever.

Posts.Content: "A higher voltage of electroporation was found in pigs to irreversibly destroy target cells within a narrow range while leaving neighboring cells unaffected, and thus represents a promising new treatment for cancer, heart disease and other disease states that require removal of tissue.[5] Irreversible electroporation (IRE) has since proven effective in treating human cancer, with surgeons at Johns Hopkins and other institutions now using the technology to treat pancreatic cancer previously thought to be unresectable.[6] A recent technique called non-thermal irreversible electroporation (N-TIRE) has proven successful in treating many different types of tumors and other unwanted tissue. This procedure is done using small electrodes (about 1mm in diameter), placed either inside or surrounding the target tissue to apply short, repetitive bursts of electricity at a predetermined voltage and frequency. These bursts of electricity increase the resting transmembrane potential (TMP), so that nanopores form in the plasma membrane. When the electricity applied to the tissue is above the electric field threshold of the target tissue, the cells become permanently permeable from the formation of nanopores. As a result, the cells are unable to repair the damage and die due to a loss of homeostasis.[7] N-TIRE is unique to other tumor ablation techniques in that it does not create thermal damage to the tissue around it."................WIKIpedia

Posts.Title: What I learned about LEG PAIN after months of Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Once a 3 always a 3..Same with 4 and 5.....Prostate Cancer is multi-focal..The average gland when removed by surgery has 7 separate and distinct tumors. These tumors can be different Gleason grades...The biopsy may find the prevalent grade 3 cancer but it can miss a tiny grade 4 or grade 5 tumor which can make itself known months or years later...

Posts.Title: Fodder for the pro-PSA test argument

Posts.Content: Antibiotics treat prostate infections, not tumors..The reduction from 75 to 70cc is insignificant, don't worry about that.. The chances are good he has had PC for many years. That's why PSA screening every year or two is so important, so you find it at the very beginning when it's much more treatable..Every male should get a PSA test at the age of 45 or 50 to establish a base line, a reading that is "normal" for him. Then as the years go by, a PSA velocity can be established, the rate at which the level is increasing. This way, any suspicious changes are very easy to spot before things get out of hand..

AgeInfo.Phrase: test at the age of 45 or 50 to establish a
the age of 45 or 50 to establish a base line

Posts.Title: Please help

Posts.Content: It IS possible to have a very high PSA number and not have prostate cancer..My urologist has two patients with PSA readings in the hundreds, multiple biopsies including saturation biopsies and no cancer found. So it IS possible..But their prostates are much larger than 70cc...In most cases with a PSA that high, the cause is prostate cancer. In it's early stages it causes no symptoms. You will just have to sweat it out until all the tests come back. There will be a bone scan, some X-rays, maybe a MRI and CAT scan. These tests will look for signs that the cancer may have spread beyond the prostate. The results of the biopsy, the Gleason score it reveals, and the results of the other tests I mentioned will allow his doctors to recommend a treatment program that will be the most effective for him...Do not jump to conclusions that this is a death sentence. It is not. This cancer is very treatable, generally slow-growing, most men live with it for many years.. A good book on the subject is "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" by Dr. Patrick Walsh..Any library or book store or eBay/Amazon..

Posts.Title: Please help

Posts.Content: The Lupron & Casodex have very few side-effects..The lack of testosterone is what causes the side-effects..At this point, hot flashes...Most men can tolerate the chemo pretty well..That Chaarted study proves it's worth doing..Some doctors will stop the Casodex now, relying on the Lupron alone to control the cancer. Then, at the first sign the Lupron is starting to fail, the bicalutamide is resumed which can give you another year in remission..When that begins to fail, two new drugs Zitiga and Xtandi are available and have proven to be very effective in many PC patients...

Posts.Content: "My husband is 50 and was diagosed with PC after having a gleason score of 9. He had a palpable tumour,the biopsy showed cores of 3+4 and 4+3." This sentence indicates a Gleason score of 7 (4+3=7) not 9 "High Volume prostate cancer Gleason 4+3 with focal Gleason 5, T3b. All margins negative except one at the apex 1mm and one at the posterior limit 1mm. Overall tumor size 6.8 ml." The "focal G-5" and the positive margins means adjunct radiation is in his future. His first post-surgery PSA test will tell just how urgent the need for radiation is..Best of luck to you both...

Posts.Title: Advice please on patholgy report- post op prostatectomy

Posts.Content: 90% of the time, there is little or no pain, you can walk as soon as you wish and in fact walking is usually recommended to speed recovery..When they instruct you on how to deal with "The Bag" get as much "stuff" out of them as you can! This may be your only chance! You want a large "overnight" bag and a strap-on leg bag for moving around..A couple of velcro straps to secure the catheter up high on your thigh and the bag (leg bag) those extra straps are important..You don't want the catheter supported by your Johnson..You want a strap for that... A pair of baggy "sweat pants" to go home in..Elastic waist, no belt.. You will meet your anesthesiologist just before the surgery..Ask him to be careful of your vocal cords when he inserts the breathing tube..I talked like Donald Duck for two weeks.. Your appetite may be lacking for a while..

Posts.Title: Transurethra Biopsy-- how accurate are they?

Posts.Content: Here is how I see it..In most countries, if all prostate cancers are detected and treated, the costs of providing this treatment soon get out of hand..By withholding PSA testing, a huge cost savings is realized... They justify this by saying: "Even if millions of prostate cancers are allowed to run their course undetected and untreated, the overall mortality rate of males, statistically, does not change at all. Overall, it makes no difference in males lifespans whether these cancers are detected and treated or not detected and treated...." My reply is, well, it may not make any difference to the male population as a whole, but as an individual who is but a tiny, insignificant part of that population, PSA testing can make a HUGE difference in how long you live and in how well you live...If cost control is a must, that can be accomplished without denial of service..

Posts.Title: Father recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Antibiotics treat prostate infections, not tumors..The reduction from 75 to 70cc is insignificant, don't worry about that.. The chances are good he has had PC for many years. That's why PSA screening every year or two is so important, so you find it at the very beginning when it's much more treatable..Every male should get a PSA test at the age of 45 or 50 to establish a base line, a reading that is "normal" for him. Then as the years go by, a PSA velocity can be established, the rate at which the level is increasing. This way, any suspicious changes are very easy to spot before things get out of hand..

AgeInfo.Phrase: test at the age of 45 or 50 to establish a
the age of 45 or 50 to establish a base line

Posts.Title: Please help

Posts.Content: It IS possible to have a very high PSA number and not have prostate cancer..My urologist has two patients with PSA readings in the hundreds, multiple biopsies including saturation biopsies and no cancer found. So it IS possible..But their prostates are much larger than 70cc...In most cases with a PSA that high, the cause is prostate cancer. In it's early stages it causes no symptoms. You will just have to sweat it out until all the tests come back. There will be a bone scan, some X-rays, maybe a MRI and CAT scan. These tests will look for signs that the cancer may have spread beyond the prostate. The results of the biopsy, the Gleason score it reveals, and the results of the other tests I mentioned will allow his doctors to recommend a treatment program that will be the most effective for him...Do not jump to conclusions that this is a death sentence. It is not. This cancer is very treatable, generally slow-growing, most men live with it for many years.. A good book on the subject is "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" by Dr. Patrick Walsh..Any library or book store or eBay/Amazon..

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Therapy in Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: A third biopsy is probably called for at this time...I would ask for a "saturation biopsy" which takes more samples and reaches places the standard trans-rectal biopsy can not. It is performed differently, in a hospital under general anesthesia.. Some Urologists like to perform a "T-3 MRI" before the biopsy to try and locate any possible cancer beforehand so the biopsy needles can be targeted more accurately...Your urologist may want to put you on antibiotics to rule the chance infection is causing the rapid PSA rise....The squeaky hinge gets the oil...Start squeaking....Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: At what stage does PC spread

Posts.Content: Starting ADT early or late makes little difference in how long you will survive....Some men postpone ADT as long as possible in order to maintain quality of life as long as possible..To many men, the side-effects associated with Hormone Treatment are worse than the problems the cancer may cause....Those without medical insurance may not be able to pay for ADT other than castration (the standard treatment outside Western countries) and they simply reject that treatment out-of-hand...

Posts.Content: You might ask how old their equipment is..There have been tremendous advances in LINAC technology over the last few years. One of the newest is the Varian RapidArc machine.. Faster, more accurate, less collateral damage allows the highest possible dose to be given without compromising safety... Radiation treatment is $100K and up...So get ready for some sales pressure.... At this point in your journey, PC staging is 50% guesswork so don't put too much faith or stock in that. What counts is your PSA level 3 years from now...

Posts.Title: For EBRT, what's best? For Brachy Minimize Symptoms

Posts.Content: First, have your uro send your biopsy slides to Dr. Epstein @ Johns-Hopkins for a second opinion..it's important to get this right...PSA velocity is just as important as the actual number..Between 8/15 and 5/17 yours took a big jump, pointing to trouble especially with the abnormal DRE...Surgery was once called the "Gold Standard" because it worked the best, produced the highest cure rate....But radiation has come a LONG way over the past 10 years..Today, it equals and in many cases betters the results achieved by surgery...Especially when brachytherapy (seeds) are combined with beam radiation..With surgery, any negative side-effects are delivered immediately... With radiation, the side effects tend to come on slowly several years after treatment..Regardless of what form of treatment you choose, find the best doctors you can to carry it out..Their skills can vary considerably.. You might consult with a Medical Oncologist..They have seen it all and they know who the good guys are. Their opinions can be VERY helpful...

Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: You need to find out 2 numbers. His PSA number and his Gleason score when he was first diagnosed. A Urologist usually does this. You could locate this doctor, explain the situation, and ask for that basic information without going through any legal formalities.. If his PSA was over 20 and his Gleason score was 8, 9 or 10 his cancer may have been aggressive and incurable right from the start...Also a factor, did he have medical insurance when he was first diagnosed? Unfortunately, for many people, this determines what type of treatment will be available to them...

Be sure the RO you choose has plenty of experience with prostate patients and has access to the latest equipment (LINACS) used to administer the radiation treatment.. If you have not yet consulted with a Medical Oncologist now might be a good time to do so, even if your urologist / surgeon disagrees. Ask HIM (the MO) who might be the best R.O. around...Don't be surprised if these actions puts you into a certain degree of conflict with the urologist surgeon as these three specialists compete with each other for patients...A good Urologist will welcome your desire to seek other opinions...

Posts.Content: Hello SUL, We know this is a rough time for you...Hang in there Brother...Where does your Dad live / Where is he being treated ? How old is he? Posts.Title: psa went to 14 from 8.9 in 6 months

Posts.Content: One, you have plenty of time to consider ALL your options..Don't let anyone rush you into anything... One point to consider...The needle biopsy found some cancer in your prostate gland...But needle biopsies can not be counted on to have discovered ALL the cancer that may be present..Prostate cancer tends to be multi-focal, there is usually more than one tumor developing at any given time....While your biopsy points to a very early stage there is a 30% chance of more advanced disease..Further testing can narrow this down before you submit to a radical prostatectomy.. No one has yet mentioned the the need for a second opinion on your biopsy slides...Most of the time, the findings are strong enough so this step is not necessary but when a small amount of Gleason 6 is the basis for a cancer diagnosis, you want to be SURE the pathology report is accurate because you and your doctors will be basing your treatment on what the biopsy revealed. So it's very important these findings are correct..There are two "expert" pathology labs that specialize in analyzing prostate biopsies. Epstien at Johns-Hopkins and Bostwick Labs. Ask your urologist to arrange for the second opinion at one of these labs...

Posts.Title: Biopsy is positive for cancer ... now what?

Posts.Content: In the States, you can ask for and MUST be given a printed copy of your pathology report.. After all we paid for those tests and reports......You might ask for a printed copy of the post surgery pathology report.. Here radiation is seldom if ever started before 3 months have passed since surgery. The radiation will slow down or stop completely the healing and recovery process so they wait until most of the healing has taken place....

Posts.Content: In your case, I would not start ANY treatment until I had an expert second opinion on your biopsy slides...Before you submit to cancer treatment, you want to be 100% sure you HAVE cancer....Most of the time, there is no question about it and a second reading of the slides is a waste of time and money but in your case, I would have an expert pathologist who specializes in reading prostate tissue slides take a look...

Posts.Title: Meeting with the URO next Friday for TX options

Posts.Content: Yours is an interesting case..59 years old, multiple biopsies, PSA 31 and they finally find a G-7 tumor.....I would be asking a lot of questions about the reason for the high PSA number. I don't think the cancer they found accounts for that high a number...Now it IS possible to have a high PSA value and have no cancer at all, but it's highly unusual..But you might be one of those guys...But I would press your doctors about it, especially if your upcoming scans are negative..For what it's worth, I would favor surgery too if the scans are clean...Maybe you could post a few more details about your biopsy report..How many cores were positive, the percentage of cancer in each positive core, that kind of stuff... Best of luck to you, keep your chin up, you CAN beat this thing !

Posts.Title: PSA rising after prostatectomy

Posts.Content: " I'm not there yet, but is there anything I can be doing to slow down the PSA doubling time? I started drinking pomegranate juice and just ordered several antioxidants (Lycopene and Resveratrol Defense + Vitamin C). I also increased my Omega-3 fish oil to 1000 mg daily. My urologist isn't into supplements and I just want to do everything I can to slow the cancer down before radiation is recommended. Let me know your views and anything else I might try. Thanks. " It was the OP who brought the subject up.. I agree with Mikla that dropping the US-PSA test would be a good first step in relieving his anxiety..Doing full pelvic radiation with any cancers actual location based on guesswork is not very effective treatment IMHO......With the standard PSA test, the need for further treatment will be known soon enough and at this point it might be possible to localize the location of the problem and focus treatment on that area....In the OP's case, a very localized G-6 cancer removed with 100% clean margins, perhaps moving on to SRT sooner rather than later is justified as any cancer is probably located in the pelvic area..

Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: Radiation treatment still offers you the possibility of a cure...If you wait too long, that opportunity is lost..The LINACS used today by most hospitals are MUCH improved over the equipment they were using just 10 years ago when most of the radiation horror stories were written. They can pinpoint their target and avoid damage to healthy tissue much better than in the past. You owe it to yourself to at least talk to a Radiation Oncologist about Salvage Radiation..It's not the horror show it once was..They might want to put you on HT for 12 months or so along with the radiation..The combined treatment works considerably better than either one alone..For sure it's no fun but it's better than dying..

Posts.Title: PSA rising (slowly) after prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Call the pathologist and ask HIM what that means...But overall, it sounds pretty good...Success is very hard to predict...Nothing you can do about it now so just relax and don't worry about it...You can start feeling confident five years from now..If you join the zero club (PSA 0.0) and stay in it for 3 years, have a big party and forget prostate cancer......Best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: Some confusion about post-surgery pathology report

Posts.Content: MRI's are wrong 30% of the time and because of this, many doctors have little faith in them..There are a handful of Urologists that use a Color Doppler Ultrasound machine to guide their biopsies and they seldom miss any cancer if cancer is present..Others use a saturation biopsy (40 cores) if they suspect cancer after a standard 12 core biopsy fails to find it..Many of us have endured multiple biopsies before our cancer is found...

Posts.Title: Simple Biopsy Report

Posts.Content: Once salvage radiation fails, you will be put on ADT for the duration..Even after IT fails, they will keep you on it. The thinking is that even after you become refractory, the cancer progressing, it will progress much slower if ADT is maintained..Besides, administering ADT is a profit center for the Docs..When you become refractory, they may try one of the newer drugs, Xtandi or Zytiga, which can produce a nice remission even at this late stage...Now, they are doing chemo first (instead of last) after trials have shown chemo is more effective if used earlier..Sadly, even with all this, there is no cure once the horse leaves the barn...

Posts.Title: Dry Orgasms

Posts.Content: Lots of things can cause vertigo but prostate cancer is seldom one of them...Your doctor should be able to isolate the cause of your vertigo (it's a fairly common complaint) and take care of it... Now, back to your prostate cancer..There are two numbers that play an important role in how you will be treated..Your PSA number and your Gleason score... Anyway, welcome to the forum..There are a lot of great people here who can and will help you get through this..Learn everything you can, Dr. Walsh's book mentioned above in the sticky threads is a good place to start...Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: I was wondering if anyone else experienced this as a symptom of Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Starting ADT early or late makes little difference in how long you will survive....Some men postpone ADT as long as possible in order to maintain quality of life as long as possible..To many men, the side-effects associated with Hormone Treatment are worse than the problems the cancer may cause....Those without medical insurance may not be able to pay for ADT other than castration (the standard treatment outside Western countries) and they simply reject that treatment out-of-hand...
Posts.Title: At what stage does PC spread

Posts.Content: "They" don't decide...YOU decide...You and the rest of the family..This usually happens when he can no longer be cared for by family members..There are several other organizations that can help with providing care at home and take some of the load off the family...Also, the side-effects from the HT drugs might have been overstated here. None of us are doctors..A second opinion on whether that might be a viable treatment at his age should be sought before you rule it out completely. None of us here really know your Dad's situation.
Posts.Title: Lupron

Posts.Content: + 2 for Ron G's answer....A second opinion is not likely to find anything that will change your treatment decisions...And regardless what you read in "Invasion Of The Prostate Snatchers" AS is just not an option for you...The author of that book, Ralph Blum, has another best seller, "The Book Of Runes"...So if you are into fortune telling and magic, this is your guy......But if you want to cure your cancer, I'd find the best surgeon available to you....

Posts.Title: Reluctant new member questions, including second opinion on biopsy and stage of PC

Posts.Content: Many of us have signed up for Medicare Advantage plans offered by all the major health insurance companies..These plans usually provide lower deductibles than the standard Medicare coverage does...
Posts.Title: Important non-political Information for Medicare Patients.

Posts.Content: Most journeys have a beginning, a middle part and an end...I'm writing this down while I still can remember the details with some degree of accuracy...At age 55, my health insurance family plan (I was self employed), always expensive, doubled in price, making it unaffordable for my wife and I to maintain. That was 20 years ago....I had a complete physical as a precaution before I canceled the insurance, everything was fine but my doctor voiced some concern over my PSA number which was 3.5, something like that..The DRE was fine....So over the next 9 years I did get the occasional PSA test, usually at a free screening or health fair...The number went up very slowly, not enough to trigger any concern. Then, at age 64.5, at another free prostate cancer screening the Uro listed my DRE as "abnormal" and the PSA came back 6.8.. He said I should "see my doctor" about further investigation..I had spent a lot of time investigating what form of Medicare to choose, so many choices, finally I chose one recommended by my family doctor, a Medicare Advantage Plan run by United Health care and accepted by my family doctor..The day my membership card arrived I made an appointment to see him, he referred me to a Urology clinic where they quickly scheduled me for a biopsy. It came back negative ! I was off the hook ! But the urologist cautioned me, something is going on, we need to watch it. I also had a mild case of BPE so he put me on Finasteride which, as expected, lowered my PSA by half, down to 4.5 or so. A year went by, PSA started moving up a little, another biopsy, again no cancer but there was some high-grade PIN..Nine more months pass, more concern, the Uro wanted a third biopsy, I resisted but finally agreed, this time he really was aggressive with the wand and the results came back positive in 4 cores, two were G-6, one G-7 and one G-9... This was nine years ago, going on ten....Back then, in Denver, I had 2 choices, surgery or radiation..One of the partners at the Urology clinic was a top notch surgeon with a good reputation who actually taught other urologists how to perform the surgery using the then fairly new da Vinci surgical robot . He tried to talk me out of having surgery, saying that G-9 cases like mine could only expect a 50-50 chance of a cure. At that time radiation offered about the same odds.. I chose surgery anyway, 50% being better than nothing and I always could fall back on radiation if necessary...The actual surgery went well, although it resulted in a nasty staph infection that put me back in the hospital for a week, then a month of IV antibiotics at home..First post surgery PSA came back 0.9 Ouch ! Nine months passed while I healed/ recovered from the surgery while I searched for the best R.O. I could find. I found one who was the director of radiology at a big local hospital that had just installed the latest Varian LINAC Rapid Arc I did 40 fractions SRT + ADT He wanted 2 years ADT but after 18 months of undetectable PSA checks he relented and my active treatment ended. Two more years went by with undetectable PSA tests, things were looking good.....Then the monster came back....Back on ADT, Lupron only, PSA went undetectable again for almost 2 years. When PSA again was detected, Casodex was added, and PSA again dropped to undetectable.. A single bone met was found in a neck vertebra, my R.O. gave it 5 shots of SBRT and it disappeared..PSA back to undetectable (all PSA's using the standard assay). About a year later, PSA returned and Zytiga replaced the Casodex. At this point I was no longer seeing any urologists, relying on a young, aggressive M.O. instead. I had a nice remission with the Zytiga, almost two years undetectable or at least less than 1.0.. Late last year the Zytiga stopped working, switched to Xtandi, got a fair but short-lived response. PSA moving up rapidly now..It was 54 two weeks ago... Two years ago, I was seen by a VA oncologist. I needed to do this in order to have the VA supply the Zytiga and Xtandi which even with Part D Medicare I could not afford those co-pays and doughnut holes..I got to like and trust the VA doctor. Both my Medicare oncologist and my VA oncologist agree chemo (Docetaxel) is my next step. Since Quality of Life takes a huge step backwards with this, I have been resisting implementing it, hoping one of the new immunotherapy treatments became available. Yes, I know about Provenge but it's not available through the VA and my Medicare doctor has little faith in it, especially considering its cost. It's very hard to walk into the Chemo Lounge when you have no symptoms and let them push a bag of poison into your veins knowing it will make you sick as hell.. So that's pretty much my journey so far..I just thought I would share it with everyone..I have learned so much from the guys who are on the same journey, thank you all.... Fairwind...

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: At this point, perhaps his primary doctor, the one directing his treatment, should be a Medical Oncologist not a Urologist....There are new, advanced drugs and treatments but they are very expensive and can be hard to get access to..A non prescription supplement, Pomi-T, has shown it can slow down the cancer progression somewhat..It's cheap and can't hurt.....
Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome to our not so little group Tom.... First Pick up a copy of Dr. Pat Walsh's book, "Surviving Prostate Cancer" and learn exactly what you are facing.. Also know that the 3 medical specialists involved here (Urologist, Oncologist and Radiation Oncologist) will all favor their own form of treatment...It will be up to YOU to separate the wheat from the chaff....The PSA38 usually means surgery can no longer cure your cancer no matter what the scans reveal...But it CAN remove 95-98% of it thus making the sure to follow radiation treatment much more likely to produce a cure...Many will argue this point, saying surgery would be a waste of time and will expose you to needless risks and side-effects..It will up to you to decide that. Your Radiation Oncologist (you will meet him soon enough) may feel his treatment is all you need, that surgery first would be a waste of time and money...But your Urologist who is also likely a surgeon may have a different outlook.....So read the book (Walsh is a surgeon) research the 'Net and do what you feel is right for you...While your cancer is somewhat advanced it's by no means hopeless. You will learn more as the test results come in and you make your treatment choices..You CAN beat this. You make up your mind based on facts and knowledge and do it. And you never look back.....Again, welcome to the club and the best of luck to you...

But if THEY had been diagnosed with terminal cancer, I bet they would not be so quick to reject natural or off-patent treatments and drugs...The drug industry is not interested in anything they can not get a patent on and proclaim to their stock-holders they have discovered a new billion dollar a year drug... So does Pomegranate and IP-6 extend the life of prostate cancer patients? The Brits seem to think so with their Pomi-T formulation..But in this country, unless it costs $100,000 a pop, it can't possibly work.... http://www.pomi-t.com/asco-pomi-t-study-summary/

Posts.Title: Herbal Supplement Could Outperform Observation in Recurrent Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Not all surgeons are created equal...If you choose surgery, and can get your insurance company to agree, I would seek out a recognized expert to perform the surgery..This is easier said than done..Another form of radiation treatment, Brachytherapy, and brachy combined with external beam can deliver results equal or better than surgery with less side-effect risk..Again, seek out the best doctors you can find and can afford... One other thing to consider..Your G-6 biopsy puts you in low risk, few men ever die from this category..But unless the prostate is removed and the entire gland biopsied, you can't be SURE there is not some higher grade cancer lurking..It is not unusual for pathology reports to be changed to a more threatening form of PC when the organ is removed and examined closely. With radiation, you have to take that needle biopsy at face value and hope for the best and the majority of the time, that's fine... Winning the battle against prostate cancer by Dr. G. Chodak is an up to date book that explains all the treatment options and favors none. Just the facts.....Dr. Walsh's book is more detailed but he is a surgeon so it slants that way a little...Making this decision is the toughest part. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: billc

Posts.Content: How old is your dad? When he was diagnosed in January, what was his PSA level and Gleason score? Hormone therapy, when administered by a medical oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer can be very effective..A few natural remedies like pomegranate, turmeric and aspirin have been shown to slow the growth and spread of PC....Zytiga is another powerful new weapon against PC...
Posts.Title: Any success stories with alternative treatments? Please, this is for my father

Posts.Content: A PSA of 2.7 would be considered normal for a 72 year old..How did they detect the cancer and do a biopsy? Probably an abnormal DRE.... One of the people you talk to should be a good Radiation Oncologist who has access to modern equipment..Chances are his treatment will begin with hormone treatment followed shortly by radiation treatment..This treatment can be curative...Personally, I don't think surgery is a good option here.. Not long ago, the standard radiation dose was 72 greys given in 40 fractions..Recently, using the new equipment, they have been able to cut the fractions down to 20 or 25, making the procedure a lot less tedious.. You should see if the RO you select is willing and able to use it. It's called "Hypofractionated Radiation Therapy"

Posts.Title: What's Next After Zytiga

Posts.Content: EBRT treatment for PC is changing rapidly. The X-ray machine (LINAC) that delivers the radiation are today greatly improved over what was in use just a few years ago..The need to use 40 fractions to safely deliver an effective dose of radiation has in most cases been reduced to around 20 fractions. Most of the newer LINAC's can be set up to deliver SBRT which requires even fewer fractions to deliver an effective dose. Treatment protocols and techniques are changing rapidly, resulting in more effective treatments and fewer side effects and far less damage to surrounding healthy tissue..So choose a RO who has been trained in the new procedures and has access to up to date equipment..While proton radiation is sometimes used to treat prostate cancer, after several studies could not find any real benefit to using this form of radiation to treat PC, and insurance balked about paying for it, most PC is treated with photon (X-ray) beam radiation. So choose your Radiation Oncologist with the same care you would use to choose a surgeon....

Posts.Title: Need some advice, guidance and\or feedback on my recent issue

Posts.Content: The grade "4" sample means AS would be pretty risky.. If it were me, I would have it treated with curative intent..The URO will recommend surgery because that's what he does...But I would talk to a Radiation Oncologist and see what he has to offer..Then YOU decide what's best for you...Don't overlook brachytherapy (seeds). Not all RO's can provide that treatment..

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: After surgery, the Gleason score on the post surgery pathology report 30% of the time finds the cancer is worse than reported by the biopsy report...Being downgraded from a G-6 or 7 to a G-8 or 9 is not that uncommon.....But getting a second opinion at an expert lab would certainly rule out any errors...Your insurance company might squawk about paying for it...

Posts.Title: Is second opinion for pathology need post surgery?

Posts.Content: At 78 years, Dad may indeed have PC...But treating it could very well cause more problems than the cancer will ever cause him..His PSA is well within the normal range for a 78 year old with an enlarged prostate..His urologist may prescribe Avodart, a mild form of hormone therapy, which will shrink his prostate and relieve the urination problems and also suppress any possible prostate cancer without introducing any severe side-effects...Usually, this drug will cut his PSA number in half.. Dad's going to be fine. Focus your attension on your Mom....Best of luck to you and your family...

Posts.Title: PSA doubled

Posts.Content: I have never heard it claimed that the PSA test could diagnose prostate cancer..No matter how high your PSA reading, that does not automatically mean you have Prostate Cancer...All it does is it gives an indication that you are at MUCH higher risk of having prostate cancer and that further testing would be advisable if you wish to find this cancer while it is still curable..Or, just as likely, rule out the possibility you have PC... Dr. Albin states the PSA test has a 80% false positive rate, making it useless for detecting prostate cancer..But the PSA test SHOULD NEVER BE USED FOR DETECTING PROSTATE CANCER so it can't possibly have an 80% false positive rate. Only a BIOPSY can detect prostate cancer with 100% accuracy.. A PSA test is just a tool that points out a biopsy might be a good idea...In the past, men had to wait until a abnormal DRE triggered a biopsy..For many, that was too late...

Posts.Title: Interesting article/interview on the history of the PSA test

Posts.Content: Chasing the fountain of youth can put you in an early grave...I suppose if you want to see if your prostate surgery was really successful, that's one sure way to find out...
Posts.Title: Testosterone After PC Surgery

Posts.Content: CyberKnife, a form of external beam radiation, has not been used very much on prostate cancer so there are few if any studies that can provide information about how effective it is...If hype could cure cancer, then Cyber-Knife would be the sure winner...You see this form of treatment promoted on highway billboards and radio spots during sports broadcasts..Dr. Gerald Chodak's book, "Winning the battle......." gives unbiased, up to date treatment options along with all the statistical details..

Posts.Title: CyberKnife or robotic radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: It is my understanding that your biopsy slides will already be stained as a result of the first pathology examination...Perhaps a different pathologist will want them stained again using different dyes... In any case, you don't want to bet your life on the results of a single needle biopsy..When patients choose surgery and the entire prostate is removed and biopsied, 30% of the time the pathology is changed to a higher grade of cancer..The TRUS biopsy can easily miss a high-grade tumor giving a false sense of security..

Posts.Title: When A Pathologist Orders Stains

Posts.Content: There are dozens of products like TBL-12 (sea cucumber extract) that claim to cure cancer...Save your money and stick with treatments that been proven to work... Two books for you to read. Surviving prostate cancer by Dr. Pat Walsh and Winning the battle against prostate cancer by Dr. Gerald Chodak. This will give you the background information you need to make an intelligent treatment choice..

Posts.Title: Testosterone Recovery Time following ADT

Posts.Content: Yours is an interesting case..59 years old, multiple biopsies, PSA 31 and they finally find a G-7 tumor.....I would be asking a lot of questions about the reason for the high PSA number. I don't think the cancer they found accounts for that high a number...Now it IS possible to have a high PSA value and have no cancer at all, but it's highly unusual..But you might be one of those guys...But I would press your doctors about it, especially if your upcoming scans are negative..For what it's worth, I would favor surgery too if the scans are clean...Maybe you could post a few more details about your biopsy report..How many cores were positive, the percentage of cancer in each positive core, that kind of stuff... Best of luck to you, keep your chin up, you CAN beat this thing !

Posts.Title: Diagnosis.....anxiety, depression......

Posts.Content: Catheter came out in 7 or 10 days and I was continent from that moment....I experienced no incontinence at all..What really helped me to recover quickly was WALKING...Even when still wearing the leg-bag I would get out and walk a mile or so. Do what ever you can comfortably do..Laying in the recliner and watching TV is the worst thing you can do...You need to get your bowels and everything else moving again....Don't urinate until you really MUST urinate. Your bladder gets lazy with the catheter so you need to stretch it back out and increase its ability to hold more urine..This may take a few weeks to get back to 3-4 hour intervals. Drink plenty of water..

Posts.Title: 1st post SRT PSA

Posts.Content: Radiation and surgery have very similar "cure" rates...Much depends on the skill and experience of those providing the treatment...Brachy is a VERY specialized skill, sometimes you must travel to find an expert in this field...Not all RO's feel comfortable doing brachy and therefore they do not recommend it.. The machines that deliver the radiation are called LINAC's, linear accelerators. Over the last few years, great improvements have been made in these machines but a large number of the older ones are still in use... One of the up to date machines is called a Varian RapidArc. You should at least be aware of the age of the machine you will be treated on...The new ones can hit their intended target with great accuracy while limiting the dose delivered to healthy tissue..This can allow a higher (more effective) dose to be delivered to the tumor.. High-dose radiation treatment is NOT without its risks and side-effects..Some occur fairly soon, during and shortly after treatment..Urinary frequency, urgency, bowel problems, fatigue all may appear during treatment...Three years out, impotency becomes an issue for 50% of those treated, same as surgery...Should you be "cured", 10-15 years out, secondary cancers and other problems caused by tissue damage may surface..by this time you are 70-75 years old and treatment becomes difficult. Different forms of radiation treatment, proton for instance, claim to deliver effective treatment while greatly limiting side-effects..But again, at the 3 year milepost, they have great difficulty in backing up those claims.. The good news is very few men ever die from Gleason 6 prostate cancer..Whatever treatment you choose will work equally well..Having your "T" drop to 16 is a benefit as it will make the radiation work better..It will take your testicles a couple of months to "get back on the job" after the 12 year vacation they have had. That's something you might want to monitor closely for a while..You don't need a big "T" bounce right now... Your RO might want to put you on a different kind of hormone therapy for a while to keep the "T" level low.. Best of luck to you and Merry Christmas!

Posts.Title: IMRT for Treatment - New to Club

Posts.Content: CyberKnife, a form of external beam radiation, has not been used very much on prostate cancer so there are few if any studies that can provide information about how effective it is...If hype could cure cancer, then Cyber-Knife would be the sure winner...You see this form of treatment promoted on highway billboards and radio spots during sports broadcasts..Dr. Gerald Chodak's book, "Winning the battle......." gives unbiased, up to date treatment options along with all the statistical details..

Posts.Title: CyberKnife or robotic radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: You should read Dr. Walsh's book and learn a little more about what is going on...Also, in my opinion, urologists are working outside their knowledge and training when they start prescribing drugs like Lupron and Casodex. You would be doing yourself a favor by making an appointment to to see a Medical Oncologist. Your primary care doctor can help you with this...Hormone therapy is SERIOUS business that comes with major side-effects...Don't let them stick that needle in you unless you know EXACTLY what you are getting into....

Posts.Title: Cialis cost ....

Posts.Content: I have never heard it claimed that the PSA test could diagnose prostate cancer..No matter how high your PSA reading, that does not automatically mean you have Prostate Cancer...All it does is it gives an indication that you are at MUCH higher risk of having prostate cancer and that further testing would be advisable if you wish to find this cancer while it is still curable..Or, just as likely, rule out the possibility you have PC... Dr. Albin states the PSA test has a 80% false positive rate, making it useless for detecting prostate cancer..But the PSA test SHOULD NEVER BE USED FOR DETECTING PROSTATE CANCER so it can't possibly have an 80% false positive rate. Only a BIOPSY can detect prostate cancer with 100% accuracy.. A PSA test is just a tool that points out a biopsy might be a good idea...In the past, men had to wait until a abnormal DRE triggered a biopsy..For many, that was too late...

Posts.Title: Friday afternoon off-topic

Posts.Content: Having a biopsy is certainly warranted in your situation...The Avodart can be expected to cut your PSA reading in half, so it's safe to assume your TRUE PSA is closer to 10 or 11 and that means a biopsy...Speculating whether or not you will test positive for prostate cancer serves no purpose and just increases your already high anxiety level.. But education never hurts so pick up a copy of Dr Walsh's book "How to survive prostate cancer" and learn what you might be facing..Since virtually all men get prostate cancer sooner or later, learning about it now will keep you a step ahead of it....

Posts.Title: Help with lab results

Posts.Content: At 78 years, Dad may indeed have PC...But treating it could very well cause more problems than the cancer will ever cause him..His PSA is well within the normal range for a 78 year old with an enlarged prostate..His urologist may prescribe Avodart, a mild form of hormone therapy, which will shrink his prostate and relieve the urination problems and also suppress any possible prostate cancer without introducing any severe side-effects...Usually, this drug will cut his PSA number in half.. Dad's going to be fine. Focus your attension on your Mom....Best of luck to you and your family...

Posts.Title: Need some advice, guidance and\or feedback on my recent issue

Posts.Content: The Lupron injection will cause a brief spike in your testosterone level, which is counter-productive when treating PC. So you may be taking a drug called Casodex for a couple of weeks to nullify the "T" bounce associated with beginning Lupron. After two weeks your "T" level will plunge to almost zero and the Casodex is no longer needed....

Posts.Title: Hi guys

Posts.Content: PC is multi-focal.. When the entire gland is examined after it has been removed, there is a average of 7 separate and distinct tumors found. These individual tumors can be of different Gleason grades..So later on it might look like a G-6 tumor has progressed into a grade 4, G-8 tumor, what really happens is the higher grade tumor was missed during the needle biopsy. With the standard 12 core needle biopsy, 30% of the time, a more aggressive, higher grade tumor goes undetected...it's not that a indolent G-6 grade 3 tumor progressed into a more threatening G-7..The higher grade tumor was there all the time, undiscovered.. That's why guys doing A.S. have to keep a sharp eye on things in case their tumors are not as harmless as they think...

Posts.Title: Maybe, maybe not? Whats up?

Posts.Content: There is a BIG difference in the LINACS (the machines that produce and deliver the radiation...I would insist on a Varian Rapid-Arc or its equivalent.. Something less than 5 years old....The newer machines do a much better job at limiting damage to healthy tissue..Just as important is the skill of the Radiation Oncologist who is writing your treatment program, giving the machine its instructions...This is a $100,000 procedure, don't settle for being treated on obsolete equipment even if you must travel to get the best....While ADT (added to boost the radiation treatment) is indeed unpleasant, it might be worth looking into as your pathology is less then ideal.....

AgeInfo.Phrase: its equivalent   Something less than 5 years old    The newer machines

Posts.Title: Rising PSA (again) post RP - questions

Posts.Content: As long as there was no adjunct HT used as part of your salvage treatment then yes, PSA 0.0 (usually written >0.01) is your goal. The radiation never "wears off" If it fails, it's because a few stray cancer cells escaped the treatment..It would take many doubling's before any tiny micro-mets make themselves known....Some men and their Oncologists choose the untra-sensitive PSA test which is 100 times as sensitive as the standard test but that last digit tends to bounce around causing a lot of stress and unnecessary anxiety..
Posts.Title: Longevity of Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Sapporo...Maybe you could put together a brief "Signature" to add to your posts so everyone would know your treatment history... Only a few types of PC can spread without leaving a substantial PSA marker..But if you have had recent surgery and these are your last 3 PSA tests, then yes, a visit with a Radiation Oncologist to discuss Salvage Radiation treatment might be in order..Bone scans, at least the ones insurance companies are willing to pay for, seldom show anything until the PSA is north of 50 or so....I would let the R/O make the decision on whether a bone scan would be worthwhile at this point...

Posts.Title: CT scan and DRE shows issue with my prostate, confused

Posts.Content: I think you would want the incontinence issue resolved before you start any R/T. The radiation tends to freeze any further improvement with the incontinence..Since your cancer was low risk, I would wait for those 3 and 6 month PSA readings before I seriously considered R/T..As long as the PSA comes back undetectable, I would take a wait and see approach... If, in the end, you decide R/T is needed, find the best R/O you can, one who has access to the newest radiation equipment that is capable of treating the prostate bed without administering a high dose to the colon and rectum..

Posts.Title: Meeting with the URO next Friday for TX options

Posts.Title: Why Does It Cost So Much??

Posts.Content: Sarg hit the nail on the head..."For what it is worth, I just figured up the totals for my Da-Vinci. Charged total $94,873.00, Insurance negotiated - Paid Total $15,534.00, and out of pocket was $435.00." If you have no insurance, you are looking at $95,000 and they won't budge off that figure..But they will happily perform the same services for $15,500 if that's all insured patients companies , including Medicare, will pay.....That's an outrage..If the price is $15,000 then that's the price...Charging cash customers $95,000 for the same treatment should be illegal..It's not like the big hospitals were all going broke and closing...On the contrary, the new hospitals all have that cost-no-object look to them...The whole medical services system is set up so that as many people as possible make as much money as possible..
Posts.Title: Why Does It Cost So Much??

Posts.Content: Gleason 8, Psa 5.3 While that's not the best news in the world, it's probably curable or at least survivable for many years..This is not going to be a walk in the park, the treatments come with some heavy side-effects and can be very expensive..Find out what your insurance covers and what it doesn't. Get pre-approvals for any treatment. In making the choice of what treatment to pursue, another book, "Winning the Battle against Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Gerald Chodak presents all the treatments in an unbiased manner and is up to date.. A typical treatment plan, you do surgery (pick the best surgeon you can find) and if the margins are clear and his PSA drops to undetectable after 6 weeks, chances are you beat it and you are done..If the cancer has spread to the surgical margin, you are not done. Radiation can be used to clean up after the surgeon. This is called "salvage radiation"..It succeeds (produces a cure) about 50% of the time...The radiation can be combined with Hormone Therapy, HT, increasing it's effectiveness substantially but subjecting your husband to heavy side-effects.. That's enough for one night, read the books and talk it over and make your choices...

Posts.Title: Newbie's wife.

Posts.Content: Catheter came out in 7 or 10 days and I was continent from that moment....I experienced no incontinence at all..What really helped me to recover quickly was WALKING...Even when still wearing the leg-bag I would get out and walk a mile or so. Do what ever you can comfortably do..Laying in the recliner and watching TV is the worst thing you can do...You need to get your bowels and everything else moving again....Don't urinate until you really MUST urinate. Your bladder gets lazy with the catheter so you need to stretch it back out and increase its ability to hold more urine..This may take a few weeks to get back to 3-4 hour intervals. Drink plenty of water..

Posts.Title: Recovery from DaVinci Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: EBRT treatment for PC is changing rapidly. The X-ray machine (LINAC) that delivers the radiation are today greatly improved over what was in use just a few years ago..The need to use 40 fractions to safely deliver an effective dose of radiation has in most cases been reduced to around 20 fractions. Most of the newer LINAC's can be set up to deliver SBRT which requires even fewer fractions to deliver an effective dose. Treatment protocols and techniques are changing rapidly, resulting in more effective treatments and fewer side effects and far less damage to surrounding healthy tissue..So choose a RO who has been trained in the new procedures and has access to up to date equipment..While proton radiation is sometimes used to treat prostate cancer, after several studies could not find any real benefit to using this form of radiation to treat PC, and insurance balked about paying for it, most PC is treated with photon (X-ray) beam radiation. So choose your Radiation Oncologist with the same care you would use to choose a surgeon....

Posts.Title: Sticky: What I Need to Know About SBRT & IMRT

Posts.Content: KLA, before we can offer advise and help, you need to clarify your Gleason score.. Gleason 5 (3+2=5 or 2+3=5) is seldom if ever reported as being positive for cancer. Few if any urologists would recommend surgery...But if ONE of the grades in your Gleason score is a 5, (4+5=9) then that is serious. You can get a copy of your biopsy report from your doctor simply by asking for one. If you have indeed tested positive for PC, now would be a good time to read "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Patrick Walsh. Try and get the newest (third) edition..

Posts.Title: What's next?

Posts.Content: For what it's worth, MANY men seem to have sub-normal testosterone levels when they are diagnosed with PC. Few men get follow-up "T" testing after treatment..But since testosterone is fuel for prostate cancer, you need to be sure you are "cured" before you consider HRT, or boosting your T level by external means...Do your homework before you climb on the Androgel bandwagon....

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and sex drive

Posts.Content: Take it easy! G-9 is not a death sentence, not today....I was diagnosed G-9 five and a half years ago and I'm in full remission and enjoying my retirement...Pick up a copy of Pat Walsh's book and read it...The next step will be a series of tests to determine if your cancer is still localized or has it spread beyond the prostate gland. What is your PSA history? After these tests have been completed, THEN a course of treatment can be discussed with your doctors..Remember, every case is different, every case responds differently to treatment..Best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: Cancer Cure ?

Posts.Content: Urologists and Radiation Oncologists do indeed work and play golf together. But Medical Oncologists, whose specialty is treating cancer with drugs, are seldom invited to join in these activities...Call it friendly competition for the patients dollar. But they have insights you will not hear from the other two...The gold markers are one way to position you for the R/T but the latest LINAC's (radiation machines) no longer need them...For the $100,000 Medicare will be billed, you might as well be treated on the latest equipment..Am I a little cynical? Yes indeed....But I'm 3 years further along on this journey than you are... It's very important to establish good rapport and trust with your doctors..But if they balk at you getting second opinions (your life is on the line here) then they are not the wonderful people you think they are...The best doctors will welcome second opinions. It protects them and enhances their reputations if the second opinion agrees with them.. Do you have your own copy of your biopsy report? If not, ask for one. You paid for it, It's yours..Your Urologist should have no qualms about giving you a copy. Should you decide to get a second opinion from another doctor, bring that report with you as the doctor will need it...Best of luck to you and please let us know how your journey progresses..
