Posts.Title: Prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Some men get a very good response out of Xtandi even though they are hormone refractory..But obtaining this drug can be difficult because of its cost..Insurance companies find reasons not to cover it...Same thing with Provenge ..Twenty years ago, men with bone mets lasted an average of 5 years..10% went in a year, 10% more made it to the 10 year mark...Today, those numbers are being pushed more towards the 10 year end of the scale if the cancer is treated aggressively and by a doctor who is aware of and uses the latest treatments available.. An inexpensive supplement which has been proven to dramatically slow down the PSA doubling time is called Pomi-T ..Will it extend your husbands life? Who knows? But it can't hurt anything..Best of luck to you both....

Posts.Title: Nerve sparing robotic surgery

Posts.Content: It was the HT that pushed your PSA down to .02, not the radiation..Radiation treatment does not necessarily kill the prostate gland completely so it is quite possible your PSA could level off at 2 or 3 and remain there for years....You said your "oncologist" tried to put you back on HT but the insurance company squawked..Was that your Radiation Oncologist?? They should know that when radiation is the primary treatment, some residual PSA is quite normal as you still have a prostate gland... I would certainly get a second opinion on the appropriateness of going back on HT at this time..It is my understanding that it takes at least 2 years for PSA to stabilize after radiation treatment...This fact might have something to do with why the insurance company balked at re-starting the HT...Again, get a second opinion from a Radiation Oncologist.....

Posts.Title: rising psa post tri-modal treatment.

Posts.Content: My 40 treatments of IGRT (external beam) was performed at a nearby hospital, about 6 miles away..I was able to drive to and from these early morning appointments without any problems..Some people can do radiation with little or no side-effects. others have more pronounced reactions. Dad will meet with his R.O. at least once a week and discuss how things are going..near the end, #25 and up, there usually is some urinary urgency and frequency problems, but nothing major..The side-effects from the HT he is on are FAR more pronounced than the radiation will be.....Try to have Dad treated on a LINAC, the radiation machine, that is less than 5 years old, and certainly less that 10 years old...The newer machines do a better job at limiting side-effects and achieving better outcomes...

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - What to expect??

Posts.Content: Radiation "works" by damaging the DNA in the cancer cells so they can't reproduce..It does not kill all the cancer cells instantly. So PSA seldom plummets after R/T. Rather, there is a slow, steady decline to "nadir", some low point that remains stable for years...When R/T is used as a primary treatment, the prostate gland is still able to produce some small amount of PSA and this is what shows up on subsequent PSA tests. If it's used as salvage (trying to salvage a failed surgery) the prostate gland has (hopefully) been completely removed so there is no source of residual PSA..In other words, PSA should drop to zero or very near zero and stay there..When HT is added as an adjunct to radiation, PSA usually drops to a very low number very quickly and will stay there as long as the HT continues. This effect masks whether or not the R/T was effective..You don't really know until you are taken off the HT and the results of the radiation must then stand on their own..... One way to judge whether radiation worked or not, PSA should never rise above what it was before treatment started....If it does, the cancer is still active and further treatment may be necessary....

Posts.Title: Longevity of Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: As long as there was no adjunct HT used as part of your salvage treatment then yes, PSA 0.0 (usually written >0.01) is your goal. The radiation never "wears off" If it fails, it's because a few stray cancer cells escaped the treatment..It would take many doubling's before any tiny micro-mets make themselves known....Some men and their Oncologists choose the untra-sensitive PSA test which is 100 times as sensitive as the standard test but that last digit tends to bounce around causing a lot of stress and unnecessary anxiety..

Posts.Content: Some men get a very good response out of Xtandi even though they are hormone refractory..But obtaining this drug can be difficult because of its cost..Insurance companies find reasons not to cover it...Same thing with Provenge ..Twenty years ago, men with bone mets lasted an average of 5 years..10% went in a year, 10% more made it to the 10 year mark...Today, those numbers are being pushed more towards the 10 year end of the scale if the cancer is treated aggressively and by a doctor who is aware of and uses the latest treatments available.. Posts.Title: Concerned Prostate Wife

Posts.Content: You already know you have prostate cancer....Five years have passed.....You have had no active treatment. It's time for another biopsy, it's as simple as that...Active Surveillance is FINE in your case but a biopsy now and then is a part of Active Surveillance..This time, send the slides out to an expert lab that specializes in doing prostate pathology..Make SURE it's just a tiny spot of Gleason 6...Prostate cancer is tricky. There is usually more than just one tumor. Different tumors can have different Gleason scores...By avoiding a biopsy, you are betting your life you only have one small Gleason 6 tumor...Your PSA history seems to suggest that, nothing to worry about..But still....

Posts.Title: Medicinal Oils

Posts.Content: Sarg hit the nail on the head..."For what it is worth, I just figured up the totals for my Da-Vinci. Charged total $94,873.00, Insurance negotiated - Paid Total $15,534.00, and out of pocket was $435.00." If you have no insurance, you are looking at $95,000 and they won't budge off that figure..But they will happily perform the same services for $15,500 if that's all insured patients companies , including Medicare, will pay.....That's an outrage..If the price is $15,000 then that's the price...Charging cash customers $95,000 for the same treatment should be illegal..It's not like the big hospitals were all going broke and closing...On the contrary, the new hospitals all have that cost-no-object look to them...The whole medical services system is set up so that as many people as possible make as much money as possible..
Posts.Title: Why Does It Cost So Much??

Posts.Content: At this point, your lead doctor should be a Medical Oncologist not a Urologist..Firmagone and Lupron do the same thing. The firmagone just costs more, especially on a monthly schedule...Your side-effects will probably not change...The side effects are just part of the package with Hormone Treatment...

Posts.Title: Thoughts on my Hormone Treatment

Posts.Content: Gleason 8, Psa 5.3 While that's not the best news in the world, it's probably curable or at least survivable for many years..This is not going to be a walk in the park, the treatments come with some heavy side-effects and can be very expensive..Find out what your insurance covers and what it doesn't. Get pre-approvals for any treatment. In making the choice of what treatment to pursue, another book, "Winning the Battle against Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Gerald Chodak presents all the treatments in an unbiased manner and is up to date.. A typical treatment plan, you do surgery (pick the best surgeon you can find) and if the margins are clear and his PSA drops to undetectable after 6 weeks, chances are you beat it and you are done..If the cancer has spread to the surgical margin, you are not done. Radiation can be used to clean up after the surgeon. This is called "salvage radiation"..It succeeds (produces a cure) about 50% of the time...The radiation can be combined with Hormone Therapy, HT, increasing it's effectiveness substantially but subjecting your husband to heavy side-effects.. That's enough for one night, read the books and talk it over and make your choices...

Get pre-approvals for any treatment. In making the choice of what treatment to pursue, another book, "Winning the Battle against Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Gerald Chodak presents all the treatments in an unbiased manner and is up to date.. A typical treatment plan, you do surgery (pick the best surgeon you can find) and if the margins are clear and his PSA drops to undetectable after 6 weeks, chances are you beat it and you are done..If the cancer has spread to the surgical margin, you are not done. Radiation can be used to clean up after the surgeon. This is called "salvage radiation"..It succeeds (produces a cure) about 50% of the time...The radiation can be combined with Hormone Therapy, HT, increasing it's effectiveness substantially but subjecting your husband to heavy side-effects.. That's enough for one night, read the books and talk it over and make your choices...

Posts.Title: Newbie's wife.

Posts.Content: The G-8 finding means you hit it as hard as you can with everything that's available to you...Make an appointment and visit with a Medical Oncologist..Get his feeling about which treatment would be the best for you..Your Urologist might say that's not necessary at this time...Do it anyway.....Ask for a referral to see a Radiation Oncologist too...Usually, surgery does not work very well against Gleason 8, 9, 10 prostate cancer. To achieve a cure, the surgeon must get it all, every last cell, or the surgery is bound to fail...Radiation has come a long ways over the last 10 years..Better equipment, better procedures, better outcomes, fewer side-effects...Ask the Radiation Oncologist you confer with if he performs Brachytherapy (seed implants).. That procedure combined with IMRT (beam) radiation has demonstrated it can achieve the highest cure rates when performed by experts...Remember that all the doctors you visit with will have a product or procedure he will want to sell you.. Pick up a copy of Dr. Walsh's book "Guide to surviving prostate cancer". It will give you the background you need to make informed decisions...All of the treatments have their benefits and their shortcomings..You will have to decide what's best for you...

Posts.Title: Surgery vs Radiation/Hormone

Posts.Content: It was, I think my worst moment when I lost my membership in the zero club...But life goes on! Find a Medical Oncologist you like , one that specializes in treating prostate cancer maybe, or at least has many prostate patients, and work out a treatment plan..Hormone therapy or ADT is not fun, the side effects are bad, but it's usually very effective at putting you back in the zero club for a good long while..First, they might like to do a couple of scans to see if they can spot the exact location of the source of the PSA..Sometimes they can still zap it with radiation....Then you decide on whether you will start the ADT immediately or postpone that until your PSA rises to an agreed on level. This approach preserves your quality of life as long as possible...There are good arguments for starting ADT both sooner or later... In the meantime, there is a supplement, Pomi-T, that the Brits have had good success with, what the heck, it can't hurt anything.. http://www.pomi-t.com/asco-pomi-t-study-summary/

Posts.Title: Concerned Partner

Posts.Content: Hormone therapy or ADT is chemical castration.....It's like being a Enoch..Erections are pretty much a thing of the past..The good news is you won't care about sex anymore so becoming impotent is not a big thing, for you at least..Your partner might not see it that way... Will things return to normal when ADT is stopped after 2 years? Sometimes...It will take a while. The effect of the Lupron does not reverse itself quickly, especially when you are over 60. It will take a year at least to recover...During this stressful time, your MO should be keeping a close watch on your PSA and your Testosterone levels..Some men recover faster than others...Some men become impatient and ask their doctors to put them on hormone replacement therapy.. I think with your G-9 pathology, your doctors will not be too enthusiastic about that..Best of luck to you..

Posts.Title: rectile dysfunction after 2 years of hormone therapy

Posts.Content: You already know you have prostate cancer....Five years have passed.....You have had no active treatment. It's time for another biopsy, it's as simple as that...Active Surveillance is FINE in your case but a biopsy now and then is a part of Active Surveillance..This time, send the slides out to an expert lab that specializes in doing prostate pathology..Make SURE it's just a tiny spot of Gleason 6...Prostate cancer is tricky. There is usually more than just one tumor. Different tumors can have different Gleason scores...By avoiding a biopsy, you are betting your life you only have one small Gleason 6 tumor...Your PSA history seems to suggest that, nothing to worry about..But still....

Posts.Title: William Shatner & PSA

Posts.Content: Six years ago when I became eligible for Medicare, I chose "Medicare Advantage" and in that category I chose an HMO type plan that has many doctors, hospitals and clinics in The Group that I can choose from..I have suffered no nasty billing surprises. I pay the published copay and that's that..The downside is I must stay in my group which is basically the entire Denver area..If you like to travel, this type of insurance puts you at a disadvantage because it will not pay if you are outside your area...You can buy a plan that offers nationwide coverage but it's considerably more expensive..

Posts.Title: What to take to the hospital

Posts.Content: It was, I think my worst moment when I lost my membership in the zero club...But life goes on! Find a Medical Oncologist you like , one that specializes in treating prostate cancer maybe, or at least has many prostate patients, and work out a treatment plan..Hormone therapy or ADT is not fun, the side effects are bad, but it's usually very effective at putting you back in the zero club for a good long while..First, they might like to do a couple of scans to see if they can spot the exact location of the source of the PSA..Sometimes they can still zap it with radiation....Then you decide on whether you will start the ADT immediately or postpone that until your PSA rises to an agreed on level. This approach preserves your quality of life as long as possible...There are good arguments for starting ADT both sooner or later... In the meantime, there is a supplement, Pomi-T, that the Brits have had good success with, what the heck, it can't hurt anything.. http://www.pomi-t.com/asco-pomi-t-study-summary/

Posts.Title: New & Wondering update 8-17-12

Posts.Content: You need to find out what Medicare would pay for these services as both the lab and the doctor routinely accept this amount as payment in full...The medical industry has a three price system. The list price, the one you were quoted which virtually no one pays..The negotiated price paid by the big insurance companies and the lowest price, that paid by Medicare for treating those patients over 65..It's not fair that patients with no insurance are expected to pay the highest price.. Knowing you had no insurance, you are lucky you were able to have the biopsy performed without paying cash up front...

Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Billing

Posts.Content: An MRI can not diagnose prostate cancer. Only a biopsy can do that. Prostate cancer that has metastasized to the bones almost always will produce a PSA of WAY above 1.7 So cancer is pretty unlikely the cause of your pain..... The next steps in your diagnosis will likely be dictated by your insurance company. A bone scan would be nice but until you are diagnosed with PC they are unlikely to approve that unless your doctors can work some magic..

A Urologist is not a medical student....A DRE has one of two possible results: "Normal" and "Abnormal"..I would call and ask him how he rated yours..If "abnormal" that explains the need for another PSA test in 4 months....

Posts.Title: Post Surgery Post Radiation - Doctors Suggestions for ED

Posts.Content: Six years ago when I became eligible for Medicare, I chose "Medicare Advantage" and in that category I chose an HMO type plan that has many doctors, hospitals and clinics in The Group that I can choose from..I have suffered no nasty billing surprises. I pay the published copay and that's that..The downside is I must stay in my group which is basically the entire Denver area..If you like to travel, this type of insurance puts you at a disadvantage because it will not pay if you are outside your area...You can buy a plan that offers nationwide coverage but it's considerably more expensive..

Posts.Content: You need to find out what Medicare would pay for these services as both the lab and the doctor routinely accept this amount as payment in full...The medical industry has a three price system. The list price, the one you were quoted which virtually no one pays..The negotiated price paid by the big insurance companies and the lowest price, that paid by Medicare for treating those patients over 65..It's not fair that patients with no insurance are expected to pay the highest price.. Knowing you had no insurance, you are lucky you were able to have the biopsy performed without paying cash up front...

Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Billing

Posts.Content: A PSA in that range USUALLY (but not always ) means prostate cancer, advanced prostate cancer..But none of us are doctors and this is all guesswork... There ARE men with very high PSA numbers but no cancer found after multiple biopsies..Not many fall into this category but it happens...You will know a lot more after the biopsy and some followup tests and procedures that will define the extent of his cancer, if any..... In the meantime, pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" and learn everything you can so you can make some informed choices regarding any treatment that may come....Keep your chin up, it's not the end of the world, Best of luck to you both...

Posts.Title: Biopsy Consult Question

Posts.Content: The standard MRI is not sensitive enough to locate prostate cancer until it's pretty far advanced. When your PSA gets up to 50 or 100 the mets begin to show up..... There are a couple of far more sensitive imaging methods available but not all cancer centers are equipped to perform them and when performed they are very expensive and your insurance company is likely to balk....Talk to your Medical Oncologist about whether these advanced scans would benefit you.. There are no side effects associated with Lupron injections..The loss of testosterone causes the litany of undesirable side-effects...Unfortunately, this treatment is also the most effective at restraining advanced prostate cancer...To make matters worse, insurance won't pay for the more advanced treatments until it has been demonstrated the hormone therapy is no longer effective. So if you refuse hormone treatment because you don't like the side-effects, you also forfeit the newest treatments unless you can pay cash for them... Back to the scans...There are men who have sought out the advanced scans, located a few small tumors, usually on the bones someplace but sometimes just a few lymph nodes and then they have had these small mets zapped with radiation. This has been successful in controlling their cancer but since it's not a standard treatment, getting insurance companies to pay for it has been a problem..

Posts.Title: Could I please ask for your help again, re: PSA

Posts.Content: Do I have this correct? In May 2013 a biopsy revealed 5 of 13 cores positive including one a 4+4 high-risk Gleason 8.. Then 18 months later, November 2014 a second biopsy found only a smaller amount of Gleason 6 cancer...but also involved an abnormal DRE... The only explanation I can think of is that the slides of your first biopsy got mixed up somehow and that first biopsy was grossly incorrect it or was for a different person.. I have never seen or heard of a Gleason 8 biopsy with lots of grade 4 cells identified reducing itself to a Gleason 6 finding with no grade 4 cells found.... Did the same urologist and pathology lab perform both of your biopsies?? If so, I would be demanding an explanation as to why they are so different....It's common for high-risk prostate cancer to appear very quickly from nowhere but it's unheard of for a 4=4=8 finding to melt away and only a modest 3=3=6 can be found 18 months later... It might be worth running a DNA test on both sets of slides to be sure they are from the same person....You should have copies of both biopsy reports... To settle the discrepancy, a "saturation biopsy" could be performed removing all doubt as to where you stand......

Posts.Title: My Husband has recently been diagnosed with Prostate cancer

Posts.Content: ADT or HT or Hormone Therapy, it's all the same thing, Chemical Castration. It's as simple as that...It costs a lot more than physical castration and sometimes it's not as effective. If your time on ADT is only temporary, an adjunct treatment to radiation, then when you stop taking the drugs your testosterone should return to normal and the effects are reversed. But after 3 or more years on the drugs, the effect tends to become permanent.. So what are the "side-effects"? Well they add up to the heaviest load of quality of life changes associated with prostate cancer treatment..In exchange for controlling your incurable cancer, they transform you into a eunuch...The list of physical changes is well known and easy to look up... But given the benefit most men receive, most men choose the life extension HT provides....When HT is administered to men over 65, the effects are hot flashes, loss of most body hair, loss of sex drive and ability, weight gain, fatigue, loss of muscle and bone mass, the whole package...

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About HT

Posts.Content: Surgery is performed far more often than Brachy, by a factor of 8 or 10 to one..So of course there are more complaints regarding surgery..But if not performed by a true expert, brachy can get just as ugly as poorly performed surgery...You might benefit by reading 'Winning the Battle Against Prostate Cancer" by Gerald Chodak..It lays out the unvarnished truth about ALL the prostate cancer treatments and it's up to date...

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed 10 days ago, insights sought

Posts.Content: Keytruda is the latest and greatest treatment for several different types of cancer...Its use against Prostate Cancer would have to be called experimental.."They" would not be treating your Dad with it unless he gave his approval to do so...This drug CAN have spectacular results...It can also have severe side-effects, patients must be very carefully monitored.... How old is your Dad? What was his PSA when he was first diagnosed? Is he also taking Lupron along with the Xtandi? Where does he live? Is he being treated by one of the big cancer treatment centers?

Posts.Title: Looking for advice and emotional support with new Prostate Ca diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Today, the better surgeons usually manage to remove ALL the prostate gland, so having detectable PSA after surgery is somewhat rare in cured patients..But it does happen..The post surgery PSA number and its velocity are what determines if further treatment is necessary...

Posts.Title: How bad is hormone treatment

Posts.Content: The standard MRI is not sensitive enough to locate prostate cancer until it's pretty far advanced. When your PSA gets up to 50 or 100 the mets begin to show up..... There are a couple of far more sensitive imaging methods available but not all cancer centers are equipped to perform them and when performed they are very expensive and your insurance company is likely to balk....Talk to your Medical Oncologist about whether these advanced scans would benefit you.. There are no side effects associated with Lupron injections..The loss of testosterone causes the litany of undesirable side-effects...Unfortunately, this treatment is also the most effective at restraining advanced prostate cancer...To make matters worse, insurance won't pay for the more advanced treatments until it has been demonstrated the hormone therapy is no longer effective. So if you refuse hormone treatment because you don't like the side-effects, you also forfeit the newest treatments unless you can pay cash for them... Back to the scans...There are men who have sought out the advanced scans, located a few small tumors, usually on the bones someplace but sometimes just a few lymph nodes and then they have had these small mets zapped with radiation. This has been successful in controlling their cancer but since it's not a standard treatment, getting insurance companies to pay for it has been a problem..

Posts.Content: Did your Dad have symptoms that led doctors to his diagnosis or was it discovered routinely (the PSA test that was 60) before he had any symptoms? Many men can have advanced PC but have no symptoms...The fact that his PSA is now undetectable seems to point to the fact that his present treatment is working quite well....Perhaps the symptoms he is experiencing now are not cancer symptoms but are the side-effects of the Lupron (HT) which for many men are pretty nasty....

Posts.Title: Keytruda for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome.....First, pick up a copy or two of Dr. Pat Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer " and both you and your Dad read it... Your fathers prognosis will depend on several numbers. First, his PSA at the time of the biopsy. under 10 is better than over 10...Next, the highest Gleason number found in the prostate biopsy results..Nothing over Gleason 6, he will live to die of something else..Gleason 7 will require more aggressive treatment but most men survive a long time and many are cured completely..Gleason 8, 9, 10 is aggressive cancer and will require aggressive treatment...But it's not hopeless by any means ! Prostate cancer is slow-growing and there are MANY effective treatments and drugs that can cure it or at least hold it in check for a long time..... So read the book and obtain a copy of that biopsy report (the Urologist will provide a printed copy if you ask for one) Stop worrying ! This is NOT the end of the world ! Dad is going to be just fine !

Posts.Title: A few questions following Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: ADT or HT or Hormone Therapy, it's all the same thing, Chemical Castration. It's as simple as that...It costs a lot more than physical castration and sometimes it's not as effective. If your time on ADT is only temporary, an adjunct treatment to radiation, then when you stop taking the drugs your testosterone should return to normal and the effects are reversed. But after 3 or more years on the drugs, the effect tends to become permanent.. So what are the "side-effects"? Well they add up to the heaviest load of quality of life changes associated with prostate cancer treatment..In exchange for controlling your incurable cancer, they transform you into a eunuch...The list of physical changes is well known and easy to look up... But given the benefit most men receive, most men choose the life extension HT provides....When HT is administered to men over 65, the effects are hot flashes, loss of most body hair, loss of sex drive and ability, weight gain, fatigue, loss of muscle and bone mass, the whole package...

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About HT

Posts.Content: You can't rush into radiation treatment before you are pretty much completely healed from the surgery...The radiation will stop the healing and recovery process right where it is. ED and incontinence issues will be locked in....You CAN start ADT, hormone treatment, right now and that will stop the cancer from spreading while you a waiting to recover from the surgery...I agree, find a good medical oncologist to take the lead position and have a consultation with a Radiation Oncologist..

Posts.Content: ADT or HT or Hormone Therapy, it's all the same thing, Chemical Castration. It's as simple as that...It costs a lot more than physical castration and sometimes it's not as effective. If your time on ADT is only temporary, an adjunct treatment to radiation, then when you stop taking the drugs your testosterone should return to normal and the effects are reversed. But after 3 or more years on the drugs, the effect tends to become permanent.. So what are the "side-effects"? Well they add up to the heaviest load of quality of life changes associated with prostate cancer treatment..In exchange for controlling your incurable cancer, they transform you into a eunuch...The list of physical changes is well known and easy to look up... But given the benefit most men receive, most men choose the life extension HT provides....When HT is administered to men over 65, the effects are hot flashes, loss of most body hair, loss of sex drive and ability, weight gain, fatigue, loss of muscle and bone mass, the whole package...

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About HT

Posts.Content: The dose is measured in Grays..(Gy) The usual total dose administered by EBRT for prostate cancer is 72 to 80 gray usually given in 40 fractions, , about 1.8 Gy per treatment.. The greater the dose, the more effective it is in killing cancer cells. Unfortunately, once you cross that 80 Gy line, side-effect risk increases rapidly..By dividing the dose by 40, side-effects are greatly reduced without compromising the effectiveness too much.. Studies have shown that the most effective form of radiation combines both EBRT and brachytherapy. This method allows a much higher overall dose, 145 gray, without undue side-effects. Not all men are eligible for this combined treatment.. Your insurance will be billed for each treatment, about $2000 a pop..By using 45 fractions instead of the more common 40, your R.O. just generated an extra $10,000 in treatment costs..But he may have good reasons for using more fractions... Your PSA puts you in the high-risk category and this justifies very aggressive treatment. the side-effects from the radiation are usually easily tolerated, not much at all..Unfortunately, that is not the case with hormone therapy or ADT. This will have major side-effects that will test your marriage.. Nancy will be affected by this just as much as you will...

Posts.Content: Keytruda is the latest and greatest treatment for several different types of cancer...Its use against Prostate Cancer would have to be called experimental.."They" would not be treating your Dad with it unless he gave his approval to do so...This drug CAN have spectacular results...It can also have severe side-effects, patients must be very carefully monitored.... How old is your Dad? What was his PSA when he was first diagnosed? Is he also taking Lupron along with the Xtandi? Where does he live? Is he being treated by one of the big cancer treatment centers?

Posts.Title: Keytruda for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Did you dad have the usual TRUS (trans-rectal ultra sounded guided) biopsy? They seldom take that many cores using that method. Perhaps they did a "saturation" biopsy, done in the hospital under general anesthesia..They go in through the perineum, not the rectum for that one.. The really important information obtained from the biopsy would be how many positive cores and what Gleason score was assigned to each sample..Gleason 8, 9 and 10 is bad news..Gleason 6 and 7 is better news..

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA and biopsy recommended - Q on Causes of elevated PSA

Posts.Content: ADT or HT or Hormone Therapy, it's all the same thing, Chemical Castration. It's as simple as that...It costs a lot more than physical castration and sometimes it's not as effective. If your time on ADT is only temporary, an adjunct treatment to radiation, then when you stop taking the drugs your testosterone should return to normal and the effects are reversed. But after 3 or more years on the drugs, the effect tends to become permanent.. So what are the "side-effects"? Well they add up to the heaviest load of quality of life changes associated with prostate cancer treatment..In exchange for controlling your incurable cancer, they transform you into a eunuch...The list of physical changes is well known and easy to look up... But given the benefit most men receive, most men choose the life extension HT provides....When HT is administered to men over 65, the effects are hot flashes, loss of most body hair, loss of sex drive and ability, weight gain, fatigue, loss of muscle and bone mass, the whole package...

Posts.Title: Prostate info for friend

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome.....First, pick up a copy or two of Dr. Pat Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer " and both you and your Dad read it... Your fathers prognosis will depend on several numbers. First, his PSA at the time of the biopsy. under 10 is better than over 10...Next, the highest Gleason number found in the prostate biopsy results..Nothing over Gleason 6, he will live to die of something else..Gleason 7 will require more aggressive treatment but most men survive a long time and many are cured completely..Gleason 8, 9, 10 is aggressive cancer and will require aggressive treatment...But it's not hopeless by any means ! Prostate cancer is slow-growing and there are MANY effective treatments and drugs that can cure it or at least hold it in check for a long time..... So read the book and obtain a copy of that biopsy report (the Urologist will provide a printed copy if you ask for one) Stop worrying ! This is NOT the end of the world ! Dad is going to be just fine !

Posts.Title: Prostate info for friend

Posts.Content: Fasteddie, you may be one of the lucky G9 guys that are cured by your surgery...Your post-op stats look great...Now it's just a waiting game..Each year that goes by with undetectable PSA is a landmark..After 5 years, you can start to relax... There was a time not too long ago when a G9, G10 diagnosis meant you had 2, maybe 3 years left if you were lucky..Today, most of us in that group can make it 8 or 10 years, some longer than that... About all you can do is watch that PSA closely for a while and live an active, healthy lifestyle...

Posts.Title: My brother just diagnosed w/ PC stage 4

Posts.Content: You need to sit down with a Kaiser Radiation Oncologist and discuss your wishes with him and find out what your options are..An alternative to HD Brachy is combining standard Brachy with IGRT which delivers the highest possible dose and is very effective. Many R.O.'s now add a 6-12 month run of HT to make the radiation even more effective. While quality of life issues are very important, staying alive is even more important and would be my first priority..

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA and biopsy recommended - Q on Causes of elevated PSA

Posts.Content: As Chuck said, we need more information..How old are you both? After his surgery, there would have been a pathology report. Very important information. You should have a printed copy of it..If not, call the surgeon and ask for one..The Gleason score is very important and if there were any positive margins. Radiation treatment is no big deal..The worst thing is the time involved (and the cost, depending on his insurance) 40 trips into the treatment center, that gets kind of old...But, depending on a lot of factors, it can still produce a cure...If he rejects treatment, the opportunity for a cure will be lost..

Posts.Title: Newbie: This is not looking good.

Posts.Content: Hormone therapy will stop the cancer in its tracks for a while in most cases...Sometimes it's used to prepare the patient for radiation treatment which can be curative..The PSA of 30 puts Dad in the high-risk group but if metastasis can not be detected there is still a chance he can be cured..If he is being treated by a Urologist, ask that doctor what his treatment plan is...If you don't like what you hear, get a second opinion. To include a talk with a Radiation Oncologist.. The HT by itself will not cure him. As the months go by, the side-effects caused by the HT can be disturbing. You need to investigate all his options and get a long-term prognosis....

Posts.Title: Stopping hormone therapy after PSA undetectable for two years?

Posts.Content: The key number in prostate cancer screening and detection is his PSA number...0.5 to 4.0 is the normal range in a healthy male, with 4.0 being the upper limit in an older man with a moderately enlarged prostate gland. See if you can find in his medical records any results from PSA tests he may have had..In the UK he may have fallen through the cracks because unless he requested a PSA test doctors don't normally perform them...Prostate cancer can progress for years undetected because symptoms don't appear until the disease is well advanced and incurable...

Posts.Title: Post Prostatectomy, what is the general consensus on testosterone treatment?

Posts.Content: The truth is, the Urologists and Oncologists will "argue" over who will do it because it's so profitable..The same drug, Lupron Depot is made by several drug companies under different names (Lupron, Eligard) available in 1 month, 3 month 4 month and 6 month formulations..There is all kinds of wheeling and dealing backstage between the doctors, drug companies and insurance companies to determine which drug YOU will get, who will administer it and how much the insurance will pay for it....It's a profit center for all involved..

Posts.Content: Your bladder gets lazy and shrinks up from the catheter...You need to work at increasing its capacity by retaining your urine for as long as you can..Resist that urge to go for as long as you can and your capacity should increase quickly as you stretch your bladder out...

Posts.Title: Hello from a newbie and a couple of questions.

Posts.Content: Gleason 7 always means there is grade 4 tumor present and that is aggressive enough to require treatment. It's not going to get better if your wait. It can only get worse and become more difficult to treat successfully..I would investigate the combination of seeds (Brachytherapy) and IMRT which is very effective and has an acceptable side-effect risk... Many people age 60 do not have adequate health insurance, so be sure to find out who is going to pay for what before you sign any treatment contracts..Radiation treatment can be very expensive, costing 3 times what surgery would cost..

Posts.Title: Do I really need treatment?

Posts.Content: I would be doing a PSA test every month or at least every two months, along with a testosterone check, to see how he is responding to the ADT...The faster his PSA falls and to what level it drops to is a good forecaster as to how effective this treatment will be..Recent trials have shown that using chemo early instead of late is considerably more effective...The more bone mets you can zap with radiation, the better....Best of luck to you both...

Posts.Title: The more I research the more confused I am

Posts.Content: Biopsies are not without risk, especially when your are 79..Steps must be taken to guard against infection and excessive bleeding....Also, at 79 your treatment options are limited. You can pretty much rule out surgery, too risky..In the U.K. radiation treatment seems to be rationed to those most likely to receive the greatest benefit. At 79, you might not make the cut...Chemo?? I would hold off on that until you have tried ADT, Hormone Therapy, which is usually very effective at controlling prostate cancer for a good many years.. In The States, NO treatment for prostate cancer would start until a biopsy verified that the patient had prostate cancer..The health insurance companies set the rules..Of course, if you have enough money to pay for treatment yourself, you can do anything you want as far as treatment goes... So let us know how your request for a biopsy goes and come back and post the results of that biopsy and we can go over that with you...Best of luck to you...You might read Dr. Walsh's book mentioned in the stickies above..

Posts.Title: Am I getting the truth

Posts.Content: The Radiation Oncologist who told you to have surgery because In your DH case, PSA is not a reliable marker for cancer progression and if treated with radiation alone it would be difficult to tell if the treatment was effective or not, that makes sense to me..Curing your husbands cancer is the number one goal right now..Dealing with the possible side-effects of his treatment are and must be secondary issues....Also, if you have not already, get a full-body MRI and one of the newer sophisticated bone scans that can spot mets of very small size..You really must know if the horse has left the barn before you begin a treatment path that assumes the horse is still in the barn..Since his PSA is useless in helping to track that, other means (scans) must be used. You may have to fight with his insurance company to get the scans approved.. As for Proton Radiation, in treating prostate cancer, it has not been able to demonstrate any advantages over photon (x-ray) radiation so getting insurance coverage is very difficult and it's very expensive...

Posts.Title: Travel

Posts.Content: The leg issue you describe is not part of hormone treatment that I am aware of...The $4200.00 for a 90 day shot seems a little expensive...I think $2000 for a 6 month shot is what they like to get...A generic substitute is available, Leuprolide, but the issue could be the 3, 4 and 6 month formulations which are called Lupron Depot. These long-lasting timed release injections might not be available as a generic..Lupron competes with Eligard, same drug, different system of timed release..You have every right to know the cost of any medications prescribed to you. ASK whoever is administering the shots (your urologist?) what the various medication options cost. In your situation, you need a medical plan that covers the drugs you are likely to need..They call it the "formulary", a list of all the drugs they will cover..Different insurance plans have different formularies..I would call Blue Cross and plead your case. Sometimes these things can be worked out. You just have to jump through the hoops... If you provide us with some basic information, your age, PSA history, treatment history, Gleason score if known, we could be much more specific with our opinions and recommendations..There are no doctors here, just guys like you who have been down this road we call our journey.. If your HT was part of your radiation treatment, maybe it's time you allowed your testosterone to recover and see how your PSA responds. I'm assuming your PSA is undetectable now...?

Getting your insurance company to go along with this viewpoint can be difficult...

Posts.Title: On the PSA, free PSA, (now PCA3) treadmill

Posts.Content: Before Dr. Walsh developed the "nerve sparing" surgical technique, impotency was almost 100%..That was the price you paid..After the nerve sparing technique was developed, impotency rates dropped to "only" 50% instead of 100%....The new procedure gives you a 50% chance instead of no chance. Recovery can take a while..You can buy an inexpensive penis pump on eBay for a reasonable amount of money and experiment with that and the ED pills..I would work with these, give it some time, and then perhaps ask your Urologist about Trimix injections which are given directly into the penis after some instruction in the proper technique..These almost always work, sometimes too well, with erections lasting over 4 hours..

Posts.Title: ED Therapy after robotic surgery?

Posts.Content: AR or SR radiation is radiation...Wait and see what that first post-op PSA test looks like..Radiation will stop the healing and recovery process right where it is so unless the need is compelling, I would wait as long as necessary to fully recover from the surgery before beginning the RT. Try to find a RO who has access to a newer LINAC, the machine that will be used to deliver the radiation..The newer equipment has made big advances over the older machines and they do a much better job especially when it comes to avoiding damage to healthy tissue...I would insist on a Varian Rapid-Arc or newer....it costs no more...

Posts.Title: SHARP Radiation Therapy

Posts.Content: A second opinion on the slides is not a bad idea...If an expert prostate pathologist see some 3+4+7 in there, that could change your treatment plan...Also, PC is multi-focal. The average cancerous prostate gland will contain 7 separate and distinct tumors..Usually, the needle biopsy misses some of those so you cant depend on the biopsy results being 100% accurate. Pick up a copy of Dr. Pat Walch's book, "Surviving Prostate Cancer" and learn what you are dealing with... Question your surgeon more closely about his experience. How many Prostatectomies has he performed using the daVinci robot?

Posts.Title: Husband Gleason 9 (5+4)

Posts.Content: " Radiation on the other hand, has a very low incidence of impotence or incontinence, however, you probably won't know the results of that for several years." If you look at radiation and surgery at the 5 year post treatment mark, the impotence and incontinence percentages become very close..With radiation, it just sort of sneaks up on you, along with other radiation related side-effects...So maybe we should mention that AGE plays a role in treatment choice..Younger men are more likely to suffer radiations side-effects if they live long enough. Radiation is the gift that keeps on giving...With surgery, what you get is what you get..Side-effects tend to get better, not worse. This is especially true in young men... Gleason scores at biopsy also play an important role in treatment choice..The G-8,9,10 guys, they might as well hit it with EVERYTHING that's available to them...The president of the American Cancer Society publicly stated that almost half of all prostate cancers were not life-threatening and did not need to be treated. Then he added: "However, there are some prostate cancers that can not be cured, that have already spread no matter how early they are discovered." That's why the Docs order MRI's and bone scans before they offer or recommend a treatment.. My own treatment has been surgery, (failed) Radiation + HT, (failed) and now ADT (double blockade, still working)..My first choice would have been Brachy + EBRT but here in Denver, there are few practitioners of this procedure and my HMO type health insurance will not pay for out of area services..Also, my prostate was enlarged to the point that Brachy was not a good match for me....At the time, 85% of the prostate surgeries being performed in Denver were being done on the Da Vinci robot, and my surgeon was a good one but I knew going in that surgery only offered me a 50-50 chance of success but that was better than no chance...

Posts.Title: Factors to consider when deciding on primary treatment...

Posts.Content: Yes indeed, you are very lucky and did very well for a high-risk patient (Gleason 9). Usually, with almost all G-9's, follow up treatment is recommended (HT + RT) "just to be sure"...But in your case your doctors may take the wait and see approach, checking your PSA every 3 months for the next year or two instead of moving right into adjunct radiation treatment..It's a tough call and I would seek out some expert advise on this before I made any decisions about further treatment..But it looks good so far, the best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Gleason 9 4+5 in the capsule. Need opinions

Posts.Content: A second opinion on the slides is not a bad idea...If an expert prostate pathologist see some 3+4+7 in there, that could change your treatment plan...Also, PC is multi-focal. The average cancerous prostate gland will contain 7 separate and distinct tumors..Usually, the needle biopsy misses some of those so you cant depend on the biopsy results being 100% accurate. Pick up a copy of Dr. Pat Walch's book, "Surviving Prostate Cancer" and learn what you are dealing with... Question your surgeon more closely about his experience. How many Prostatectomies has he performed using the daVinci robot?

Posts.Title: Diagnosed today, What do the number mean?

Posts.Content: Lupron Depot was first patented in 1993. Patents give protection for 20 years. So the patent expired in 2013...But to maintain their grip on the market, drug companies find ways to keep drugs protected from generic producers by changing the delivery method, gaining a new patent for the same basic drug then taking the old drug off the market..These drugs (cancer drugs) are simply too profitable for the drug companies to allow generic producers to get into the market..MASSIVE political contributions insure the status quo is maintained...

Posts.Title: Come on Man!!

Posts.Content: Prostate cancer tends to be multi-focal. When removed for biopsy, the average cancerous prostate gland has seven distinct and separate tumors...They can be of widely different Gleason grades. And they can develop quickly..I had 3 prostate biopsies. The first two were clean..The third one, done 8 months after the second, revealed my prostate was full of cancer, mostly G-6 but one nasty G-9...Why? How is this possible? Nobody can answer that...It's just what is...

Posts.Title: Starting Lupron

Posts.Content: If you had nodes tested positive for cancer, then forget Urologists, your condition needs to be treated by a Medical Oncologist. And yes, 30% of the time a prostate biopsy that only finds Gleason 6 misses a pocket of higher grade cancer...Were you ever offered surgery or radiation to treat your cancer when it was first diagnosed? The New Mexico Cancer Center in Albq. seems to have fairly high ratings. You might check in with them for a second opinion..If you get resistance with Regular Medicare, you might look into Medicare Advantage which many medical facilities will take that refuse regular medicare....As for the VA, I get most of my routine medical services there, including expensive cancer drug prescriptions..But as a first line cancer treatment center, you can probably do better outside the VA system....Oncology is just not their strong point... But for sure, with your PSA at 13 or higher you need to get on ADT NOW...Don't just let that cancer take off uncontrolled....

Posts.Title: Immediate or delayed ADT

Posts.Content: There is another back-stage issue going on here...With most of the newer, very effective drugs, (Zytiga, Xtandi) you must be judged "hormone refractory" (the Lupron is not working any more) before insurance companies (including the VA) will pay for them...So if you don't start (and then fail) ADT, you will never be eligible to receive these drugs...Also, the latest studies and trials have shown that starting Chemo early in the treatment of advanced PC works much better than starting it late..A trial that combines Chemo with Zytiga has produced excellent results... I hate to say this but in many areas Dr. Walsh's book is becoming outdated and no longer valid....The basic stuff is still good but parts dealing with advanced treatments have fallen behind....

Posts.Title: Immediate or delayed ADT

Posts.Content: "parenchyma of prostate glandular substance consisting of small compound tubulosaccular or tubuloalveolar glands, making up the bulk of the prostate; it is surrounded by muscular substance and permeated by muscular strands." In plain English, it's prostate tissue....But that does not mean prostate tissue was left behind...Your surgeon might have trimmed away any "leftovers" he noticed and that extra tissue never made it to the pathologist for examination... One of the first rules of these journeys is never look back..You can't do anything about yesterday...Instead, focus on tomorrow where you CAN change the path of your journey....

Posts.Title: Can someone please explain what transection of Prostatic Parenchyma means....

Posts.Content: The Radiation Oncologist who told you to have surgery because In your DH case, PSA is not a reliable marker for cancer progression and if treated with radiation alone it would be difficult to tell if the treatment was effective or not, that makes sense to me..Curing your husbands cancer is the number one goal right now..Dealing with the possible side-effects of his treatment are and must be secondary issues....Also, if you have not already, get a full-body MRI and one of the newer sophisticated bone scans that can spot mets of very small size..You really must know if the horse has left the barn before you begin a treatment path that assumes the horse is still in the barn..Since his PSA is useless in helping to track that, other means (scans) must be used. You may have to fight with his insurance company to get the scans approved.. As for Proton Radiation, in treating prostate cancer, it has not been able to demonstrate any advantages over photon (x-ray) radiation so getting insurance coverage is very difficult and it's very expensive...

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis - RALP vs. IMRT vs. Proton Beam for PC

Posts.Content: ADT or Hormone Therapy or HT is usually the preferred treatment for an 80 year old..In many men, it is very effective, controlling prostate cancer for 10 years and even longer. Unfortunately, this is not true for all men..The AVERAGE period of effectiveness for HT is about 3 years. 50% of those treated in this manner become hormone refractory by the 3 year mark...Many oncologists start their PC patients on Lupron and when the PSA starts to rise they add Casodex and finally Finasteride, completing the Triple Blockade...When THAT becomes ineffective as determined by PSA monitoring, they move onto the new drugs and treatments that are available which can extend survival considerably further. At this point there is no "Standard Treatment" because all men respond differently to these treatments. Quality of life issues must be considered along with survival...

AgeInfo.Phrase: the preferred treatment for an 80 year old  In many men

Posts.Title: PSA rising after IMRT with Lupron

Posts.Content: Relax...I doubt your biopsy will find any cancer (but you never know)....If the biopsy comes back negative, you may wish to check your PSA every 6 months to establish your PSA velocity, the rate of change. That's far more important than the actual PSA number...There are other more sophisticated blood tests that can better predict the presents of prostate cancer. So don't make yourself sick by worrying...

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA - nervous

Posts.Content: Goatts, your HT is part of, adjunct too your upcoming radiation treatment. You will probably be on HT for 2 years.. There is a sticky at the top of this board that details all the likely side-effects. It has been demonstrated the HT in conjunction with RT improves the R/T outcome considerably. Otherwise nobody would do HT at this stage of their treatment, the side-effects are just too onerous..The hot-flashes become a constant reminder but the less noticed effects are just as insidious...

Posts.Title: Overwhelmed

Posts.Content: There is nothing to it...You check into the Pre-Op lounge..They put you in a Johny on a gurney and start an IV..The surgeon and Anesthesiologist both come in and say hello. You will sign some papers....Shortly, the Anesthesiologist comes back, asks if you are ready to go...if so, he injects something into your IV and the next thing you know, you are in Recovery, with a very attentive nurse asking you how you feel...After about an hour, they take you up to your room...Welcome back to the world..Next day, they put you in a wheel-chair, take you out front and someone takes you home..Bring a pair of "sweat pants" and a sweater to travel in..When they are explaining your catheter, get all the accessories you can out of them..Especially the velcro straps that hold everything in place...That's it, Your done...best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: Immediate or delayed ADT

Posts.Content: There is nothing to it...You check into the Pre-Op lounge..They put you in a Johny on a gurney and start an IV..The surgeon and Anesthesiologist both come in and say hello. You will sign some papers....Shortly, the Anesthesiologist comes back, asks if you are ready to go...if so, he injects something into your IV and the next thing you know, you are in Recovery, with a very attentive nurse asking you how you feel...After about an hour, they take you up to your room...Welcome back to the world..Next day, they put you in a wheel-chair, take you out front and someone takes you home..Bring a pair of "sweat pants" and a sweater to travel in..When they are explaining your catheter, get all the accessories you can out of them..Especially the velcro straps that hold everything in place...That's it, Your done...best of luck to you !

Posts.Title: PSA Velocity after RP - What is normal?

Posts.Content: If you had nodes tested positive for cancer, then forget Urologists, your condition needs to be treated by a Medical Oncologist. And yes, 30% of the time a prostate biopsy that only finds Gleason 6 misses a pocket of higher grade cancer...Were you ever offered surgery or radiation to treat your cancer when it was first diagnosed? The New Mexico Cancer Center in Albq. seems to have fairly high ratings. You might check in with them for a second opinion..If you get resistance with Regular Medicare, you might look into Medicare Advantage which many medical facilities will take that refuse regular medicare....As for the VA, I get most of my routine medical services there, including expensive cancer drug prescriptions..But as a first line cancer treatment center, you can probably do better outside the VA system....Oncology is just not their strong point... But for sure, with your PSA at 13 or higher you need to get on ADT NOW...Don't just let that cancer take off uncontrolled....

Posts.Title: New study. Prevalence of Prostate Cancer on Autopsy in undiagnosed men 60+

Posts.Content: This was posted on another forum. It's one of the better explanations I've seen..The posters handle is Knotreel.. "what's happening requires an explanation of your sphincter system. Before the RRP, you had two sphincters, one sphincter associated with your prostate and bladder neck and one at your pelvic floor. You still have the sphincter located in your pelvic floor. The prostate/bladder sphincter is involuntary with no conscious control. The pelvic floor sphincter is mostly consciously controlled (except not so much during sex). Here's roughly how they work. In the case of urination, the bladder fills to a point then the involuntary sphincter opens and allows pressure to be felt by your pelvic floor voluntary sphincter according to bladder pressure. Then you know its time to go and you consciously open the pelvic floor sphincter and urine flows through both sphincters. After the RRP we no longer have the prostate/bladder sphincter In the case of sex, after you gain an erection the "brain" down there tells your prostate sphincter to close and to relax the pelvic floor sphincter. Then when ejaculation occurs the fluid is forced though the relaxed pelvic floor sphincter. Females only have the pelvic floor sphincter and males have the other on that closes during sex so that the ejaculate fluid goes where it supposed to, rather than back into the bladder. So when us prostate-less guys we have sex, our only remaining sphincter the usually , the usually voluntary pelvis floor sphincter is trying to relax and there is no prostate sphincter to hold back the urine. I really don't see how this is not a major issue for everyone without a prostate but some of us are apparently not bothered much with this, but I would guess that all of us must have this to some degree. Best thing you can do for now is empty your bladder before."

Posts.Title: Incontinence while ejaculating.

Posts.Content: Relax...I doubt your biopsy will find any cancer (but you never know)....If the biopsy comes back negative, you may wish to check your PSA every 6 months to establish your PSA velocity, the rate of change. That's far more important than the actual PSA number...There are other more sophisticated blood tests that can better predict the presents of prostate cancer. So don't make yourself sick by worrying...

Posts.Title: Scared of Meeting da Vinci

Posts.Content: " Radiation on the other hand, has a very low incidence of impotence or incontinence, however, you probably won't know the results of that for several years." If you look at radiation and surgery at the 5 year post treatment mark, the impotence and incontinence percentages become very close..With radiation, it just sort of sneaks up on you, along with other radiation related side-effects...So maybe we should mention that AGE plays a role in treatment choice..Younger men are more likely to suffer radiations side-effects if they live long enough. Radiation is the gift that keeps on giving...With surgery, what you get is what you get..Side-effects tend to get better, not worse. This is especially true in young men... Gleason scores at biopsy also play an important role in treatment choice..The G-8,9,10 guys, they might as well hit it with EVERYTHING that's available to them...The president of the American Cancer Society publicly stated that almost half of all prostate cancers were not life-threatening and did not need to be treated. Then he added: "However, there are some prostate cancers that can not be cured, that have already spread no matter how early they are discovered." That's why the Docs order MRI's and bone scans before they offer or recommend a treatment.. My own treatment has been surgery, (failed) Radiation + HT, (failed) and now ADT (double blockade, still working)..My first choice would have been Brachy + EBRT but here in Denver, there are few practitioners of this procedure and my HMO type health insurance will not pay for out of area services..Also, my prostate was enlarged to the point that Brachy was not a good match for me....At the time, 85% of the prostate surgeries being performed in Denver were being done on the Da Vinci robot, and my surgeon was a good one but I knew going in that surgery only offered me a 50-50 chance of success but that was better than no chance...

Posts.Content: That was quick....G-6 is low-risk PC, very few men ever die from it..The IMRT should take care of it with minimal side-effects. After a week of treatments, you get into a groove and just coast along..You may have some urinary issues, increased frequency and urgency after #15 or so, but after your treatment ends, that slowly goes away...Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: Overwhelmed

Age.Phrase: 5 sounds normal for a 49 year old  DRE would not

DoctorRecommended.Sample: Gleason 8 is aggressive and frequently leads to follow-up treatment following surgery..There will be some detailed scans before they start radiation to try and determine if the cancer has spread...Don't be surprised if your doctors recommend combining the radiation treatment with hormone treatment..This doubled barrel approach seems to work considerably better than radiation by itself......The grade "4" sample means AS would be pretty risky.. If it were me, I would have it treated with curative intent..The URO will recommend surgery because that's what he does...But I would talk to a Radiation Oncologist and see what he has to offer..Then YOU decide what's best for you...Don't overlook brachytherapy (seeds)....Then he added: "However, there are some prostate cancers that can not be cured, that have already spread no matter how early they are discovered." That's why the Docs order MRI's and bone scans before they offer or recommend a treatment.. My own treatment has been surgery, (failed) Radiation + HT, (failed) and now ADT (double blockade, still working)..My first choice would have been Brachy + EBRT but here in Denver, there are few practitioners of this procedure and my HMO type health insurance will not pay for out of area services..Also, my prostate was enlarged to the point that Brachy was not a good match for me....At the time, 85% of the prostate surgeries being performed in Denver were being done on the Da Vinci robot, and my surgeon was a good one but I knew going in that surgery only offered me a 50-50 chance of success but that was better than no chance......See what he thinks about doing both surgery and radiation..Ask HIM to recommend a Radiation Oncologist and talk with him too...Pick up a copy of Dr Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer" and read it carefully. THEN decide on a course of treatment and don't look back....Best of luck to you......There are no doctors here..Find a good Medical Oncologist and sit down and have a long talk with him. See what he thinks about doing both surgery and radiation..Ask HIM to recommend a Radiation Oncologist and talk with him too...Pick up a copy of Dr Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer" and read it carefully....Surgery might be one of them but don't rush into it before you have a complete understanding about what is going on. Read the book I recommended to get a solid background about what your are facing before you make a treatment decision..Be warned, the doctors will all push the product they are selling......G-9 is considered "high-risk" and it is NOT unusual for the surgeon to recommend "adjutant" radiation treatment following surgery, especially if the post-surgery pathology report is less than perfect...Recent studies have demonstrated that by adding hormone treatment to the radiation, the radiation becomes 50% more effective than when it is used alone... Debating "salvage" and "adjunct" radiation is just nit-picking, really...It is important that you get yourself as continent as possible before any adjunct radiation treatment as the radiation pretty much stops progress on that front..Going on HT can buy you time in that regard......While my PSA at diagnosis was similar to yours, I had less overall cancer in the cores, only one core with G-9..My surgeon told me surgery had a 50-50 chance of delivering a complete cure, but that with G-9, I should expect to do follow-up radiation regardless..My radiation oncologist said forget the surgery, you will need radiation anyway, so lets just do radiation and HT..I then talked with a Medical Oncologist. Explained my quandary..He gave it some thought and then told me "I would try the surgery first, and move on to radiation if that fails"....I took his advise..The surgery DID fail, my PSA hung at 0.9..Not only that, I developed a hospital acquired staff infection that put me back in the hospital for a week and I.V. antibiotics for a month..My only lingering side-effect is 100% impotence..The hot flashes have stopped now that I'm off the HT but I've lost some muscle mass....Have your testosterone level checked..Not all men get the desired response from the Lupron..Your "T" level should be less than 20 and ideally less than 10..If it's not, perhaps going back on the Casodex would be of benefit.. Your primary care doctor can perform these tests for you..Surgery is not usually recommended in advanced cases, it can't cure you if the horse has left the barn..But it CAN remove 98% or more of the cancer and that leaves just 2% (or whatever) to deal with and not 100%..Radiation might be a better choice as they can focus the beam on a wider area..Lots of things happen back stage, between the doctors and the insurance companies..(radiation costs about 4 times as much as surgery) In this business, nothing happens until it's decided who is going to pay for it.....KLA, before we can offer advise and help, you need to clarify your Gleason score.. Gleason 5 (3+2=5 or 2+3=5) is seldom if ever reported as being positive for cancer. Few if any urologists would recommend surgery...But if ONE of the grades in your Gleason score is a 5, (4+5=9) then that is serious....Few if any urologists would recommend surgery...But if ONE of the grades in your Gleason score is a 5, (4+5=9) then that is serious. You can get a copy of your biopsy report from your doctor simply by asking for one....You want to see his PSA at 8-12 weeks post surgery..Any ED or incontinence problems will be locked into place by the radiation, no more improvement after that... Also, it is becoming standard to include HT, hormone therapy for at least a year, more often 2 years, before, during and after radiation as it has been shown to make the radiation more effective..He can start that anytime, the sooner the better. of course, that will lock in the ED for as long as he is on it... The doctors can recommend and offer treatments but YOU decide which ones you wish to pursue..Always get a second opinion before you commit to treatments that come with serious side-effects....With a PSA of 5, your scans will probably be clean..That means your treatment team can go for a CURE..That's right, CURE..At 71, surgery is pretty risky so that leaves some form of radiation treatment, which is just as effective but with fewer potential side-effects..The Gleason 9 puts you the high-risk group so you can expect aggressive treatment to be recommended..Is the Grim Reaper just a step behind you ?? NO !! With today's treatments and drugs with more coming soon, they can CURE you or worst case, keep you going for another 8 or 10 years...So enjoy the weekend and stop worrying about things you can't do anything about.. At some point you will want to have a discussion with a Radiation Oncologist....If it were me, I would have it treated with curative intent..The URO will recommend surgery because that's what he does...But I would talk to a Radiation Oncologist and see what he has to offer..Then YOU decide what's best for you...Don't overlook brachytherapy (seeds). Not all RO's can provide that treatment.....Chief, consider Johns advise carefully...There is NO SENSE in undergoing BOTH surgery AND radiation...Choose the treatment that offers the BEST CHANCE of producing a CURE...It is very hard to justify doing surgery when even the surgeon expects radiation will be needed to finish the job....Laying radiation on top of surgery really compounds the side-effect issues..It is the skill of your doctors that will determine your outcome, so choose them carefully..Best of luck to you.....
